div3.p: *(h r(htorikh/ e)stin a)nti/strofos th=| dialektikh= is translated by Cicero, ex altera parte respondere dialecticae, Orat. XXXII 114. ‘Vox a scena ducta videtur. Chori antistrophe strophae ad assem respondet, eiusque motus ita fit, ut posterior in prioris locum succedat...Significat ex altera parte respondere et quasi ex adverso oppositum esse; id quod etiam in antistrophen cadit.’ Trendel. El. Log. Arist. § 14 p. 74: and to the same effect, Comment. ad Arist. de Anima, II 11 5 p. 408. ‘a)nti/strofon dicitur quod alius rei quasi partes agit eamque repraesentat;’ Waitz, Comm. ad Anal. Pr. I 2, 25 a 6.

The term is borrowed from the manoeuvres of the chorus in the recitation of the choral odes. *strofh/ denotes its movement in one direction, to which the a)ntistrofh/, the counter-movement, the wheeling in the opposite direction, exactly corresponds, the same movements being repeated. Müller, Diss. Eumen. p. 41. Hist. Gr. Lit. c. XIV § 4. Mure, Hist. Gk. Lit. Bk. III. c. 1 § 15. Hence it is extended to the words sung by the chorus during the latter of these evolutions, and signifies a set of verses precisely parallel or answering in all their details to the verses of the strofh/. And thus, when applied in its strict and proper sense, it denotes an exact correspondence in detail, as a fac-simile or counterpart.

Hence in Logic a)ntistre/fein is used to express terms and propositions which are convertible, and therefore identical in meaning, precisely similar in all respects. On the various senses of a)ntistre/fein and its derivatives in Logic, see Waitz, u. s. In this signification, however, a)nti/strofos does not properly represent the relation actually subsisting between the two arts, the differences between them being too numerous to admit of its being described as an exact correspondence in detail; as I have already pointed out in the paraphrase (Introd. p. 134).

It also represents Rhetoric as an art, independent of, though analogous to, Dialectics, but not growing out of it, nor included under it. The word is of very frequent occurrence in Plato (Gorgias, Republic, Philebus, Timaeus, Theaetetus, Leges), who joins it indifferently with the genitive and dative; and he employs it in this latter sense; as likewise Isocrates, peri\ a)ntid. § 182; and Aristotle himself in several places; Polit. VI (IV) 5, 1292 b 7, kai\ e)/stin a)nti/strofos (corresponding)
au(/th e)n tai=s o)ligarxi/ais w(/sper h( turanni\s e)n tai=s monarxi/ais. c. 6 ult. 1293 a 33. c. 10, 1295 a 18. de part. anim. II 17 ult. e)n me\n ou)=n tou/tois toi=s zw/|ois h( glw=tta toiau/th th\n fu/sin e)sti/n, w(/sper a)ntistro/fws e)/xousa tw=| mukth=ri tw=n e)lefa/ntwn.

Lastly, Waitz, u. s., points out a peculiar signification of it, ‘res contraria alteri quam potestate aequiparat,’ in de Gen. Anim. II 6, 743 b 28. to\ yuxro
 suni/sthsin a)nti/strofon (as a balance) th=| qermo/thti th=| peri\ th
 kardi/an to
 e)gke/falon. Trendelenburg, Comm. ad de Anima u. s., after defining a)ntistre/fein as above, adds, a)nti/strofos ex eadem chori similitudine significat ex altera parte respondere (this is from Cicero, u. s.) Arist. Rhet. I 1; quod non significat, rhetoricam in dialecticae locum succedere (i.e. can be substituted for it, step into its place, as a convertible term), sed quasi ex adverso esse oppositam (stands over against it, as a corresponding opposite in a sustoixi/a, two parallel rows of coordinate opposites, like the partners in a country dance). Quintilian, Inst. Orat. II 17, 42, specie magis quam genere differunt.

The term a)nti/strofos therefore applied to the two arts, seems to represent them as two coordinate opposites, or opposites in the same row (see Spengel on the study of Rhetoric, Munich 1842, p. 21). They are sister arts, with general resemblances and specific differences; two species under one genus, proof: both modes of proof, both dealing with probable materials, but distinguished by the difference of the two instruments of proof employed: the one concluding by the formal svllogism, and by the regular induction, assumed complete; the other drawing its inferences by the abbreviated, imperfect, conversational enthymeme, never complete in form, and by the single example in the place of the general induction.

Rhetoric is afterwards described as parafue/s, mo/rion and o(moi/wma (infra c. II § 7). parafue/s and mo/rion both express in different ways the relation that Rhetoric bears to Dialectics as the off-shoot, branch, or part; a species or variety of the general art of probable reasoning: parafue/s as a subordinate shoot, growing out of the same root with the larger plant or tree,—a term so far corresponding with a)nti/strofos, but differing from it in making Rhetoric subordinate. mo/rion reduces it to a still lower level in comparison with the other. o(moi/wma implies no more than a mere general resemblance.

In Sext. Empir. adv. Math. VII 6, occurs an explanation of a)nti/strofos, quite in character with the ordinary Greek etymologies, r(htorikh/n, h(=s a)nti/strofon ei)=nai th
 dialektikh/n, (not referring apparently to this passage, but most probably to the sunagwgh\ texnw=n) toute/stin i)so/strofon, dia\ to\ peri\ th
 au)th
 u(/lhn stre/fesqai (versari circa), as Homer called Ulysses a)nti/qeon instead of i)so/qeon. Alexander (infr.) gives the same explanation.
Bacon Adv. of learning Bk. II IX 3, has antistrophe for ‘correspondence’, “and it hath the same relation or antistrophe that the former hath.”

The points of correspondence and difference between the two arts have been already fully explained in the Introduction, p. 90 foll.: I will here give a summary of them from Alexander's Commentary on the
Topics, p. 4. They are 1. that both of them are mh\ peri\ e(/n ti ge/nos a)fwrisme/non; that is, that neither of them has any special subject-matter, like the sciences, but argues or perorates upon any thesis or subject whatsoever that can be presented to it. 2. to\ di) e)ndo/cwn kai\ piqanw=n, no proof or conclusion, or principle, that they employ is more than probable; exact demonstration and necessary conclusions are excluded from both alike; pi/stis, belief, the result of mere persuasion, and not e)pisth/mh, the infallible result of scientific demonstration, being the object aimed at. 3. mh\ di) oi)kei/wn a)rxw=n, they have no ‘special, appropriate’ first principles, such as those from which the special sciences are deduced; though they likewise appeal to the ta\ koina/, the koinai\ a)rxai/, the ultimate axioms and principles common to all reasoning, which are above those of the special sciences, and from which the latter must be deduced. And, 4. they are o(moi/ws peri\ ta\ a)ntikei/mena a)llh/lois; they argue indifferently the opposite sides of the same question, and conclude the positive or negative of any proposition or problem; unlike science and demonstration, which can only arrive at one conclusion. Where the materials and the method are alike only probable, every question has, or may be made to appear to have, two sides, either of which may be maintained on probable principles; in Dialectics and Rhetoric no certainty is either attained or attainable. The chief points of difference between them are, that Dialectics deals practically as well as theoretically with every kind of problem or question that can be submitted to it; proceeds by question and answer, in the way of debate, and its discussions are of a more general or universal character; whereas the subjects of Rhetoric are practically, though not theoretically, almost absolutely limited to Politics; it follows a method of continuous narration or explanation (diecodikw=s), and deals in its conclusions rather with individual cases than with general principles or universal rules, maxims and axioms.

Alexander, in a preceding passage, gives the following very extraordinary account of the derivation and original meaning of a)nti/strofos: to\ ga\r a)nt. a)nti\ tou= i)so/strofo/n te kai\ peri\ ta\ au)ta\ strefome/nhn kai\ kataginome/nhn le/gei.
koina\ a(pa/ntwn] See Introd., p. 87, and the Paraphrase, pp. 134—5.

a)fwrisme/nhs] ‘marked off, separated by a limit’, from every thing else about it; and so ‘definite, special’ (§ 7). 1, 2, 1 peri/ ti ge/nos i)/dion a)fwrisme/non, opposed to peri\ tou= doqe/ntos. Polit. I 13, 1260 b 1 a)fwrisme/nhn tina\ doulei/an (a definite, limited, kind of slavery). Ib. IV (VI) 4, 1290 b 25 a)podiori/zein. a)fori/zetai (h( th=s yuxh=s du/namis) pro\s ta\s a)/llas duna/meis tw=| e)/rgw| tou/tw|, “this capacity of the soul is marked off, separated, distinguished, from all the rest by this function,” de Anima II 4, 9, 416 a 20. The preposition is similarly used in the compound a)poble/pein, which is ‘to look away, or off’, from all surrounding objects, so as to fix the attention on one particular thing, or turn it in one particular direction. Comp. Lat. definire, determinare.

Parallel passages, in which this same characteristic of Rhetoric and
Dialectics is noticed, are cited in the Introd. p. 75. See also Quintilian, II 21, 16—19, on the province of the orator.
e)ceta/zein...lo/gon] Note 1, Introd. p. 135. h( dialektikh\ e)cetastikh/, Top. A 2, 101 b 3.

sunh/qeian] ‘habituation, familiarity, practice’, acquired by association (prop. that of living or herding together). Top. A 14, 105 b 27 th=| dia\ th=s a)pagwgh=s sunhqei/a| peirate/on gnwri/zein e(ka/sthn au)tw=n (tw=n prota/sewn). See also on I 10, 18. This sunh/qeia is derived from the constant operation or activity, the e)ne/rgeiai, of the developed and acquired and settled e(/cis, or mental state (e(/cis from e)/xein, ‘to be in such and such a state or condition’, to\ pw=s e)/xein): by the constant exercise of the e(/cis, or established confirmed habit, and its e)ne/rgeiai, is produced by association that familiarity, or habituation, or practice, which secures success even to the empirical unartistic use of Dialectics or Rhetoric.
ei)kh=| tau=ta dra=|n is the use of them antecedent to practice, and without previously acquired familiarity: a)po\ tau)toma/tou, by a mere spontaneous impulse, and therefore ‘at random.’

‘Est autem dialectica,’ says John of Salisbury, Metalogicus, II 4, ‘ut Augustino placet, bene disputandi scientia: quod quidem ita accipiendum est ut vis habeatur in verbis; ne scilicet dialectici credantur, quos casus iuvat artis beneficio destitutos.’
au)ta/] Rhetoric and its processes.

o(dopoiei=n] ‘to make a way’; to trace a path to be followed, which will lead you without unnecessary deviations to the place at which you wish to arrive. o(do/s therefore, in this metaphorical usage, is not merely a way, but the way, the best way; the way which will lead you most surely and expeditiously to the end proposed. Hence it denotes a regular, systematic, or scientific method; the best and easiest way of attaining the end desired in any intellectual pursuit or branch of study. And thus it is that the simple o(do/s, as well as the compound me/qodos, come to denote a scientific or systematic procedure in the pursuit of truth as a philosophical ‘method’, or in any art or study. Hence we find o(dw=| dih|rh=sqai, Plat. Phaedr. 263 B, of a systematic methodical scientific division; and Rep. VII 533 D: kaq' o(do/n, in the same sense, Rep. IV 435 A, and Crat. 425 B. In Aristotle, de gen. et corr. I 8, 2 o(dw=| de\ ma/lista peri\ pa/ntwn...diwri/kasi *leu/kippos kai\ *dhmo/kritos. de part. Anim. 14, 9 pw=s me
 ou)=n a)pode/xesqai dei= th
 peri\ fu/sews me/qodon, kai\ ti/na tro/pon ge/noit' a)
 h( qewri/a peri\ au)tw=n o(dw=| kai\ r(a=|sta... Anal. Pr. I 30 init., h( me
 ou)=n o(do\s kata\ pa/ntwn h( au)th\ kai\ peri\ filosofi/an kai\ peri\ te/xnhn o(poianou=n kai\ ma/qhma. Top. B 2, 109 b 14 o(dw=| ga ma=llon kai\ e)n e)la/ttosin h( ske/yis. Eth. Nic. I, 2 a)po\ tw=n a)rxw=n h)\ e)pi\
ta\s a)rxa\s h( o(do/s. Dionysius, de Comp. Verb. c. 25, has h( r(htorikh\ o(do/s for the more usual me/qodos: and again o(dw=|, de Comp. Verb. c. 4 sub fin. From this usage of the Greek word the Latins seem to have borrowed their via or via et ratione, which frequently occurs in precisely the same sense. See Cicero de Fin. III 5, 18, IV 4, 10; Orat. III 10, XXXIII 116; de Orat. I 25, 113. Quint. II 17, 41 esse certe viam atque ordinem in bene dicendo nemo dubitaverit; and x 7, 6 via dicere.

The verb o(dopoiei=n is found in the same sense, Met. A 3, 984 a 18. proi+o/ntwn d' ou(/tws, au)to\ to\ pra=gma w(dopoi/hsen au)toi=s kai\ sunhna/gkase zhtei=n, and Rhet. III 12, 3 (according to MS A^{c} and some others); and the substantive o(dopoi/hsis, III 14, 1.

proodopoiei=n, which occurs several times in Aristotle (as Rhet. II 2, 10, II 13, 7, III 12, 3, Prob. XXX 1, 954 b 12, de part. Anim. II 4, §§ 4, 5, 6, III 9, 8, de gen. anim. IV 4, 9, peri\ *mantikh=s, I 11. Polit. II 9, 1270 a 4, IV (VII) 17, 1336 a 32, and V (VIII) 3, 1338 a 35 pro\ o(dou=), has a meaning slightly differing from the preceding. The metaphor is now taken from the office of pioneers, who precede an advancing army, and prepare, clear, or ‘pave the way’ for them.

di) o(/...th
 ai)ti/an] th
 ai)ti/an is here grammatically the antecedent to o(/, the cause, ai)ti/a, being in the relative pronoun expressed as an abstract notion (‘the cause, which thing’) in the neuter. A similar change from feminine to neuter, in antecedent and relative, occurs in de Anima 1 3, 407 a 4 th
 ga tou= panto\s (yuxh
) toiau/thn ei)=nai bou/letai oi(=o/n pot' e)sti
 o( kalou/menos nou=s, Pol. II 2 init. kai\ di) h(
 ai)ti/an fhsi\ dei=n nenomoqeth=sqai... ou) fai/netai sumbai=non e)k tw=n lo/gwn, and in Eur. Iph. T. 900 (Herm.) h( d' ai)ti/a ti/s a)nq) o(/tou ktei/nei po/sin; where o(/tou must be understood as neuter: see Hermann on v. 1038.

seq. To the same effect III 14, 8 dei= de\ mh\ lanqa/nein o(/ti pa/nta e)/cw tou= lo/gou ta\ toiau=ta: pro\s fau=lon ga a)kroath
 kai\ ta\ e)/cw tou= pra/gmatos a)kou/onta, e)pei\ a)
 mh\ toiou=tos h)=|, ou)qe
 dei= prooimi/ou—as the vehicle for appeals to the feelings and other indirect proofs addressed to the judges personally, which were usually introduced into the prooi/mion.
pi/steis] rhetorical, not demonstrative, proofs; modes of belief, of things probable; all the materials and arguments of Rhetoric being probable merely, none of them certain. See Introd. p. 136 note.

prosqh=kai...sw=ma th=s pi/stews] All kinds of indirect proof are secondary, subordinate, non-essential, mere ‘adjuncts’ or ‘appendages’, like dress or ornaments to the body: ‘the body’ being the actual, logical, direct and substantial proof of the case. What is here called ‘the body’, meaning
the substance as opposed to accidents, we usually represent by ‘the soul’ in this same relation; the body in its turn now standing for the accidents and non-essentials of a thing. So the Scholiast on Hermogenes, Proleg. (quoted by Ernesti, Lexicon Technologiae Graecae p. 110, Art. e)nqu/mhma) oi( palaioi\ w(/sper ti zw=|on to
 lo/gon u(pe/qento e)k sw/mato/s te sunesthko/ta kai\ yuxh=s: yuxh
 me
 kalou=ntes ta\ e)nqumh/mata kai\ th
 du/namin th
 dia\ tw=n kefalai/wn sunistame/nhn: sw=ma de\ th
 fra/sin kai\ to\ e)/cwqen ka/llos, o(\ poiei=n ei)w/qasin ai( i)de/ai. And Cicero, Orat. XIV 44 nam et invenire et iudicare quid dicas magna illa quidem sunt et tamquam animi instar in corpore.

Quintilian describes the views of some of those who thus rigorously limit the province of Rhetoric as an art—ai( pi/steis e)/ntexno/n e)sti mo/non— to the employment of the ‘enthymeme’, the rhetorical representative of the logical and demonstrative ‘syllogism’; with the exclusion of all that is, strictly speaking, ‘beside the subject or real issue’, all that is beside the facts of the case and the direct proof of them; all indirect proof, namely, from the assumed character of the speaker himself, or appeals to the feelings of the judges or audience, and also all ornaments and graces of style and delivery. Aristotle here assumes this to be theoretically the only true and proper method, though he by no means consistently adheres to it in his actual treatment of the subject. Quintilian's description is as follows, though, as the reasons for the exclusion of these indirect proofs are somewhat different from those assigned by Aristotle, he probably does not refer immediately to him: Fuerunt et clari quidem oratores quibus solum videretur oratoris officium docere. Namque et affectus duplici ratione excludendos putabant: primum quia vitium esset omnis animi perturbatio; deinde quia iudicem a veritate depelli misericordia vel ira similibusque non oporteret: et voluptatem audientium pctere, quum vincendi tantum gratia diceretur, non modo agenti supervacuum sed vix etiam viro dignum arbitrabantur. Inst. Orat. V. Prooem. I.
On the general question of appeals to the feelings, Quint. II 17, 26 seq.: and on the prevailing practice, Isocr. peri\ a)ntid. § 321.

pragmateu/esqai is well explained by Bonitz on Metaph. A 6, 987 a 30. ‘pragmateu/esqai peri/ ti, vel peri/ tinos is dicitur ab Aristotele, qui in investiganda et cognoscenda aliqua re via ac ratione procedit; itaque coniunctum legitur cum verbis diale/gesqai, zhtei=n, qewrei=n’. The primary sense of doing business, or occupying oneself about anything, passes into the more limited or special signification of an intellectual pursuit, and thence of ‘a special study’, ‘a systematic treatment of a particular subject of investigation, or practice’ (as in this present case, of Rhetoric, comp. § 10). pragmatei/a, like me/qodos, te/xnh, e)pisth/mh, filosofi/a, and many other words, is used to express not only the intellectual process of investigation, but also the resulting science, art, treatise, or written work, or part of such work. See on this point, Introd. p. 17, note 2. Also, on the general meaning of the term, Waitz on Anal. Post. II 13, 96 b 15. Trendel. de Anima p. 199. Elem. Log. Arist. § 58, p. 135.

diabolh/ from diaba/llein ‘to sunder or set at variance’, and so
‘to make hostile, to engender a mutual dislike between two parties’, in its technical application to Rhetoric, of which it is a potent instrument; and with its opposite a)polu/esqai ‘to absolve oneself, clear away from oneself ill-feeling and suspicion’, forms one of the principal topics of the prooi/mion (see Introd. pp. 343, 4). It denotes the exciting of suspicion and ill-will in the minds of the judges or audience, in order to prejudice them against the opponent with whom you are in controversy: and is therefore improperly classed with the pa/qh or emotions such as e)/leos and o)rgh/. This has been already noticed by Victorius and Muretus: the latter says, ‘diabolh\ non est pa/qos, sed pertinet ad iudicem ponendum e)n pa/qei.’

Top. *d 5, 126 a 31. [dia/bolon] to\n duna/menon diaba/llein kai\ e)xqrou\s poiei=n tou\s fi/lous. These words, which seem to be a mere gloss upon dia/bolon in the text of the Topics, occur apparently in one MS only, marked u by Waitz, and inserted by him in the critical notes of his edition, Vol. II p. 144. Bekker altogether omits to notice them. Though of no authority they will equally well answer the purpose for which they are here employed, of helping, namely, to define the meaning of diabolh/.
On pa/qos and pa/qh, see Introd. pp. 113—118.

ou) peri\ tou= pra/gmatos dikasth/n] Appeals to the feelings are e)/cw tou= pra/gmatos: they are ‘beside the proper subject, the real question, the direct issue’, which is the fact and the proof of it; and ‘directed to the judge’, intended to bias and pervert his judgment, to incline him to our side in the contest, and so to have the effect of a secondary or indirect kind of proof of the justice of our case.

w(/st' ei) peri\ pa/sas—le/gwsin] Similarly in Rhet. III 1, 4, it is said of the ornaments of style, and declamation in general, as of appeals to the feelings here, that they are only allowed to be employed dia\ th\n moxqhri/an tw=n politeiw=n; in well-governed states they would not be permitted at all.

oi(\ me/n...oi(\ de/] ‘either...or’. The one only think that the laws ought to be so framed, hold the opinion as a theory; the others, as the Court of Areopagus, actually (kai/, also, besides the mere theory) carry it into practice, kai\ xrw=ntai.

e)n *)arei/w| pa/gw|] Heindorf ad Theaet. § 76. Lycurgus c. Leocr. §§ 12, 13, quoted by Gaisford, kai\ tau=ta ka/lliston e)/xontes tw=n *(ellh/nwn para/deigma to\ e)n *)arei/w| pa/gw| sune/drion, o(\ tosou=ton diafe/rei tw=n a)/llwn dikasthri/wn, w(/ste
kai\ par' au)toi=s o(mologei=sqai toi=s a(liskome/nois dikai/an poiei=sqai th\n kri/sin, pro\s o(\ dei= kai\ u(ma=s a)poble/pontas mh\ e)pitre/pein toi=s e)/cw tou= pra/gmatos le/gousin: k.t.l.

Lucian, Hermotimus, c. 64, has something similar about the practice of this court, a)lla\ kata\ tou\s *)areopagi/tas au)to\ poiou=nta: oi(\ e)n nukti\ kai\ sko/tw| dika/zousin, w(s mh\ ei)s tou\s le/gontas a)ll' ei)s ta\ lego/mena a)poble/poien. (Lucian ed. Hemsterh. I p. 805), and again, Anacharsis s. de Gymn. c. 10, (Vol. II p. 898) oi( de\ (dikazo/menoi) e)/s t' a)
 me
 peri\ tou= pra/gmatos le/gwsin a)ne/xetai h( boulh\ kaq) h(suxi/an a)kou/ousa: h)
 de/ tis h)\ froi/mion ei)/ph| pro\ tou= lo/gou, w(s eu)nouste/rous a)perga/saito au)tou/s, h)\ oi)=kton h)\ dei/nwsin e)/cwqen e)pa/goi tw=| pra/gmati, oi(=a polla\ r(hto/rwn pai=des e)pi\ tou\s dikasta\s mhxanw=ntai, parelqw
 o( kh=ruc katesiw/phsen eu)qu/s, ou)k e)w=n lhrei=n pro\s th
 boulh/n k.t.l. There are several allusions to the same in Quintilian, II 16, 4, VI 1, 7, X I, 107, XII 10, 26. Spalding in his note on the first of these passages calls attention to—what indeed is sufficiently apparent on the face of the statements—Quintilian's carelessness in extending to all the lawcourts of Athens, a practice actually prevailing at the most only in one of them; in spite of the direct evidence to the contrary in the extant orations of the Athenian orators, and the story of Hyperides and Phryne which he himself tells in II 15, 9.

diastre/fein] to warp, or distort to wrest out of the straight (‘right’) line or proper direction, to pervert or ‘deprave’ the judgment. The same metaphor is repeated in streblo/n. The metaphor which compares wrong, the deviation from the ‘right’ line or path, to the crooked or twisted, the divergence from the straight, and represents wrong judgment as the warping of the moral rule, occurs in various languages; skolio/s, and o)rqo/s, eu)qu/nei de\ di/kas skolia/s, Solon ap. Dem. de F. L. p. 423, skoliai=s o(doi=s patw=n, Pind. Pyth. II 156, Pl. Theaet. 173 A &c. &c. So e(likto/s, Eur. Androm. 448 e(likta\ kou)de\n u(gie\s a)lla\ pa=n pe/ric fronou=ntes. So Plato of the good and bad horse in the human chariot, Phaedr. 253 D, o( me\n...to/ te ei)dos o)rqo/s...o( d' au)= skolio/s k.t.l.

So also rectum and pravum or varum or curvum, right and wrong (wrung or twisted out of shape, distorted, similarly intortus) tort, Fr. (tortum), torto, Ital. Compare Lucretius, IV 516, denique ut in fabrica, si prava est fabrica prima Normaque si fallax rectis regionibus exit,—Omnia mendose fieri, &c. Cic. Acad. Pr. II 11, 33, interesse oportet, ut inter rectum et pravum, sic inter verum et falsum. Hor. Ep. II 2, 44, curvo dignoscere rectum, (‘virtutem distinguere a vitio’. Orelli). Pers. Sat. III 52, haud tibi inexpertum curvos deprendere mores. IV 11, rectum discernis ubi inter curva subit, vel cum fallit pede regula varo. V 38, apposita intortos extendit regula mores.

‘Crooked’ for perverse, immoral, wrong, is very common in the earlier writers of our own language. Deut. xxxii 5, a perverse and crooked generation. Ps. cxxv 5, Prov. ii 15, whose ways are crooked, and they froward in their paths. Ep. ad Phil. ii 15, and in many other places and authors. For examples of the latter, see Richardson's Dict. Art. ‘crooked’.

Very different to this are the principles laid down by the author of
the *(phtorikh\ pro\s *)ale/candron as a guide to the practice of the rhetorician, c. 36 (37) § 4. xrh\ de\ kai\ tou\s dikasta\s e)pai/nw| qerapeu=sai, w(s dikastai\ di/kaioi kai\ deinoi/ ei)sin. sumparalhpte/on de\ kai\ ta\s e)lattw/seis, ei)/ pou tw=n a)ntidi/kwn katadeeste/rws e)/xei pro\s to\ le/gein h)\ pra/ttein h)\ a)/llo ti pro\s to\n a)gw=na. The judges are to be flattered, and the opponent represented in the darkest colours, whether his alleged defects have or have not any bearing upon the matter at issue. pro\s de\ tou/tois e)mblhte/on to/ te di/kaion kai\ to\ no/mimon kai\ to\ sumfe/ron kai\ ta\ tou/tois a)ko/louqa; which is the exact contradictory of the course prescribed by Aristotle in § 6 as alike fair and in accordance with the true principles of the art.
proa/gontas ei)s] Comp. III 14, 7, and note.

ka)
 ei)/ tis...poih/seie] The process by which a)/n in this and similar forms of expression—w(s a)
 ei), w(/sper a)
 ei), kaqa/per a)
 ei), oi(o/nper a)
 ei), and the like—has lost its force, become inactive, (consopitum, ‘gone to sleep’, Buttm.,) in the sentence, is explained by Buttmann in his note on Dem. Mid. § 15, p. 530. The conditional a)/n belongs to some verb in the apodosis, originally expressed, afterwards left to be understood, as in the clause before us. The expression at full length would be, ka)
, ei)/ tis poih/seie, poih/seie, ‘as one would do, if he were to do’. Still, though the particle has lost its direct and active force in this sentence, some latent notion of conditionality always remains, even when the verb which a)
 supposes cannot actually be supplied. This is the case in such phrases as fobou/menos w(/sper a)
 ei) pai=s, Pl. Gorg. 479 A ‘fearing as a child would’: Ar. parva naturalia peri\ mantikh=s I 2, 2 o(/swn w(/sper a)
 ei) la/los h( fu/sis e)stin, ‘whose natural habit is, as it might be (a)/n), talkative’; de Anima I 5, 5, 409 b 27, w(/sper a)
 ei) th
 yuxh
 ta\ pra/gmata tiqe/ntes. In such cases the a)/n is retained by habit and association, when the sense no longer requires it. The phrase accordingly is not found in the earlier forms of the language, and does not become common till the time of Plato and Aristotle, with whom, the latter especially, it is very frequent. The association required time before it was established as a fixed habit. I believe that it does not occur in Thucydides, and that it makes its first appearance in Xenophon; that is, in the forms above given; for as an unnecessary appendage to a participle, or in cases analogous, a)/n is thus used by earlier writers. See Hermann on Soph. Phil. 491, and Jelf, Gr. Gr. § 430, I, for some instances [Kühner's Ausführliche Grammatik § 398 p. 209 sq. S.].

Aristotle seems to be the earliest writer who assumed the license of joining ka)

 ka)

those already quoted, Rhet. II 20, 4, w(/sper a)

On the ‘legal issues’, sta/seis, a)mfisbhth/seis, which, as Victorius remarks, are here tacitly referred to, see Introd. p. 397, Appendix E to Bk. III.

keime/nous no/mous] kei=sqai and some of its compounds are often convertible with the passive of tiqe/nai. kei=sqai itself ‘to be placed, fixed, established’=ti/qesqai; sugkei=sqai ‘to be put together or composed’=sunti/qesqai; diakei=sqai ‘to be disposed’=diati/qesqai; pokei=sqai (as I 2 13) ‘to be assumed’=u(poti/qesqai or u(polamba/nesqai.

[kei=mai is constantly borrowed as a perfect passive to ti/qhmi, while te/qeimai is almost invariably used as a deponent perfect. Thus the usage of the perfect in the best writers would be: o( nomoqe/ths te/qeike to
 no/mon. h( po/lis te/qeitai to
 no/mon: o( no/mos kei=tai (Dem. Or. 46 § 12 note). infra chap. 15 § 23 toi=s no/mois, a)

toi=s kri/nousi, kri/seis, tou\s kri/nontas] On the different senses of kri/nein and krith/s as applied to the different branches of Rhetoric, see Introd. p. 137 note I: and on the necessary imperfections of laws in their application to particular cases, the consequent introduction of e)piei/keia to modify them and adapt them to the circumstances of the case, and Plato's opinion, on the authority of laws, see p. 138 note I.
e)pi\ toi=s kri/nousi] e)pi/ resting, and so depending, upon; hence penes, in the power of, at the discretion of. § 8 e)pi\ toi=s kritai=s katalei/pein.

This primary, literal, and physical sense of e)pi/, (in this application of it,
which represents the object of the preposition as the basis on which something stands or rests, and therefore depends upon), of the half dozen Grammars and Lexicons, which, after forming my own opinion, I have consulted on the point, is to be found distinctly stated only in that of Rost and Palm, where it lurks hardly discoverable, amidst the enormous mass of illustrations of the various usages of e)pi/ accumulated in Vol. I pp. 1032 —1045, in p. 1038, col. 2.

ai( nomoqesi/ai e)k pollou= xro/nou skeyame/nwn gi/nontai] ‘legislation arises from (is the work of men after) long previous consideration’. Thuc. I 58, e)k pollou= pra/ssontes ou)de\n eu(/ronto e)pith/deion.

e)c u(pogui/ou] (retained by Bekker; Gaisford not. var. prefers u(pogu/ou, and so L. Dindorf, on Xen. Cyr. VI 1, 43.) u(po/guion: pro\ mikrou= gegono/s, Hesychius. e)c u(pogu/ou: par' au)ta/, a)periske/ptws, e)k tw=n su/neggus, Suidas. By the Scholiast on Arist. Nub. 145, in Suidas v. a)rti/ (Gaisf.), e)c u(pogui/ou le/gein is interpreted by au)tosxedia/zein; and in Eustath. (ap. eund.) it is said to be derived from gui=on in the sense of xei/r, (compare Theocr. Idyl. XXII 81 and 121; the ‘hand’ is the member, par excellence), from which likewise he deduces e)ggu/h, e)ggua=|n, and e)gguali/zein; and u(po/guon, o(\ kai\ e)c u(pogu/ou le/getai, to\ e)ggu/s fasi prosdo/kimon, h)\ parauti/ka gegono/s, kai\ w(s ei)pei=n pro/xeiron, h)\ ma=llon u(poxei/rion. Examples may be found, all bearing much the same sense, in Koch's note on Moeris Lex. p. 343, and a still larger list in Rost and Palm's Lex. s.v., to which add Rhet. II 22, 11; Pol. VII (VI) 8, 1321 b 17. u(poguio/taton (the readiest way or means) pro\s au)ta/rkeian. Isocr. Paneg. § 13. Menand. ap. Spengel, Rhet. Gr. III 391. In Isocr. peri\ a)ntid. § 4, and Epist. 6. 2, p. 418 B, it stands for ‘close at hand’, h)/dh u(pogui/ou moi th=s tou= bi/ou teleuth=s ou)/shs, and similarly Ar. Eth. Nic. III 9 (Bekk.) sub fin., o(/sa qa/naton e)pife/rei u(pogui=a o)/nta.

It appears from all this that u(pogui=on means ‘under the hand’, as an unfinished or just finished work, fresh and recent, pro/sfaton (so Rhet. II 3, 12) as Moeris explains it: and e)c u(pogui/ou, ‘from under the hand’, corresponds to our ‘off-hand’, or ‘out of hand’, and is used to express anything ‘sudden and unexpected’ or ‘unpremeditated’, ‘extemporaneous’ a signification which appears in all the examples. Similarly e)k xeiro/s, a)po\ xeiro<*>s, ‘off-hand’.

a)podido/nai] a word of very frequent use in Aristotle, has for one of its elementary senses that of ‘to give back’, reddere; a)po/ as in a)pone/mein, a)polamba/nein, a)paitei=n, a)po/plous, a)poplei=n (see Sturz. Lex. Xenoph.), from which all the other senses in which at least Aristotle employs it may be deduced. Another of the original senses of the word is ‘to give forth’, or ‘produce’, as the earth produces her fruits, and this also might be applied to the interpretation of it in several of its various uses. But as this signification is likewise deducible from the other—for production, as
when the earth produces her fruits, may be regarded as a payment or restoration, or ‘return’ of something as due—it may perhaps be better to refer them all to the one original signification, reddere. So in Eth. N. II 1, 1103, a 27, b 22, ta\s e)nergei/as a)podido/nai is not simply ‘to produce’, but to produce energies that are due to the system, energies corresponding to the faculties from which they spring. So Trendelenburg, El. Log. Arist. § 55, p. 132, ‘a)podido/nai proprie est reddere, unde ex suum cuique tribuendi significatione facile orta est declarandi vis (declarare is the sense which the word bears in the passage specially referred to, Top. A 5, 102 a 3) nihil enim est aliud quam logice suam cuique naturam reddere.’

a)podido/nai is therefore (1) to give back, restore, repay, render, always implying some kind of obligation, (2) to render as a due, ‘assign’ (which best represents it in the majority of cases in Aristotle); of due distribution, suum cuique; hence (3) of the due fulfilment of any office or duty, as a)podido/nai lo/gon, ‘to render an account’, to explain, or set forth, any statement or doctrine, a)pofai/nesqai, declarare. To one or the other of these I believe all the multifarious uses of the word may be referred.

I will add a few examples in the way of illustration:—Dem. c. Aristocr. p. 638 § 56, tou\s e)xqra\ poiou=ntas e)n e)xqrou= me/rei kola/zein a)pe/dwken (assigns as a due) o( no/mos; and elsewhere. Plat. Phaed. 71 E (a good example), ou)k a)ntapodw/somen th
 e)nanti/an ge/nesin (pay back in return), a)lla\ tau/th| xwlh\ (mutilated, defective, lopsided, single where all the rest are pairs) e)/stai h( fu/sis; h)\ a)na/gkh a)podou=nai k.t.l. de Anima I 1, 403 b 1, tou/twn de\ o( me
 th
 u(/lhn a)podi/dwsin, ‘assigns’ or ‘applies’, that is, to the definition, which is the thing in question, to which it assigns matter as the sole element: comp. c. 4, 408 a 3; and a)pone/mein, in precisely the same sense, ib. V 1, and Pl. Tim. 34 A. a)podidw=si make to correspond, bring into comparison, Rhet. III 11, 13. a)pod. leitourgi/an de part. An. III 14, 9, ‘duly to fulfil certain functions (services)’. Ib. II 14, 5, (h( fu/sis) pantaxou= a)podi/dwsi (makes due compensation, duly assigns) labou=sa e(te/rwqen pro\s a)/llo mo/rion. Top. *d 1, 121 a 15, et passim, to\ a)podoqe
 ge/nos, a)podido/nai ge/nos. Top. A 18, 108 b 9, th
 a)po/dosin tw=n o(rismw=n, the rendering, or due preparation, production, of definitions: and so elsewhere. de part. An. III 7, 18, a)pod. to\ e)/rgon of the due performance of the work. Ib. I 1, 43 a)pod. to\ o)stou=n ti/ e)sti, to state, give a sufficient account or explanation. Phys. I 6, 1, 189 a 16, *)empedoklh=s pa/nta a)podido/nai (to produce, effect everything) oi)/etai o(/saper *)anac. e)k tw=n a)pei/rwn. Eth. Nic. III 1, 110 b 8, poi=a de\...ou) r(a/dion a)podou=nai, to give an account, explain.

So here a)podido/nai is ‘duly to assign, distribute, or apportion’ and again I 2, 5, a)podi/domen ta\s kri/seis ‘we render our judgments’. These same applications of the word occur likewise in Plato, as Rep. 379 A, (to represent), Ib. 472 D, VI 508 E, Phaedr. 237 C, Theaet. 175 D, Polit. 295 A. The precise opposite, a)polamba/nein, occurs with the same sense of a)po/, I 11, 3. a)pone/mein is used in exactly the same sense, ‘to assign as a due’; see for instance Eth. Nic. IV 7, 1123 b 18, o( toi=s qeoi=s a)pone/momen, Ib. V 35, timh\ a)pone/metai toi=s a)gaqoi=s, Ib. 1124 a 9.

h)/dh...kri/nousin] by this time, now that we have come to them, ‘they actually decide’ So in the next line, to\ filei=n h)/dh kai\ to\ misei=n ‘this time’, in theircase, not in the former, of something new, special, and marked. h)/dh therefore in these cases is often translatable by a mere emphasis. The word is repeated so soon after, applied to the same persons, and expressing almost identically the same thing, that it is not improbable that Spengel may be right in his conjecture that the one or the other should be erased. Rhet. Gr. Vol. I. Pref. p. v. ‘paulo post alterutrum h)/dh abundat, puto prius.’ However there are two still closer together, II 25, 14.

It may be worth while to say a few words on this very common usage of h)/dh and analogous particles of time, in the way of illustration and exemplification. *)/hdh and its analogues e)/ti, ou)ke/ti, ou)/pw, are used emphatically to mark a critical point, climax, degree attained, as deserving of special and particular attention, at the moment, and in reference to something else which is not equally remarkable. They are all particles of time, and derive this their secondary sense from the metaphorical application of this notion of ‘already’, a definite time which we have just reached: ‘point’, or ‘stage’, or ‘degree’ attained being substituted by the metaphor for ‘time’ in the original sense of the word.

This will be best illustrated by a few examples. Arist. peri\ mnh/mhs kai\ a)namnh/sews c. 2. 16, w(/sper fu/sis h)/dh to\ e)/qos, ‘habit, already by this time, now that we have reached this point, has become a second nature’. Met. *d 21, 1022 b 18, e(/na de\ [tro/pon pa/qos le/getai] tou/twn e)ne/rgeiai kai\ a)lloiw/seis h)/dh, ‘one sense of pa/qos is, the actual energies and changes of these’. h)/dh, by the time that they have reached this stage or state, and have actually become what they are. Categ. c. 8, 9, a 4, h(
 a)/n tis i)/sws e(/cin h)/dh prosagoreu/soi, ‘which may now (at this stage) be fairly called a e(/cis’. peri\ e(rmhnei/as c. 9, 19, a 39, kai\ ma=llon me
 a)lhqh= th
 e(te/ran, ou) me/ntoi h)/dh (not yet actually, not quite, not yet arrived at the stage of,) a)lhqh= h)\ yeudh=. Polit. II 8, 1268 b 20, e)kei=nos h)/dh e)piorkei=. III 7, 1279 a 40, plei/ous d' h)/dh xalepo
 h)kribw=sqai. VIII (v) 8, 1308 a 15, e)/sti ga w(/sper dh=mos h)/dh oi( o(/moioi, i.e. though this may not be strictly true of all oligarchies, when we come to the o(/moioi, at this stage, by this time, it is now quite true that they may be regarded as a dh=mos. Eth. Nic. V 3, 1132 a 2, pro\s e(/teron kai\ e)n koinwni/a| h)/dh o( a)/rxwn, ‘when a man has come to be a ruler, he must then...’ in the case of others this perhaps is not necessarily true, but the ruler must, actually, live or act in relation to others and in society’. Rhet. I 6, 24, pa/ntes h)/dh o(mologou=sin. I 10, 11, h)/dh diafe/rei ‘it does make a difference’. c. 11 § 3, to\ ei)qisme/non w(/sper pefuko\s h)/dh gi/gnetai. Ib. § 26, e)/rgon h)/dh gi/gnetai. II 6 § 12, and 25 § 14, bis. I have confined myself in these illustrations to examples from Aristotle; from the ordinary language, in which this usage is at least equally common, I will content myself with citing Herod. III 5, a)po\ tau/ths h)/dh *ai)/guptos: and Eur. Hippol. 1195 (Monk) pro\s po/nton h)/dh keime/non *sarwniko/n.

It is found also in French, Italian and German—déjà, gia, schon. C'est
déjà quelque chose, ‘and that's something’. das ist schon etwas. The Italian gia, when used as an expression of assent, may be similarly explained.

The use of demum is precisely similar, and common in most Latin writers. Sallust, Cat. XX idem velle atque idem nolle ea demum (that and that alone) firma amicitia est. Quint. II 5, 1, artemque de qua loquimur bonis demum (to the good, and to them alone) tribui volunt. VII Praef. init. neque enim ea demum quae ad docendum pertinent exsecuti sumus. VII 2, 21, VIII Prooem. 3, IV 5, 7, XI 1 § 44, 3 § 68, et passim. Cic. Tusc. Disp. I 19, 43, eaque ei demum naturalis est sedes, et seq., de Orat. II 30, 131, hi loci ei demum oratori prodesse possunt. Rarer is the analogous use of denique and tandem: Cic. de Orat. II 30, 131, c. 34, 146, tum denique scrutari locos, c. 75, 304, quantum est in eo tandem mali! c. 77, 315, hisce omnibus rebus consideratis, tum denique id... Hor. Ep. I 17, 2, quo tandem pacto... On iam in this same usage, see Munro, on Lucr. I 600, 613, II 314, 426; add, II 974, and Virg. Aen. V 179, iam senior, VI 304, VII 46, 735.

Similarly in a negative sentence, ou)/pw sometimes introduces the notion of time in estimating the amount or degree, Eth. Nic. V 10, 1135 a 11, to\ au)to\ de\ tou=to, o(/tan praxqh=|, a)di/khma/ e)sti, pri\n de\ praxqh=nai ou)/pw, a)ll' a)/dikon. Ib. 23, a)/dikon me\n a)di/khma de\ ou)/pw. Ib. b 24, ou) me/ntoi pw a)/dikoi —in the two former cases the unjust habit of mind is distinguished as ‘not yet amounting to’ the actual crime or unjust act; and in the third case this distinction is applied to the a(ma/rthma, which, though a wrong in itself, has not yet reached the stage or degree of the vice, confirmed evil habit, of a)diki/a—also VI 10, 1142 b 14, au(/th ga\r ou)/pw fa/sis. Ib. 25, ou)d' au(/th pw eu)bouli/a, and 28.

So also ou)ke/ti, ‘no longer; not as before; not, now that we have reached this point’. Pol. V (VIII) 3, 1338 a 6. Rhet. I 2, 21, a)
 ga e)ntu/xh| a)rxai=s ou)ke/ti dialektikh\ ou)de\ r(htorikh/, II 24, 3, a)ll' e)kei/nh k.t.l. Ib. II 9, 3. de gen. et corr. I 2, 3, 315 b 3, pw=s de\ tou=to ou)ke/ti, Hist. Anim. I 6, 3, 490 b 16, tw=n de\ loipw=n zw/|wn ou)ke/ti ta\ ge/nh me/gala, Ib. V 1 7, 539 a 30, ta\ de\ qhle/a me/n e)stin, a)/rrena d' ou)ke/ti. Dem. de F. Leg. § 80, o(
 d' a)
 au)toi\ la/bhte mhke/t) e)kei/nois peri\ tou/tou prosta/ttete. Plat. Gorg. 503 A, ou)x a(plou=n e)/ti tou=to e)rwta=|s. Protag. 312 E. Xen. Oecon. 3. 1. Buttm. ad Mid. 13 a p. 528, ‘ou)ke/ti proprie valet non ut antea, hinc non ut alias, non item, non iam.’

sunh/rhtai] (Bekker and Spengel. Alii sunh/rthtai) ‘with whom are connected...’ In pro\s ou(/s, pro\s expresses a mere general reference, ‘with respect to whom’, ‘in whose case’; and sunh/|rhtai ‘are often taken into, embraced in, the account’, su/n, together with their proper business, the mere facts of the case and the proof of them. I can find no sufficient authority for sunairei=n in this sense; the nearest approach to it is in Plat. Phaedr. 249 B, ei)s e(\n logismw=| sunairou/menon, but even this is something different. Vater makes a similar observation. The interpretation also of pro/s is certainly rather strained. Probably sunh/rthtai is right.

to\ a)lhqe/s] No one is a fair judge, where his own passions or interests are concerned. Gaisford quotes appositely, Pol. III 16, 1287 a ult. a)lla\ mh\n ei)sa/gontai/ g' e)f) e(autou\s oi( i)atroi\ ka/mnontes a)/llous i)atrou/s, kai\ oi( paidotri/bai gumnazo/menoi paidotri/bas, w(s ou) duna/menoi kri/nein to\ a)lhqe\s dia\ to\ kri/nein peri\ tw=n oi)kei/wn kai\ e)n pa/qei o)/ntes.

e)piskotei=n] ‘to bring darkness, throw a shadow over, overshadow’. Dem. c. Mid. 565, 25, oi)ki/an w)|kodo/mhken e)n *)eleusi=ni tosau/thn w(/ste pa=sin e)piskotei=n toi=s e)n tw=| to/pw|. Infr. III 3, 3. Plat. Euthyd. 274, o( *eu)qu/dhmos e)pesko/tei tw=| *kthsi/ppw| th=s qe/as: an odd and unexplained use of this word. It seems to mean that Euthydemus, by bending forward and getting in the way, obscured or darkened Ctesippus—not however in the ordinary sense of the word, but in that of intercepting the object, and so darkening by throwing a cloud over, and thereby depriving him of his view (th=s qe/as gen. of deprivation, implied in the verb).

In a metaphorical sense it occurs in Dem. Olynth. B 23, 26, Isocr. ad Dem. § 6, and in several fragments of the Comic Poets, (Ind. ad Meineke, Fr. Com. Gr. Vol. v Pt. I p. 393,) for instance, Eubul. incert. Fr. 11 (Mein. III 267) to\n oi)=non tw=| fronei=n e)piskotei=n; and in other authors. See also Victorius: and Gaisford in not. var. p. 18.
e)/cw tou= pra/gmatos] e)/cw for e)kto/s. Lobeck, Phryn. p. 128.
ta\ e)/cw tou= pra/gmatos texnologou=sin] infra § 11; comp. de Anima I 3, 406 b 26 kai\ o( *ti/maios (Plato, in the Timaeus) fusiologei= th\n yuxh\n kinei=n to\ sw=ma.

diori/zein] to separate by a limit or boundary line. Herodot. IV 42 diourisa/ntwn *)asi/hn te kai\ *libu/hn. Hence to separate a thing from others, to mark off as a special province or domain, and so of ‘the definition’, which includes all that is essential to, or characteristic of, the thing defined, and excludes everything else. The word here of course means something more than a bare definition; it expresses the limitation or ‘determination’ of the proper contents of the prooi/mion.

e)/ntexnoi pi/steis] are the regular systematic proofs by enthymeme and example, the sw=ma th=s pi/stews § 3, and opposed here, not merely to the a)/texnoi pi/steis of c. 15, the witnesses, documents, torture, oaths and such like, which we do not invent, but find ready to our hand to be employed in the support of our case; but also to the irregular appeals to the feelings (pa/qos), and to evidence from character (h)=qos).

politikwteras th=s dhmhgorikhs pragmatei/as] pragmatei/as, here applied to the study and practice of one of the departments of Rhetoric; sec on § 3.—politikwte/ras: There are three possible senses of this word, firstly, ‘more worthy of, more becoming to, a citizen’, more agreeable to the position and duties of a citizen, ‘better and worthier’; secondly, ‘more suitable to a public man, statesman, or politician’, larger, more comprehensive, and liberal; as opposed to the comparatively trifling and petty occupations of private citizens: thirdly, more public and common, wider, more general; koino/n, as opposed to i)/dion and oi)kei=on: the second seems to be the most appropriate here, and so I have rendered it in the paraphrase. [p. 141 of the Introduction: “nobler and larger and more liberal (or ‘statesmanlike’, or ‘more worthy of a citizen’,) vid. not. ad loc.”]
meqo/dou peri\ ta\ dhmhgorika\ kai\ dikanika/] The third kind of Rhetoric, to\ e)pideiktiko/n, is here omitted, but afterwards supplied, c. 3 § 1.

th=s dhmhgorikh=s pragmatei/as h)\ th=s peri\ ta\ sunalla/gmata] ‘The most general expression which the Athenians have for a contract is sunalla/gua, sunqh/kh, sumbo/laion.’ Meier und Schömann der Attische Process p. 494. The difference usually taken between sunqh/kh and suna/llagma appears in Rhet. I 15, 22 e)/ti de\ pra/ttetai ta\ polla\ tw=n sunallagma/twn (ordinary dealings, buying and selling and such like transactions), kai\ ta\ e(kou/sia kata\ sunqh/kas (in the way of, by contracts): we are concerned here only with the first and third of these, suna/llagma and sumbo/laion.

The ordinary signification of both of these is a contract, or covenant, or mutual agreement, or interchange (suna/llagma), between two or more parties. They are thence extended to any dealings, especially business transactions, or even any circumstances of ordinary intercourse between man and man, and more particularly any of those which may give rise to a suit at law. These are i)/dia sumbo/laia or sunalla/gmata: see Dem. de Cor. p. 298 § 210, ta\ tou= kaq' h(me/ran bi/ou sumbo/laia, with Dissen's note: Isocr. Paneg. §§ 11, 78, p. a)ntid. §§ 3, 38, 40, 42, 79 ta\ kata\ th\n po/lin kai\ ta\ sumbo/laia ta\ gigno/mena pro\s h(ma=s au)tou/s. § 309 e)n toi=s a)gw=si toi=s peri\ tw=n sumbolai/wn. The former of these two seems to refer rather to dealings in general, the second to special contracts. Areop. §§ 33, 34. Arist. Eth. N. II 1, 1103 b 15 pra/ttontes ga\r ta\ e)n toi=s sunalla/gmasi toi=s pro\s tou\s a)nqrw/pous gigno/meqa oi( me\n di/kaioi oi( de\ a)gaqoi/. Rhet. I 15, 22 e)/ti de\ pra/ttetai polla\ tw=n sunallagma/twn kai\ ta\ e(kou/sia kata\ ta\s sun-
qh/kas. Rhet. ad Alex. c. 1 (2 Oxf.) § 2 tai=s peri\ ta\ sumbo/laia dikaiologi/ais.

That the meaning of the terms is not confined to contracts proper, is plain also from Eth. N. v 1131 a 2. (This passage is quoted at length on I 15, 22.) tw=n ga\r sunallagma/twn ta\ me\n e(kou/sia ta\ d' a)kou/sia (the ‘voluntary’ being illustrated by buying and selling, lending and borrowing, whereas ‘involuntary’ are all of them crimes, laqrai=a or bi/aia: all of them cases in which the breach of the supposed contract, private or public, entitles the aggrieved party to a legal remedy). Opposed to these i)/dia sumbo/laia or sunalla/gmata are the public (koina/) international commercial treaties, su/mbola. See further on su/mbola, note on c. 4 § 11.

sumbo/laia is also employed in a wider and more general sense, as Rhet. ad Alex. c. 2 (3 Oxf.) § 2 peri\ tw=n pro\s a)/llas po/leis summaxiw=n kai\ sumbolai/wn. Other examples may be found in Plat. Gorg. 484 D a)/peiroi tw=n lo/gwn oi(=s dei= xrw/menon o(milei=n e)n toi=s cumbolai/ois. Rep. I 333 A ti/ de\ dh/; th
 dikaiosu/nhn pro\s ti/nos xrei/an h)\ kth=sin e)n ei)rh/nh| fai/hs a)
 xrh/simon ei)=nai; *pro\s ta\ cumbo/laia, w)= *sw/krates. *cumbo/laia de\ le/geis koinwnh/mata, h)/ ti a)/llo; koinwnh/mata dh=ta, and several others in Ast's Lexicon. Arist. Polit. IV (VI) 16, 1300 b 22, and 32 peri\ tw=n mikrw=n sunallagma/twn, o(/sa draxmiai=a kai\ penta/draxma kai\ mikrw=| plei/onos. Ib. 15 ult. 1300 b 12, a)rxh\ h( tw=n peri\ th

pro\ e)/rgou] ‘to the purpose’; anything ‘for’, or ‘in favour of’, and therefore ‘likely to promote’, any ‘work’ we may have in hand; and hence generally ‘serviceable’ or ‘profitable’ to any purposes. pro\ e)/rgou (which also occurs infra I 4 §§ 3, 7) is the Aristotelian mode of writing what in Xenophon, Plato, Demosthenes, and indeed ordinary Greek in general, appears as prou/rgou. Some examples in Fritsche ad Eth. Eud. A 3, 1215 a 8.

kakou=rgon] As a special variety of the general conception of dishonesty, fraud, knavery, this adjective is applied in a peculiar sense to sophistical reasoning. Rhet. III 2, 7 tw=n d' o)noma/twn tw=| me\n sofisth| o(mwnumi/ai xrh/simoi, para\ tau/tas ga\r kakourgei=. Topic. I 11, 172 b 21. Plat. Gorg. 483 A. Dem. Lept. 491. Stallb. ad Rep. I 338 D. Similarly sukofantei=n is used for cheating in argument, bringing fallacious objections, Top. *q 2, 157 a 32. I (de Soph. El.) 15, 174 b 9. Both of them represent the knavish tricks and fallacies which may be employed in rhetorical and dialectical reasoning. Plat. Rep. 341 B pro\s tau=ta kakou/rgei kai\ sukofa/ntei.

A debate in a political assembly, which turns upon questions of public and national concern (koino/teron), in which accordingly the audience, who
are all members of it, have a strong personal interest, and are therefore impatient of anything that would divert them from the direct proof of the expediency or inexpediency of the policy recommended or condemned, affords much less room for these deceptive arts ad captandum, ta\ e)/cw tou= pra/gmatos, than the practice of the law-courts, where the judges who decide the case are usually not personally interested in the issue, and the pleader has therefore to create an interest in them by these irregular methods: this is on the principle so pithily stated by the Corinthian envoys, Thuc. I 120, 3 kakou\s krita\s w(s mh\ proshko/ntwn ei)=nai. (This is a more correct mode of stating the argument than that adopted in the paraphrase, Introd. p. 141.)

This contrast of the two kinds of audiences, in respect of their several dispositions to keep the speakers to the point, does not hold of our own law-courts and parliaments. The Athenian dicasts, careless, ignorant, and unprofessional, selected at random from the population of the city, with their sense of responsibility diminished or destroyed by the large number of those who had to decide, might very likely be indifferent to the issue of the case before them, and require a stimulus to their attention from the parties immediately concerned: but this is not true of the professional judges of our courts, who regard the right decision of the case as a business and a duty.
o( krith/s] applied to the e)kklhsiasth/s in the general sense of ‘judge’ or ‘critic’ of the question or arguments employed; supr. § 7. Introd. p. 137, note 1.

a)nalabei=n] is to ‘bring back’, ‘recover’; hence to ‘gain over’, ‘conciliate’, as a)na/ in a)napei/qein, a)nadida/skein, a)nadido/nai, a)nade/xesqai k.t.l. ‘Membranae Balliolenses, captare: Muretus, accurare, excipere: Portus, reficere, recreare, h( metafora/ ab aegrotis; vel conciliare. Omnes hae notiones a primaria resumendi, ad se recipiendi, facile deducuntur.’ Gaisford. The order is, (1) to ‘get or bring back’; thence, (2) to ‘bring back into the proper and normal state’, as of ‘recovery’ from a disease—the notion of something as due being again implied as in a)podido/nai, note on § 7— and thence again, (3) as here, to ‘restore’, as it were, the audience to their proper state of mind, conciliate them to your views and interests. Hence, lastly, the senses of reparare, reficere, recreare, and the like; abundantly illustrated in Steph. Thes. ed. Did. Vol. II pp. 431—2.

dido/asin] (e(autou/s) sese dant, ‘lend themselves’, o( d' h(donh=| dou/s, Eur. Phoen. 21. Valck. Diatr. p. 233. And so, many of its compounds,
e)ndido/nai, e)kdido/nai, e)pidido/nai, a)podido/nai, diadido/nai, u(podido/nai, paradido/nai, (h(donh=| paradou/s, Pl. Phaedr. 250 D), prodido/nai (Herod. bis), e)kdido/nai (Herod.). The process is the usual one by which transitive verbs become intransitive, viz. by the ellipse of the reflexive pronoun.

h( de\ pi/stis a)po/deici/s tis] a)po/deicis, in its strict, proper, and highest senses, is exact scientific demonstrative proof, by syllogism, leading from and to universal and necessary conclusions. And therefore, properly speaking, paraplh/sion fai/netai maqhmatikou= te piqanologou=ntos a)pode/xesqai kai\ r(htoriko
 a)podei/ceis a)paitei=n, Eth. Nic. I 1. a)po/deicis sullogismo\s e)pisthmoniko/s, Anal. Post. I 2, 71 b 18. e)c a)nagkai/wn a)/ra sullogismo/s e)stin h( a)po/deicis, c. 4, 73 a 24. a)po/deicis sullogismo\s deiktiko\s ai)ti/as kai\ tou= dia/ ti, Ib. c 24, 85 b 23. a)po/deicis e)sti/n, o(/tan e)c a)lhqw=n kai\ prw/twn o( sullogismo\s h)=|, h)\ e)k toiou/twn a(\ dia/ tinwn prw/twn kai\ a)lhqw=n th=s peri\ au)ta\ gnw/sews th
 a)rxh
 ei)/lhfen, Topic. A 1, 100 a 27. Waitz, Comm. ad Anal. Post. Vol. II p. 293 seq. pi/stis therefore, whose premisses and conclusions are never more than ‘probable’, cannot properly be said to be ‘a kind of demonstration’. It resembles it however, and may be regarded as a ‘sort of demonstration’ in this; that probable proof often produces a belief or conviction as strong and certain as that which follows from demonstration. It is therefore to be understood here, as often elsewhere, as a general term including proof of every kind. A similar misapplication of a)po/deicis to rhetorical proof is found in Rhet. II 1, 2, and II 20, 9. So sullogi/zesqai, of reasoning, inference, conclusion in general; Rhet. I 6 § 17, 10 § 1, 11 § 23 and II 22 § 4, where sullogismoi/ stands for ‘Enthymemes’; Poet. 4, 5, sumbai/nei qewrou=ntas manqa/nein kai\ sullogi/zesqai ti/ e(/kaston. Phys. II 1, 193 a 7, sullogi/saito ga a)/n tis e)k geneth=s w)
 tuflo\s peri\ xrwma/twn. Similarly, a)podeiktiko/s of a rhetorical argument or speech, Rhet. II 1, 2, pro\s to
 lo/gon o(ra=|n, o(/pws a)podeiktiko/s (conclusive) h)= kai\ pisto/s. A still more remarkable example of this looseness of expression occurs I 4, 5, where Dialectics is called h( a)nalutikh\ e)pisth/mh˙ The rhetorical enthymeme, again ‘a kind of a)po/deicis’, is subsequently and this time correctly, called kuriw/tato:n tw=n pi/stewn. See Introd. p. 92.
to\ d' e)nqu/mhma sullogismo/s˙ tis]. On the enthvmeme, Introd. p. 101— 105. On peri\ de\ sullogismou= i)dei=n, and on me/rous tino/s, Introd. p. 143, note.

dh=lon de/] de/, omitted by one MS, and rejected by Buhle, Schrader, Bekker, and Spengel, is retained and defended by Victorius and Vater. It is justified not only by the common usage of the Greek language (see Buttm. Exc. XII on Dem. c. Mid. de particula de/ in apodosi, p. 150; the passages which he thus quotes might be multiplied indefinitely), but also by the special usage of Aristotle himself. Waitz, on Organ. 17 b 1, Vol. I p. 335, comp. Zell ad Eth. Nic. I 1 § 4, Vol. II p. 5, who quotes examples from Aristotle, to which add Rhet. I 4 § 2, I 10 § 4, I 11 §§ 6 and 11, II 25 § 10, an exact parallel, the protasis here also commencing with e)pei/. Similarly Pol. VII (IV) 13 init. e)pei\ de\ du) e)stin (a long parenthesis of several clauses intervenes, and the apodosis begins with) dei= d' e)n tai=s te/xnais k.t.l. de Anima I 3, 406 a 4 and 10. Phys. VI 8, 2, ei) to\ me/n... i(/stasqai de/. See also Stallb. on Phædo 78 C. The particle is thus used in the apodosis generally, not always, as a repetition of a preceding de/, and in these cases may be translated by “I say”. It repeats in order to recal the attention to the connexion of the apodosis with the foregoing protasis, which might be overlooked after a long parenthesis: in cases where this would not be necessary, it may be accounted for by the influence of habit or association. Of the many illustrative passages I had collected from other writers as well as Aristotle, I will content myself with citing two or three apposite ones from Thucydides. I 11, sub init., e)peidh\ de\ a)fiko/menoi ma/xh| e)kra/thsan, (parenthesis) fai/nontai de/ k.t.l. I 18 init., e)peidh\ de/ (ten lines) meta\ de\ th\n tw=n tura/nnwn kata/lusin k.t.l. II 65, e)pei/ te o( po/lemos kate/sth, o( de\ fai/netai kai\ e)n tou/tw| prognou\s th\n du/namin. IV 132, o( de\ *perdi/kkas k.t.l. and VIII 29 (three of these are referred to by Arnold, note 2 on I 11). Paley on Aesch. P. V. 952, 994, 2nd ed. gives some instances from Aeschylus. I may also add Plat. Phaedo 78 C, ta\ de\ a)/llot' a)/llws kai\ mh/depote kata\ tau)ta/, tau=ta de\ ei)=nai ta\ cu/nqeta. A good example may be found in Phaedo 87 A, B, dou\s de/—ei) de\ tou=to...

tou\s logikou\s sullogismou/s] Waitz on Anal. Post. I 21, 82 b 35, p. 353, ‘opponitur tw=| logikw=s to\ a)nalutikw=s 84 a 8, 86 a 22, 88 a 19, accurata demonstratio, quae veris ipsius rei principiis nititur, ei quae probabili quadam ratione contenta est....Unde fit ut logiko/n idem fere sit quod dialektiko/n.’ And this is its usual signification...‘Quamquam’ (he adds, referring to the present passage) ‘1355 a 13, quum logiko\s sullogismo/s et hic et in iis quæ proxime sequuntur opponatur rhetorico syllogismo (e)nqumh/mati), veram demonstrationem significare videatur.’ To the same effect is what follows, where to\ a)lhqe/s exact truth and knowledge, scientific certainty, is represented as the object of the logikoi\ sullogismoi/, and to\ o<*>/moion tw=| a)lhqei= (probability, ta\ e)/ndoca, which has only a resemblance to truth),
as the object of the enthymeme. And as both are apprehended by the same faculty, this faculty will be cultivated by the study and exercise of both alike, and the processes that lead to them, syllogism and enthymeme: and therefore the knowledge of the materials and modes of constructing syllogisms, and the practical application of them, equally in all their varieties, demonstrative, dialectical, and rhetorical (enthymeme), are serviceable to the rhetorician as a training and preparation for the practice of his art.

pro\s ta\ e)/ndoca] ‘things probable, matters of opinion, not certainty’; the materials, objects, and results of Rhetoric, as of Dialectics. Top. A 10, 104 a 8, e)/sti de\ pro/tasis dialektikh\ e)rw/thsis e)/ndocos, k.t.l. Ib. c. 1, 100 b 21, e)/ndoca de\ ta\ dokou=nta pa=sin h)\ toi=s plei/stois h)\ toi=s sofoi=s, kai\ tou/tois h)\ pa=sin h)\ toi=s plei/stois h)\ toi=s ma/lista gnwri/mois kai\ e)ndo/cois. Cic. de Orat. I 23, 108, sunt enim varia et ad vulgarem popularemque sensum accommodata omnia genera huius forensis nostrae dictionis.

dio/ti] ‘that’,=o(/ti. The earliest instance of this use of dio/ti appears to be in Herod. II 50. It occurs in Xenophon (add Symp. I 11, to the examples in Sturz's Lexicon), Plato, Ep. I 309 D, Dem. de Cor. §§ 155, 167, 184, but each time in a document. Isocr. Paneg. § 48, Phil. § 1, Archid. § 24, Plat. § 23, Antid. §§ 133, 263. p. tou= zeu/gous § 43, pro\s *kalli/maxon §§ 1, 31. (Some of these referring to Isocrates are derived from Benseler's note, Praef. p. v note 4, who has the following remark, from Baiter on Paneg. § 48, ‘Isocrates ubicunque dio/ti usurpavit, id fecisse videtur hiatus evitandi causa’ [see esp. Isocr. Lochit. § 7, where e)nqumoume/nous o(/ti is followed by kai\ dio/ti...S.]. It is found several times in the Rhet. ad Alex. as c. 17 p. 1432 a 16, c. 30 p. 1437 a 19, and elsewhere, but it is in Aristotle that it first becomes common; too common to need further illustration. See however Waitz on Anal. Pr. 58 b 7, Comm. I p. 495. For dio/ti = o(/ti, Steph. Thes. Vol. II 1544 cites Crito Com. ap. Athen. 4, p. 173 C, pa/ntwn a)kou/wn dio/ti parasi/tw| to/pos ou(=tos tri/a mo/non a)gaqa\ kekth=sqai dokei=. Its ordinary sense is ‘because’.

It has also a third signification, ‘why.’; the indirect interrogative, corresponding to the direct, dia\ ti/, as o(/pws to pw=s, o(/pote to po/te, o(/sos to po/sos, o(/pou to pou=, &c. In this sense it occurs in Plato, Phaedo 100 C, (four other examples in Ast's Lex.), Xen. Cyrop. VIII 4, 7, h)= kai\ e)/xois a)

With dio/ti ‘that’, compare ou(/neka and o(qou/neka in Sophocles, as Philoct. 634, the reason, the what for, passes into a mere statement of fact; because, into that. See Ellendt, Lex. Soph. o(qou/neka.

a)poneu/ein, to bend the head away from something else and turn the attention to a particular object; hence, to incline to, fix the attention upon: a)po/ as in a)poble/pein, (supr. § 1). Plat. Theaet. 165 A, e)k tw=n yilw=n lo/gwn pro\s th\n gewmetri/an a)peneu/samen. In Plat. Legg. VII 815 A, e)/kneusis plhgw=n kai\ bolw=n, is declinatio, the bending of the head aside to avoid a blow. (In Eur. Iph. T. 1186 v. 1155 Herm. su\ d' e)s to\ th=s qeou= g) e)ce/neusas ei)ko/tws, e)ce/neusas is of doubtful interpretation. Hermann, followed by Paley, derives it from e)knei=n evadere, referring to Valckenaer on Hippol. 469, and 822. It seems however at least equally probable that the aorist belongs to e)kneu/ein abnuere, opposed to e)pineu/ein annuere, and that the meaning of the line is “It was natural, or reasonable, for thee to decline, reject, their offer, ei)s to\ th=s qeou= g), looking to, in respect of, in regard of, thy duty to the goddess”. This sense of the word seems to be more in conformity with what precedes; and it occurs again in line 1330 Dind., with the same sense and derivation, e)ce/neus' a)posth=nai, beckoned us off, “gave us a sign to stand aloof”.)
xrh/simos—e)nteu/cews] This passage is cited by Dionysius, Epist. ad Amm. I c. 6. He reads dia/ te for dia/ te, and didaskali/a for didaskali/as (six lines below).

On the defence of Rhetoric, compare Quint. Inst. Orat. II 17, 26, seq. (in II 16 he sums up the arguments against the use of it), Isocr. a)nti/d. § 251 seq. and Id. Nicocles, §§ 1—9, also Gorgias, in Plato's dialogue, c. XI 456 A—457 C. On the true office and functions of the orator, Cic. de Orat. I 46, 202—a striking passage. Id. de Invent. I 3 and 4.
dia/ te] te is answered by the (irregular) correlative de/ in e)/ti de/ at the beginning of the next sentence. de Anima II 4, 7, 416 a 2—6, ou)/te (parenth.)...pro\s de\ tou/tois.

a)na/gkh di) au)tw=n h(tta=sqai] The argument of this clause, xrh/simos de/— e)pitimh/sews, is summed up in two lines of Euripides, Alex. Fragm. 55 (12) Dind. a)glwssi/a| de\ polla/kis lhfqei\s a)nh\r | di/kaia le/cas h(=sson eu)glw/ssou fe/rei. It is to the effect, that truth and right having a natural superiority over falsehood and wrong, the proper use of Rhetoric is to enable them to assert and enforce that superiority; to bring truth to light, and detect and expose deceit and sophistry. If the opposites of truth and right do ever prevail over these, it must be the fault of the parties concerned themselves, a)na/gkh di) au)tw=n h(tta=sqai, who have failed to avail themselves
of this powerful instrument. Rhetoric is therefore ‘corrective’ or ‘remedial’ of the perversion of truth and right to which legal decisions are always more or less liable from misrepresentation of facts, fallacious arguments, or the blinding of the judgment by appeals to the feelings.

According to this translation of di) au)tw=n, it is correctly and logically said that it is a consequence (w(/ste) of the natural superiority of truth and right to their opposites, that if those who have truth and right on their side are defeated, their defeat must be due to themselves, to their own neglect of Rhetoric, which would have enabled them to enforce this their natural superiority. Whereas if we follow Victorius (and Spengel who assents to his view, Arist. Ars Rhet. Vol. II p. 26) in explaining di) au)tw=n by di) e)nanti/wn, w(/ste becomes incorrect or meaningless: for there is neither truth nor sense in saying that it follows from the natural superiority of truth and justice that these, in the case of a wrong judgment, are defeated by their opposites; and not only so, but with this interpretation a)na/gkh is also wrong—the consequence, if there be one, is certainly not necessary—and di) au)tw=n should be u(p' au)tw=n.

In the Introd. p. 144 note, I have referred to Waitz's note on Anal. Pr. 55 a 14, who gives examples of au)tw=n &c. for the reflexive au(tw=n &c. The usage is however so constant in Aristotle as hardly to need illustration. A good example is de Anima II 5, 6, 417 b 24, dio\ noh=sai me\n e)p' au)tw=|, o(po/tan bou/lhtai, ai)sqa/nesqai d) ou)k e)p) au)tw=|. Rhet. I 4, 9, e)p' au)toi=s, ‘in their own power’.
pro\s e)ni/ous] ‘in dealing with some’.

didaskali/as] de Soph. El. c. 2, 161 b 1, quoted in Introd. p. 75. Genuine and complete ‘instruction’ by demonstrative proofs. Top. A c. 14, 105 b 30, pro\s me\n ou)=n filosofi/an kat' a)lh/qeian (i.e. di) a)podei/cews) peri\ au)tw=n pragmateute/on, dialektikw=s (and therefore also r(htorikw=s) pro\s do/can.

B 8, 114 a 8, *g 4, 119 b 22, *q 3, 158 b 37; I (de Soph. El.) c. 4, 166 a 4, Eth. N. IV 12, 1126 b 27, Polit. II 6, 1266 a 16, Rhet. I 12, 10.

pa/lin ou)=n—le/gwmen ta\ loipa/] ‘Let us then take as it were a fresh start, and so first define it, and then proceed to the rest’.
On this definition of Rhetoric, see Introd. pp. 33—4; and note on paraphrase, p. 149: on the other current definitions of it, Ib. pp. 27—36. On Rhetoric as a du/namis, Ib. p. 14 seq.
