ta\ sumbebhko/ta pa/qh toi=s mege/qesi] These are usually called sumbebhko/ta kaq' au(ta/ in Aristotle's terminology, i.e. absolute, necessary consequences (rather than accidents) of the essence or definition of a thing. The ordinary sumbebhko/ta are separable accidents, qualities or properties, which do not form part of this essence of the subject, or consequently of its definition; with or without which the essence of the subject, (that which constitutes its being, or makes it to be what it is,) remains the same. The sumbebhko/ta kaq' au(ta/ are distinguished from the ordinary sumbebhko/ta in this; that although they are not of the essence, and therefore do not enter into the definition, still they are immediately deducible from it, and inseparable from the subject, and are therefore the proper objects of study. They are in fact identifiable with the i)/dia or propria of the five predicables. The sumbebhko/ta pa/qh toi=s mege/qesi in the text are accordingly ‘the inseparable properties of magnitudes’; as ‘the equality of the interior angles of a triangle to two right angles’ is a necessary property of the triangle, though not included in the definition, which is ‘a plane figure bounded by three straight lines’: still the property is deducible from the definition, and thus is inseparable from the notion of it: the triangle cannot exist without this property, though it is not of its essence, and therefore not part of the definition. This example is given in de Anima I 1 § 8, 402 b 19. See the whole section. And again de part. Anim. I 3, 10 sumbebhko\s ga/r ti (kaq' au(to\) tw=| trigw/nw| to\ dusi
 o)rqai=s i)/sas e)/xein ta\s gwni/as. See further in Trend. ad de Anima I 1, 1, Comm. p. 188 seq. Bonitz ad Metaph. *d 30, 1025 a 30. Anal. Post. I 7, 75 a 42, e)n tai=s a)podei/cesin...tri/ton to\ ge/nos to\ u(pokei/menon, ou(= ta\ pa/qh kai\ ta\ kaq' au)ta\ sumbebhko/ta dhloi= h( a)po/deicis...ou)k e)/sti th
 a)riqmhtikh
 a)po/deicin e)farmo/sai e)pi\ ta\ toi=s mege/qesi sumbebhko/ta.
On pa/qh see Introd. p. 114.
On e)/ntexnoi and a)/texnoi pi/steis, see Introd. p. 150 (paraphrase), and on the general subject, analysis of I c. 15, pp. 193—207.

toi=s me\n xrh/sasqai ta\ de\ eu(rei=n] The former lie ready at hand, and require only to be employed; the latter, proofs of all kinds, direct and indirect, pi/steis, h)=qos, pa/qos, must be ‘discovered’ or ‘invented’ for this occasion by the speaker himself. Hence the distinction of inventio from the other parts of Rhetoric by the Latin Rhetoricians. So Cicero, de Inventione (this title is adopted to represent the whole domain of Rhetoric, because ‘invention’ or proof of one kind or another is the sw=ma th=s pi/stews, I 1 § 3, by far the most prominent and important part of the entire art) VII 9, quare materia quidem nobis rhetoricae videtur ea, quam Aristoteli visam esse diximus; partes autem hae quas plerique dixerunt, inventio, dispositio, elocutio, memoria, pronunciatio (invention, order and arrangement of parts, style, memory, and delivery including action). Inventio est excogitatio rerum verarum aut veri similium quae causam probabilem reddant &c. Similarly Quintilian, Inst. Or. I 12, 4, Quid? nos agendi subita necessitate deprehensi nonne alia dicimus alia providemus, quum pariter inventio rerum, electio verborum (style in single words), compositio (combination of words in sentences), gestus, pronunciatio, vultus, motusque desiderentur? XII 1, 30, bonos nunquam honestus sermo (style) deficiet, nunquam rerum optimarum inventio.

pi/stewn tri/a ei)/dh] Compare Rhet. III I, 1. This threefold division of rhetorical proofs, due to Aristotle, is recognized by Dionysius, de Lys. jud. c. 19, a)/rcomai de\ a)po\ tw=n kaloume/nwn e)nte/xnwn pi/stewn, kai\ xwri\s u(pe\r e(ka/stou me/rous diale/comai. trixh=| de\ nenemhme/nwn tou/twn, ei)/s te to\ pra=gma kai\ to\ pa/qos kai\ to\ h)=qos k.t.l.: and by Charmadas, in Cic. de Orat. I 19, 87, where only the h)=qos and pa/qos are directly mentioned, but the other, which is absolutely indispensable, must of course be assumed as a third division: by Cicero himself, de Orat. II 27, 115, ita omnis ratio dicendi tribus ad persuadendum rebus est nixa; ut probemus vera esse quae defendimus; ut conciliemus nobis eos qui audiunt; ut animos eorum ad quemcunque causa postulabit motum vocemus. This is repeated in §§ 121 and 128 and the h)=qos and pa/qos described at length in c. 43 and the following. These two latter are again referred to Orat. XXXVII 128; and again in Partitiones Oratoriae XIII 46 the three pi/steis are thus ingeniously distinguished in a twofold division. Argumentandi duo
sunt genera, quorum alterum ad fidem directe spectat, alterum se inflectit ad motum. (These are the ‘direct’ and ‘indirect’ proofs and arguments.) Dirigitur cum proposuit aliquid quod probaret, sumpsitque ea quibus niteretur; atque his confirmatis ad propositum se retulit atque conclusit. Illa autem altera argumentatio, quasi retro et contra, prius sumit quae vult eaque confirmat, deinde id quod proponendum fuit permotis animis iacit ad extremum.

Quintilian touches on this subject in many places of his work; the most detailed account of h)=qos and pa/qos is given in the second chapter of his sixth book: the description and distinction of them occur in §§ 18, 19. They are both referred, as subordinate species, to the general head of ‘affectus’, § 8, comp. § 12; and these are again distinguished from the direct and logical arguments, § 3. In this and the following section he compares these two classes of arguments together in respect of their rhetorical value and importance, and comes to a conclusion precisely opposite to that of Aristotle. For Aristotle holds that these indirect proofs, though necessary to the orator by reason of the deficiencies and infirmities of his audience, dia\ th\n tou= a)kroatou= moxqhri/an, III 1 § 5, and therefore not to be excluded from the theory or practice of Rhetoric, yet are to be regarded as merely auxiliary and subordinate, standing in the same relation to the direct proofs as dress and personal ornaments to the body, serviceable but not essential. Quintilian on the contrary pronounces that these in comparison with the overpowering force of the appeals to the feelings are only not contemptible in respect of their power of persuasion; quos equidem non contemno, sed hactenus utiles credo ne quid per eos iudici sit ignotum; atque ut dicam quod sentio, dignos a quibus causas diserti docerentur § 3: that those that use them therefore are only fit to lay before the judges the facts of the case, not to influence their decision, and to instruct the real advocate, who can sway their minds and feelings at his will, and force them to decide in favour of his client: ubi vero animis iudicum vis afferenda est, et ab ipsa veri contemplatione abducenda mens, ibi proprium oratoris opus est § 5.

It may be observed in concluding this note, that there is a somewhat important difference, which I have already pointed out in the Introduction, between Aristotle's view of the use to be made of h)=qos in the practice of Rhetoric, and that of the Latin Rhetoricians, as well as the author of the Rhet. ad Alex.; see c. 39 (38) 2. Quintilian's auctoritas—and compare Cicero in de Oratore, II 43—expresses the influence of character upon opinion, in general: but in Aristotle's system the h)=qos means something more; the effect must be produced immediately by the speech dei= de\ kai\ touto sumbai/nein dia\ to\n lo/gon, a)lla\ mh\ dia\ to\ prodedo/casqai poi=o/n tina ei)=nai to\n le/gonta, Rhet. I 2, 4; and hence it finds a place in Rhetoric as in Art: whereas in the other view the auctoritas exercised may have been previously acquired, and altogether e)/cw tou= pra/gmatos, acting independ
ently of any artistic or systematic process, in the way of reasoning or proving.
On h)=qos, as auctoritas, see Introd. p. 151 note.

toi=s e)pieike/si] ‘worthy and respectable people’. Eth. Nic. v. 14 sub init. kai\ o(/te me\n to\ e)pieike\s e)painou=men kai\ a)/ndra to\n toiou=ton, w(/ste kai\ e)pi\ ta\ a)/lla e)painou=ntes metafe/romen a)nti\ tou= a)gaqou=, to\ e)pieike/steron o(/ti be/ltion dhlou=ntes. The primary sense of e)pieikh/s is therefore ‘equitable’, one who has a leaning to the merciful side and of an indulgent disposition, as opposed to one who takes a strict and rigorous view of an offence, puts a harsh construction on men's motives and actions, is inclined to enforce on all occasions the letter of the law. From this, and because we think this the better disposition of the two, e)pieikh/s is ‘transferred’ by metaphor (i.e. the metafora\ a)po\ tou= ei)/dous e)pi\ to\ ge/nos, the second of the four species of metaphors, Poet. XXI 7) to the general (or generic) signification of ‘good’.

a(plw=s] has various usages. It may for instance mean (I) ‘simply’, opposed to sunqe/sei or kata\ sumplokh/n: and this appears to be the primary sense of the word, in accordance with the derivation. Thus as the elements of nature are often called a(pla= sw/mata in their simple, uncombined state, so we have a(plw=s, de Anima II 14, 8, to denote ‘singly, or simply, by itself’ (kaq' e(auth/n Themistius), without the admixture of any other element; dokei= de/ tisin h( tou= puro\s fu/sis a(plw=s ai)ti/a th=s trofh=s kai\ th=s au)ch/sews ei)=nai. Similarly when applied in a moral sense to human character, it denotes ‘simplicity’ (of composition), ‘singleness’ of heart and purpose, as opposed to ‘duplicity’, (Plat. Rep. III 397 E, ou) diplou=s a)nh\r ou)de\ pollaplou=s. VIII 55, 4 D, Rhet. I 9, 29, Eur. Rhes. 395 filw= le/gein ta)lhqe\s a)ei\ kou) diplou=s pe/fuk' a)nh/r. Ruhnk. Tim. p. 86).

The commonest signification however is that of (2) simpliciter et sine exceptione ‘generally’ or ‘universally’, as opposed to kaq' e(/kaston, ‘specially’, ‘particularly’, ‘individually’, Eth. N. I 1, 1095 a 1, or to e)/stin w(s ‘partially’, or kata\ me/ros, de Anima II 5, 4, nu=n ga\r a(plw=s e)le/gomen peri\ au)tw=n, in general terms—we must now come to particulars. Hence it signifies ‘altogether’, ‘absolutely’, omnino, as ou)de\n a(plw=s ‘none at all’, de Part. An. IV 13, 9, a)du/naton o(/lws ‘absolutely impossible’. Plato will supply abundance of examples of this usage. See also Waitz, Comm. on Organ. Vol. I p. 354, who exemplifies it from Aristotle.

From this again may be distinguished a third sense (3), in which it is equivalent to kaq' au(to/n, and opposed to pro/s ti, ‘the relative’. In this sense it is defined, Top. B 11, 115 b 33, o(\ a)
 mhdeno\s prostiqeme/nou dokh=| ei)=nai kalo
 h)\ ai)sxro
 h)\ a)/llo ti tw=n toiou/twn, a(plw=s r(hqh/setai. de Soph. El. c. 5, 166 b 22 and b 37, where to\ a(plw=s and mh\ a(plw=s are opposed as the absolute and relative in a paralogism of the substitution of the one for the other. Anal. Post. I 4, 83 a 15, kathgorei=n me
 mh\ a(plw=s kata\ sumbebhko\s de\ kathgorei=n. Eth. N. I 3, 1095 b 3, Polit. IV (VII) 1, 1323 b 17, kai\ a(plw=s (absolutely, in itself) kai\ h(mi=n (relatively to us).

From these three may perhaps be distinguished a fourth sense (4) in which it occurs; for instance, in Met. A 6, 987 a 21, oi( *puqago/reioi... li/an a(plw=s e)pragmateuqhsan “treated the subject too simply”, i. e. too carelessly, without taking sufficient pains with it, with insufficient elaboration; ‘negligenter’, Bonitz ad loc. q. v. On the various modes in which a(plw=s is opposed to the relative and particular see Schrader on I 9, 17.

kuriwta/thn e)/xei pi/stin to\ h)=qos] ‘is the most authoritative, effective, instrument of persuasion’. On the influence of character on the judgment add to the passages already quoted, Rhet. ad Alex. c. 38 (39), 2, and Isocr. a)nti/dosis §§ 276—280.
The oratorical artifice here described is well illustrated by Marc Antony's speech in Fulius Caesar, Act III Sc. 2, “I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts,” &c.

ku/rios in this and similar cases seems to derive its meaning from the ‘authority’ or ‘influence’ exercised by any one or any thing that has the power of doing so, of which general notion it is a special application. It corresponds to our ‘sovereign’, as when we speak of a sovereign remedy. Trendelenburg, on de Anima II 5, 7, Comm. p. 368, would connect this signification with the ku/rios no/mos, ‘ratio e iudiciis et foro tracta videtur. ku/rios no/mos, qui a)ku/rw| oppositus est, lex est quae rata viget &c.—ita hic ku/ria o)no/mata, quatenus eorum auctoritas valet.’ This is perhaps unnecessarily narrowing the signification. Other persons and things, besides laws, exercise authority. A good instance of ku/rios in this general sense, implying superiority, authority, mastery, occurs in de Anima II 8, 3, 419 b 19, ou)k e)/sti de\ yo/fou ku/rios o( a)h\r ou)de\ to\ u(/dwr, where ku/rios may be interpreted ‘absolute master’, the air and water are not absolute masters of sound: some other conditions are required to produce it. Ib. 419 b 33, to\ de\ keno\n o)rqw=s le/getai ku/rion tou= a)kou/ein.
ou) ga\r o(moi/ws a)podi/domen k.t.l.] Comp. II 1, 4.

dia\ de\ tw=n lo/gwn] In § 3 we are told that there are three kinds of pi/steis or rhetorical proofs, which are conveyed through the channel or medium-(dia/ with the genitive) of the speech. These three are then described seriatim. The first, § 4, is dia\ tou= h)/qous; the second (§ 5), dia\ tw=n a)kroatw=n, o(/tan ei)s pa/qos u(po\ tou= lo/gou proaxqw=sin; and the third, § 6, dia\ tw=n lo/gwn, plainly in the sense of the direct pi/steis or arguments proper, o(/tan a)lhqe\s h)\ faino/menon dei/cwmen e)k tw=n peri\ e(/kasta piqanw=n. dia\ tw=n lo/gwn is the reading of all the MSS except A^{c}, which has to\n lo/gon: but this, as an unnecessary and unaccountable departure from the construction of the parallel expressions, dia\ tou= lo/gou, tou= h)/qous, tw=n a)kroatw=n, and afterwards dia\ tou/twn, seems to be self-condemned.

By these lo/goi we may understand either the actual words which are the instruments or medium of the reasonings, or better the reasonings or arguments themselves which the words convey. This explanation appears to be sufficiently rational and consistent, and in accordance with the ordinary usages of the language. Spengel, however, in his paper über die Rhet. des Arist. (Trans. Bav. Acad. 1851) p. 26, and again in his edition of the Rhetoric, Vol. II p. 46, thinks that the text requires alteration, and would read di) au)tou= de\ tou= lo/gou, or dia\ d' au)tou= tou= lo/gou, which seems to be totally unnecessary. The explanation above given is confirmed by the rendering of the Vetus Translatio ‘per orationes autem credimus’, where ‘orationes’ plainly stands for the ‘words of the speeches in which these arguments are expressed’.

a)lhqe\s h)\ faino/menon] The second of these terms denotes the fallacious branch of Rhetoric, ‘the apparent, unreal, sham’ arguments, exemplified in II 24, and corresponding to the spurious branch of Dialectics treated in the *sofistikoi\ e)/legxoi, and appended to the Topics. The illustration of these is allowed to enter into a scientific treatise only for the purpose of detecting and exposing these fallacies, and enabling the pleader or dialectician to confute them when employed by an adversary. e)/sti ga\r h( sofistikh\ fainome/nh sofi/a ou)=sa d' ou)/, de Soph. El. I, 165 a 21.

e)pei\ de\ ai( pi/steis—kai\ pw=s] “seeing then that these are the channels, or modes of communication of rhetorical proofs, it is plain that to grasp, or get possession, or make himself master of them (labei=n) is a task for one who has a capacity for logical reasoning, and for the contemplation or study of characters, and thirdly [for the discernment] of the emotions;—and of the latter, what each is in itself, and what are its qualities and properties (poi=o/n ti), and from what sources (what motives and impulses, e)k ti/nwn,) it may be excited, and in what modes (pw=s).”— tau=ta...e)sti\ labei=n tou= sullogi/sasqai duname/nou, lit. ‘it belongs to the student of logic to get hold of them’.

Of these the logical branch belongs to Dialectics, which teaches the habit of reasoning and discussion, the other two to the study of Ethics,
which deals with human beings as individuals, and investigates the fixed habits, virtuous or vicious (e(/ceis), which constitute their characters (h)/qh), and the moral pa/qh or ‘emotions’, which when developed by exercise, according to the direction which they take, become virtues and vices. The consequence is, w(/ste sumbai/nei, that Rhetoric may be considered a scion or offshoot of the study of Dialectics and Ethics, the latter ‘which may fairly be called Politics’ (because it treats of men in society and therefore includes the science of the individual, h( me\n ou)=n me/qodos (Ethics) tou/twn e)fi/etai, politikh/ tis ou)=sa. Eth. Nic. I 1, 1074 b 11), standing to them in the relation of the offshoot to the parent plant. Sed idem (Aristoteles) et de arte rhetorica tres libros scripsit, et in eorum primo non artem solum eam fatetur, sed ei particulam civilitatis sicut dialectices assignat. Quint. Inst. Orat. II 17, 4.

sullogi/sasqai] improperly applied here, as a)po/deicis above, I § 11 p. 19, to rhetorical reasoning. But as there the rhetorical pi/steis are called a kind of demonstration, ‘a sort of’, or subordinate variety of, demonstration in a general sense, so here the syllogistic process is allowed to stand for reasoning in general, to which even rhetorical reasoning, though not syllogistic in the strict sense, but enthymematic, of course belongs.

parafue/s] which usually appears under the form parafua/s in Aristotle and Theophrastus, properly denotes either a branch or a separate plant ‘growing alongside’ of the parent plant, and proceeding either from the stem or the root, as a scion or offshoot. In the latter of these two senses it certainly occurs in Theophr. Hist. Plant. II 2, 4, e)a
 a)po\ r(i/zhs h( parafua\s h)=, though here also the hypothetical e)a/n admits the other possibility. Also parafu/esqai, Hist. Plant. III 17, 3, a)pokope
 de\ kai\ e)pikauqe

Plant. I 6, 6, VII 2, 5 and 8, &c.), parablasta/nein, -blasth/, -bla/sthma, are applied by Aristotle and his pupil Theophrastus primarily to plants, and by analogy to the corresponding parts of animals.

It occurs again as a metaphor in Eth. Nic. I 4, 1096 a 21, parafua/di ga\r tou=t' e)/oike kai\ sumbebhko/ti tou= o)/ntos; that is, to\ kaq' au(to/ and h( ou)si/a stand to ‘the relative’, to\ pro/s ti, in the same relation as parent plant to offshoot. ‘Similitudo, explicante Giphanio, a pullis arborum desumta, qui Graecis dicuntur parafua/des’. Zell, ad loc. So that Rhetoric is represented by this metaphor as a scion derived from two stocks or plants, Dialectics and Ethics, not identical with either, but with a general or inherited family resemblance to both. (The analogy will not bear
pressing: one does not see, for example, how a young plant can be the scion or offspring of two others, but this general meaning is clear, that it bears a likeness to both, though differing from each of them.)

a)lazonei/a implies both presumption and imposture; either a character between both and a mixture of both (as Theophrastus' a)lazw/n, ‘the braggart’, of which Pyrgopolinices in the Miles Gloriosus, Thraso in the Eunuchus, and Captain Bobadil in Every Man in his Humour, are the three types, ancient and modern; and probably also the Sophistical Rhetoricians here referred to): or again a character in which either presumption or imposture is characteristic and predominant. For example, the insolent assumption, arrogance, and swagger appear more prominently in this picture of the a)lazw/n drawn by Xenophon, Cyrop. II 2, 12, o( me\n ga\r a)lazw\n e)/moige dokei= o)/noma kei=sqai e)pi\ toi=s prospoioume/nois kai\ plousiwte/rois ei)=nai h)/ ei)si, kai\ a)ndreiote/rois, kai\ poih/sein a(\ mh\ i(kanoi/ ei)sin u(pisxnoume/nois: kai\ tau=ta faneroi=s gignome/nois o(/ti tou= labei=n ti e(/neka kai\ kerda=nai: poiou=sin. This last mercenary element is not found elsewhere in the character of the a)lazw/n. In Aristotle, Eth. Nic. II 7, IV 13, empty pretension, ostentation and swagger are the leading characteristics of the a)lazw/n. The vice is one of the extremes of which a)lh/qeia, the social virtue of frankness, sincerity, and plain dealing is the mean, the opposite extreme being ei)rwnei/a, ‘mock’ in conversation, Socrates' habit. It is the extreme in prospoi/hsis, ‘pretension’, of which a)lh/qeia is the mean state. Whereas in Aristophanes it usually represents rather the other side of the character, its quackery and imposture; and a)lazw/n is ‘a quack or a humbug’. Of course Socrates and his brother Sophists are the great representatives of the class. Nubes 102, 1494, et passim. And this is also the side of the character which is generally uppermost in Plato's view of it. See Rep. VI 486 B, 490 A, VIII 560 C, Phaedo 92 D, h(donh\...a(pa/ntwn a)lazone/staton, Phil. 65 C. The definition of it given in the Platonic o(/roi, p. 416, is that of undue pretension, assumption, imposture. e(/cis prospoihtikh\ a)gaqou= h)\ a)gaqw=n tw=n mh\ u(parxo/ntwn. Quackery and imposture are also predominant in the application of it, Rhet. II 6, 11.

di) a)/llas ai)ti/as a)nqrwpika/s] ‘incident to humanity’, implying the infirmities, imperfections, frailties, miseries, and especially errors to which
the human condition is exposed, and from which the divine nature, which is tactily opposed to it in this conception, is exempt. ‘The other human causes’ here referred to are any other defects or imperfections to which the human nature is liable. Thuc. III 40 a)nqrwpi/nws a(marta/nein, compared with III 45, pefu/kasi/ te a(/pantes i)di/a| kai\ dhmosi/a| a(marta/nein: ‘humanum est errare’. Plato, Soph. 229 A kata\ th
 a)nqrwpi/nhn do/can, ‘ex humana opinione, quae obnoxia est erroribus. Uti apud Latinos homo fuit frequens erroris vel imbecillitatis humanae excusatio’ (Heindorf ad loc. Polit. 279 C, a)lecifa/rmaka kai\ qei=a kai\ a)nqrw/pina et cet.). Demosth. de Cor. p. 328, § 308, h)\ para\ th=s tu/xhs ti sumbe/bhken e)nanti/wma, h)\ a)/llo ti du/skolon ge/gone—polla\ de\ ta)nqrw/pina.—Id. c. Lept. p. 506, 15, pa/nta d' a)nqrw/pina h(gei=sqai. Bœot. de Nomine p. 998, polla\ ga/r e)sti ta)nqrw/pina. Ar. Rhet. I 13, 17, kai\ to\ toi=s a)nqrwpi/nois sugginw/skein e)pieike/s. Eth. Nic. In Rhet. I 5, 10, dia\ to\ pa/ntwn a)pe/xesqai tw=n a)nqrwpi/nwn, it has this more general sense of ‘all human affairs, business and enjoyments’: with which comp. Plat. Theaet. 170 B kai\ pa/nta pou mesta\ ta)nqrw/pina (all human society or affairs in general) zhtou/ntwn didaska/lous k.t.l. So Virgil, Æn. I 462, sunt lacrimae rerum; et mentem mortalia tangunt: and in the second sense, Ecl. VIII 35, nec curare deum credis mortalia quemquam.

The eighth and ninth and part of the tenth sections of this chapter are quoted by Dionysius, Ep. ad Amm. I c. 7, from tw=n de\ dia\ to e)n tou/tois o(moi/ws e)/xei. The variations are, dei/knusqai (bis) for deiknu/nai, e)n toi=s a)nalutikoi=s for e)n toi=s dialektikoi=s, the omission of h)\ o(ntinou=n, and of au)tw=n e(kate/rw|; for e(/tero/n ti dia\ tau=ta sumbai/nein para\ tau=ta tw=| tau=ta ei)=nai, we have e(/tero/n te dia\ t. s. para\ to\ tau=t' ei)=nai, also fanero\n de\ kai\ o(/ti for o(/ti kai\, further to\ omitted before ei)=dos, and ga/r after kaqa/per, and lastly r(htorei/as for r(htorikh=s.
tw=n de\] pi/stewn.

e)n toi=s dialektikoi=s] Dionysius has a)nalutikoi=s, which Spengel has introduced into the text, with the remark, certe Aristoteles th=| dialektikh=| scripsisset (Rhetores Graeci p. 5, Praef. p. 5); and again, über die Rhet. des Arist. Trans. Bav. Acad. 1851, p. 44, Aristoteles sagt nur e)n th=| dialektikh=|, nicht e)n toi=s dialektikoi=s; in reply to which I will merely quote Rhet. II 22, 14, where e)n toi=s dialektikoi=s again occurs. Even without this evidence
I can see no reason why an author who speaks habitually of others of his works in the plural, as ta\ a)nalutika/, h)qika/, politika/, meqodika/, should be denied that privilege in the special case of the Topics. Nor do I see why the single testimony of Dionysius should override the authority of all the Aristotelian MSS. I have therefore retained the old reading.

pa/ntes de\ ta\s pi/steis poiou=ntai—kai\ para\ tau=ta ou)de/n pws] Anal. Pr. II 23, 68 b 9, o(/ti d' ou) mo/non oi( dialektikoi\ kai\ a)podeiktikoi\ sullogismoi\ dia\ tw=n proeirhme/nwn gi/nontai sxhma/twn, a)lla\ kai\ oi( r(htorikoi\ kai\ a(plou=s h(tisou=n pi/stis kai\ kaq) o(poianou=n me/qodon, nu=n a)\n ei)/h lekte/on. a(/panta ga\r pisteu/omen h)\ dia\ sullogismou= h)\ e)c e)pagwgh=s. Anal. Post. I 18, 81 a 40, ei)/per manqa/nomen h)\ e)pagwgh=| h)\ a)podei/cei. Eth. Nic. VI 1139 b 27, e)k proginwskome/nwn de\ pa=sa didaskali/a, w(/sper kai\ e)n toi=s a)nalutikoi=s le/gomen: h( me\n ga\r di) e)pagwgh=s, h( de\ sullogismw=|. The reference here is most unmistakeably to the opening words of the Anal. Post., an additional evidence, against Brandis (see the succeeding note), that the reference in e)k tw=n a)nalutikw=n is either directly and exclusively to this passage of the Analytics or at any rate includes it with the others.

h)\ o(ntinou=n] is rejected by Spengel on the authority of Dionysius, who omits it, and against that of the Aristotelian MSS, which, as appears from Bekker's revision, all agree in retaining it. It is not merely perfectly intelligible, and absolutely unexceptionable on all critical grounds, but when compared with the commencement of the Anal. Post., to which reference is immediately after made, it seems to tally so precisely with what is there stated, that it might almost be regarded as a necessary addition. In the passage of the Analytics we are told that every kind of instruction and learning, proof scientific and popular, mathematical or dialectical knowledge, is conveyed by way of syllogism or induction: and it is then added, w(s d' au(/tws kai\ oi( r(htorikoi\ sumpei/qousin: h)\ ga\r dia\ paradeigma/twn, o(/ e)stin e)pagwgh/, h)\ di) e)nqumhma/twn, o(/per e)sti\ sullogismo/s, a statement with which the h)\ o(ntinou=n of the Rhetoric seems to correspond to a nicety. And for the same reason I hold that this passage is referred to in e)k tw=n a)nalutikw=n, as well as Anal. Pr. II 23, 68 b 9, (quoted in the preceding note,) and the continuation of the subject there suggested in chapters 24 and 27, (which contain the logical description of induction and example, and the enthymeme), though Brandis, in his tract on the Rhetoric in Schneidewin's Philologus IV 1, p. 24, would confine the reference to the latter passage.

e)k tw=n topikw=n] On this reference to the Topics see note in Introd. p. 154, and note on II 25, 3, in this Commentary. The reference to the Topics there made is precisely similar to this: that is, it is made to the work in general and its contents, and not to any particular passage: what is stated here may be gathered or inferred from the Topics.

 to\ ei)=dos th=s r(htorikh=s] ‘It is plain that either kind of Rhetoric (the paradeigmatw=des or the e)nqumhmatiko
) has good in it’, that each of them has its own particular virtue and excellence, or advantage. Buhle construes the words to\ ei)=dos th=s r(htorikh=s e)/xei e(ka/teron a)gaqo/n, ‘Rhetoricen utroque bono frui, et enthymemate et exemplo’. (He takes to\ ei)=dos th=s r(. for a mere periphrasis. So in fact it does occur in Pol. I 4, 1253 b 28, e)n o)rga/nou ei)/dei “in the shape of an instrument”, de gen. et corr. I 3, 10, e)n u(/lhs ei)/dei—but ei)=dos in this usage does not seem to admit the definite article.) We have a similar use of a)gaqo
 e)/xein in Rhet. II 20, 7, ei)si\ d' oi( lo/goi dhmhgorikoi/, kai\ e)/xousin a)gaqo

e)n toi=s meqodikoi=s] ‘Scheint eine mittelstellung zwischen analytik und dialektik eingenommen zu haben’, Brandis, u.s. p. 13. The work is mentioned twice by Dionysius, Ep. ad Amm. I cc. 6 and 8, each time in company with Analytics and Topics. From this circumstance and from the reference here, it is natural to conclude that its subject was connected in some way with Logic. Diogenes Laert. V 1, 23, includes in his list of Aristotle's writings meqodika/ in eight books, and § 25, meqodiko/n in one: the former comes amongst the logical, the latter amongst the rhetorical works. It appears also in the list of the ‘Anonymous’ author of the life of Aristotle (in Buhle, Vol. I p. 62), again in near connexion with works on Logic, *)analutikw=n, *problhma/twn, *meqodika/. Hesychius Milesius in his life of Aristotle (Buhle, Vol. I p. 72), describes it thus; pro\s me\n ou)=n th\n eu(/resin, ta/ te topika\ kai\ meqodika/, pare/dwke
prota/sewn plh=qos, e)c w(=n pro\s ta\ problh/mata piqanw=n e)pixeirhma/twn oi(=o/nte eu)porei=n: classing it, like Dionysius and Diogenes, with the Topics and Analytics, the latter of which is mentioned immediately after. Simplicius ad Categ. fol. 7 a (quoted by Buhle) speaks of it as one of Aristotle's u(pomnh/mata, commentarii; e)n toi=s u(pomnh/masin, kai\ ga\r e)n toi=s meqodikoi=s, kai\ e)n toi=s u(pomnh/masi, kai\ e)n tai=s diaire/sesi, kai\ e)n a)/llw| u(pomnh/mati. Brandis, u.s., adds a reference to the Schol. in Arist. p. 47 b 40.

r(htorei=ai] ‘rhetorical exhibitions or displays’ Probl. XVIII 3. The word is a rare one, and as distinguished from r(htorikh/ denotes rather the practice and results of Rhetoric, speaking and speeches, than the system and theory of it as embodied in the ‘art’. It is found in Plato, Polit. 304 A, where Stallbaum notes, ‘vox r(htorei/a a Platone ficta videtur ut ars oratoria nobilior et generosior distingueretur a varia illa r(htorikh=| cuius nomen profanaverant qui ad explendas suas cupiditates abusi erant.’ The fact, that the word was a Platonic invention, and the ground assigned for the distinction, seem equally unauthenticated. It occurs also in Isocrates, kata\ tw=n *sofistw=n § 21, for ‘the practice of rhetoric’ in general, also Panath. § 2, Phil. § 26; and amongst the later writers, in Plutarch and Lucian: r(htoreu/ein, in Plato, Isocrates, and Rhet. ad Alex. 36 (37), 35.

piqanoi\ me
 ou)=n—oi( e)nqumhmatikoi/] Anal. Pr. II 23, ult. fu/sei me
 ou)=n pro/teros kai\ gnwrimw/teros o( dia\ tou= me/sou sullogismo/s, h(mi=n d' e)narge/steros o( dia\ th=s e)pagwgh=s. The objects of sense and observation from which we derive our inductions and examples are ‘nearer to us’, more readily apprehensible by us, than the universals of the syllogism: and therefore, Top. A 12, 105 a 16, e)/sti d' h( me
 e)pagwgh\ piqanw/teron kai\ safe/steron kai\ kata\ th
 ai)/sqhsin gnwrimw/teron kai\ toi=s polloi=s koino/n, o( de\ sullogismo\s biastikw/teron kai\ pro\s tou\s a)ntilogikou\s e)nerge/steron, ‘induction is a mode of reasoning which is clearer (to us) and more persuasive, because its materials are better known to us’, the example must be familiar and well known or it will not produce its effect in the way of proof; also some kind of induction is constantly used by every one, toi=s polloi=s koino/n; the syllogism and enthymeme are more ‘cogent’ and ‘effective’ against an adversary in a debate, and are therefore ‘more applauded’, qorubou=ntai de\ ma=llon oi( e)nqumhmatikoi/.

There is no real contradiction between what is here said and in Probl. XVIII 3. In the Problem the question is why people in general are better pleased with examples than with enthymemes, the fact being assumed. The answer is, that they learn more from them, and are therefore more amused, and the facts which are adduced by way of examples are more familiar and interesting; the enthymeme (as the syllogism in the Topics) proceeds from universals, which we are less acquainted with than with particulars. Consequently, examples are more pleasing and therefore plausible (piqana/), whilst the conclusive
argument, the enthymeme which leaves the adversary without reply, is more striking, and therefore more applauded.

qorubei=sqai, ‘to be applauded’, is a regular formation of the passive. For although the usual construction of qorubei=n is with e)pi/ and the dative, many examples of the transitive use of it are found. See the examples of both, and of the passive, in Ast's Lex. Plat. Isocr. Panath. § 233, (o( lo/gos) e)ph|nh/menos h)=n kai\ teqorubhme/nos: and Rhet. II 23, 30, tw=n sullogismw=n qorubei=tai ma/lista toiau=ta o(/sa k.t.l. Cf. Rhet. I 9, 40, quoted in Introd. p. 155.
e)rou=men u(/steron] II chapters 20—24.

piqano/n] ‘plausible’, that which readily persuades; pisto/n, ‘credible’, that which is to be relied on; the latter represents the higher degree of trustworthiness. dia\ toiou/twn, piqanw=n kai\ pistw=n.
The connexion of the argument of this section is given in the paraphrase, Introduction p. 155.

e)c w(=n e)/tuxen] sc. e)c e)kei/nwn a(\ e)/tuxen: ‘any materials, or propositions taken at random, any chance propositions’. So Rhet. I 5, 11, dia\ to\ mhde\n e)/xein w(=n to\ gh=ras gwba=tai. On the attraction of the relative from its proper case after the verb to that of its antecedent, see Matth. Gr. Gr. § 473, and note on Rhet. I 5, 11.

to\ e)/rgon au)th=s] The proper office, the special function, business, ‘work’, e)/rgon, of Rhetoric, is exercised in such things as we are obliged to take advice about, where there are no definite rules of art ready laid down to guide us.

The e)/rgon of anything is that which it is specially appointed (by nature) to do, its proper special work. It is in the execution, the carrying out or fulfilment of this e)/rgon, that this a)reth/, this special excellence of everything, resides. Nature always works intelligently with a purpose in view, pro\s te/los ti, everything has its own special e)/rgon. This is especially manifest in all ‘instruments’, o)/rgana (things in which the purpose is apparent); as of an axe or knife the office or purpose is to cut (large and small things), of a horse to run, of an eye to see, of the <*>ind to think, and so on; and the purpose or office being the same in kind and differing only in degree, in doing a thing at all and in doing it well, the a)reth/ is shewn in and measured by the performance of this special work; sharpness in the knife to cut well, swiftness in the horse to run well, is the due fulfilment of its e)/rgon. Eth. N. VI 2, 1139 a 16, h( <*>) a)reth\ pro\s to\ e)/rgon to\ oi)kei=on. This doctrine is first laid down by Plato, Rep. 1 352 E seq. and borrowed by Aristotle, Eth. Nic. I 6, and II 5, where the theory of moral virtue is based upon it. Hence Pol. I 2, 1253 a 23, pa/nta de\ tw=| e)/rgw| w(/ristai kai\ th=| duna/mei. Eth. Eud. II 1, 1218 b 38, peri\ a)reth=s, o(/ti e)sti\n h( belti/sth dia/qesis h)\ e(/cis h)\ du/namis e(ka/stwn, o(/swn e)sti/ tis xrh=sis h)\ e)/rgon, which is there illustrated at length.
dia\ pollw=n sunora=|n] ‘to take in at a glance through the medium, or along the line, of many steps of proof or syllogisms’, ‘to take in a long chain of arguments at one view’.

logi/zesqai po/r)r(wqen] expresses much the same thing as dia\ pollw=n sunora=|n, to deduce or string together syllogisms in a chain from a long way off or back, ‘to string together a long chain of connected syllogisms’. With po/r)r(wqen here, compare the similar use of it in II 22, 3, and Top. A 11, 105 a 8 ou)de\ dh\ w(=n su/neggus h( a)po/deicis, ou)d' w(=n li/an po/r)r(w.

bouleuo/meqa de/] On the proper objects of deliberation compare Eth.
Nic. III 5, VI 2 lege/sqw de\ tou/twn (tw=n th=s yuxh=s mori/wn) to\ me
 e)pisthmoniko
 to\ de\ logistiko/n, to\ ga bouleu/esqai kai\ logi/zesqai tau)to/n, ou)qei\s de\ bouleu/etai peri\ tw=n mh\ e)ndexome/nwn a)/llws e)/xein. c. 5, 1140 a 32, bouleu/etai d' ou)qei\s peri\ tw=n a)duna/twn a)/llws e)/xein, ou)de\ tw=n mh\ e)ndexome/nwn au)tw=| pra=cai. de Anima III 10, 4, 433 a 29, prakto
 d' e)sti\ to\ e)ndexo/menon kai\ a)/llws e)/xein. We deliberate and act only in cases where the event or issue is uncertain (may be in either of two ways, a)mfote/rws); where the event is necessarily this or that, i. e. certainly one way, and not the other, or where it is not in our own power, where we have no control over it, no one either deliberates whether or no anything is to be done or tries to do it. ta\ e)ndexo/mena a)mfo/terws e)/xein is usually expressed by ta\ e)ndexo/mena a)/llws e)/xein, things contingent and uncertain in their issue; opposed to ta\ mh\ e)ndexo/mena a)/llws e)/xein, things certain and necessary, which can be only in one way, which have only one possible issue, and cannot be in one way or another, indifferently.

ou(/tws u(polamba/nwn] ‘on that supposition’, i. e. if he actually supposes them to be necessary and unalterable: because it is possible that he may have deliberated or even attempted in action things which he did not know were beyond his control, in mere ignorance.

ou)de\n ple/on] ‘there is nothing to be gained by it, no advantage in it’. Valckenaer, Diatr. in Eur. Fragm. p. 150 (156), supplies numerous examples. In three MSS (Bekker) the words ou)de\n gar pleon are followed immediately by h)\ ou(/tws e)nde/xetai sumbouleu/ein. They were first omitted by Bekker, though previously suspected by Muretus. The origin of this interpolation, for such it seems to be, may be thus accounted for. The words sullogi/zesqai and suna/gein being very nearly synonymous, some one may have added in the margin h)\ ou(/tws: e)nde/xetai de\ sumbouleu/ein— meaning that we might read sumbouleu(ein in place of sullogi/zesqai to avoid the tautology, sumbouleu/ein referring to the deliberative branch of Rhetoric, or public speaking: h)\ ou(/tws, ‘or thus’, merely expressing the possibility of a various reading, e)nde/xetai de\ sumbouleu/ein. The essential stop after ou(/tws was then omitted or overlooked, and the words finally introduced into the text as an appendage to ple/on, with the sense, as rendered by Gaisford, ‘nihil enim amplius profici potest, quam quod sic deliberatur: i. e. incassum enim instituitur ista (altera) consultatio’.

suna/gein, (ratione) colligere. Rhet. II 22, 3 and 15. The su/n in words of this kind, which denote a process of reasoning or understanding, as sunie/nai, sumba/llein, (to comprehend, comprehendere,) and sullogi/zesqai itself, denotes the bringing of things together in the mind for the purpose of comparison, upon which either a judgment is founded and a conclusion drawn, or the understanding itself developed or enlightened. suna/gein and sullogi/zesqai are found again together as synonyms, Met. H. init. 1042 a 3, e)k dh\ tw=n ei)rhme/nwn sullogi/sasqai dei=, kai\ sunagago/ntas to\ kefa/laion te/los e)pitiqe/nai.
ta\ me\n e)k sullelogisme/nwn pro/teron] ‘the conclusions of previous syllogisms’, which serve as major premisses to new syllogisms, and so on through the entire chain of demonstration.

a(plou=s] ‘a simple, uncultivated person’, Germ. einfach. This use of the word belongs to the first of the three varieties above distinguished (note on a(plw=s, § 4 p. 30). It is opposed here rather to the ‘complications’ of an advanced stage of civilization and refinement, than to duplicity of character, and expresses ‘an elementary state of cultivation’. Similarly Pol. II 8, 1268 b 39, tou\s ga\r a)rxai/ous no/mous li/an a(plou=s ei)=nai kai\ barbarikou/s ‘rude and barbarous.
e)nqu/mhma—para/deigma] On enthymeme and example see Introd. pp. 99—108.

o( prw=tos sullogismo/s] prw=tos ‘in its earliest, most elementary’, or ‘normal, typical, form’. plh/rwma th=s prw/ths (primary, in its original form) po/lews, Pol. VI (IV) 4, 1291 a 17. a)ristokrati/an ma/lista tw=n a)/llwn para\ th\n a)lhqi/nhn kai\ prw/thn. Ib. c. 8, sub fin. Pol. VII (VI) c. 4, 1319 a 39, th\n belti/sthn kai\ prw/thn dhmokrati/an. On this passage, see note on II 21, 6.
oi(=on (pro\s to\ dhlou=n, sullogi/zesqai a)podei=cai) o(/ti. Infr. § 19, oi(=on o(/ti e)pe/bouleue k.t.l. and c. 1 § 13.
*dwrieu/s] the type of an Olympic victor; son of Diagoras of Rhodes, to whom Pindar's seventh Olympian ode is inscribed. See Introd. p. 158, note 1.

stefani/thn a)gw=na] This is the title distinctive of the four great games, of which honour was in reality the prize, the garland being merely a symbol or external sign. They were hereby distinguished from a)gw=nes xrhmati=tai or a)rguri=tai (Plut.) in which the prize was money, and in which therefore mercenary motives might possibly enter into the competition. Pausanias X 7, 3 tells us that it was not till the 2nd Pythiad that the Pythian games became an a)gw\n stefani/ths. Add to the instances
from Xen. Mem., Demosth., and Lycurg., Aesch. c. Ctes. § 179, and Isocr. Antid. § 301, tou\s a)qlhta\s tou\s e)n toi=s stefani/tais a)gw=si nikw=ntas.
[Anon. vita Euripidis, init. h)/skhse de\ kat' a)rxa\s pagkra/tion h)\ pugmh\n, tou= patro\s au)tou= xrhsmo\n labo/ntos o(/ti stefanhfo/rous a)gw=nas nikh/sei. S.]
*)olu/mpia neni/khken] The accusative in these phrases is an extension or ‘equivalent’ of a cognate accusative. Jelf, Gr. Gr. § 564.
A summary repetition of the contents of the following sections, 14—19, is given in the chapter on lu/sis, II 25, 8—9.
e)pei\ d' e)sti\n o)li/ga—w(s e)pi\ to\ polu/] Comp. II 22, 3, kai\ mh\ mo/non suna/gein e)k tw=n a)nagkai/wn, a)ll' kai\ e)k tw=n w(s e)pi\ to\ polu/.

e)ndexo/mena] ‘things possible’, as opposed to things necessary, not here to things impossible. On e)nde/xesqai and du/nasqai, to\ e)ndexo/menon and to\ dunato/n in Aristotle, see Waitz on Anal. Pr. I 3, 25 a 37, (Vol. I p. 375 seq.) and Bonitz on Metaph. *q 3, 1047 a 26, p. 387. dunato/n according to Waitz, where the two are distinguished, expresses physical, e)ndexo/menon logical, possibility: the latter implies the possible truth of an assertion, viz. that when we assert anything we do not contradict ourselves. e)ndexo/mena are therefore here ‘possibilities’ as opposed to certainties; things and events which are only conceived as possible, which may be in one way or in another. In the ordinary language e)nde/xesqai and e)ndexo/menon have usually some other words, as a)/llws e)/xein, ge/nesqai h)\ mh\ gi/gnesqai, or something similar, added to them in the way of a definition or limitation. With the absolute use of it in this passage (and the general sense in which it appears in Waitz's and Bonitz's Commentaries) comp. I 4, 3, ou)de\ dh\ peri\ tw=n e)ndexome/nwn a(pa/ntwn. Eth. Nic. VI 2, 1139 a 8, e(\n de\ w(=| ta\ e)ndexo/mena. Ib. c. 12, 1143 b 2, tou= e)sxa/tou kai\ e)ndexome/nou.

e)k tw=n a)nalutikw=n.] Anal. Pr. I 8, 29 b 29, e)pei\ d' e(/tero/n e)stin u(pa/rxein te kai\ e)c a)na/gkhs u(pa/rxein kai\ e)nde/xesqai u(pa/rxein (polla\ ga\r u(pa/rxei me/n, ou) me/ntoi e)c a)na/gkhs: ta\ d' ou)/t) e)c a)na/gkhs ou)/q) u(pa/rxei o(/lws, e)nde/xetai d) u(pa/rxein) dh=lon o(/ti kai\ sullogismo\s e(ka/stou tou/twn e(/teros e)/stai, kai\ ou)x
o(moi/ws e)xo/ntwn tw=n o(/rwn, a)|ll' o( me\n e)c a)nagkai/wn, o( d) e)c u(parxo/ntwn, o( d) e)c e)ndexome/nwn. Anal. Pr. I 13, 32 b 4, where two kinds of possibility, to\ e)ndexo/menon, are distinguished: one, the order of nature, which from its ordinary uniformity makes a near approach to the necessary, and the other, the indefinite, the purely accidental, to\ a)po\ tu/xhs, in which there is no natural order at all.

ta\ me\n a)nagkai=a e)/stai, ta\ de\ plei=sta w(s e)pi\ to\ polu/] ‘It is plain that the materials of enthymemes, the propositions or premisses of which they are constructed, though they may be necessary, are most of them no more than probabilities, or things that usually happen’. [On me/n—de/, see the references above given in note on 1 § 12 p. 24.]
ge/getai e)nqumh/mata e)c ei)ko/twn kai\ shmei/wn] Comp. I 3, 7, II 25, 8, where paradei/gmata are added. Anal. Pr. II 27, 70 a 10.

On ei)ko/ta and shmei=a, Introd. p. 160—163. The meaning and connexion of the following sections on the rhetorical instruments of proof are explained in full detail in the paraphrase, to which the reader is referred (Introd. p. 163—168).
*lu=sai to\ lexqe/n] On lu/ein, lu/sis, luto/n, see Introd. on II 25 p. 267 and note 1.

te/kmar] Eustathius ad Il. H. p. 665, 45. tekmai/resqai to\ teleiou=n, a)po\ tou= te/kmwr, o(\ dhloi= to\ te/los. to\ me/ntoi tekmai/resqai a)nti\ tou= shmeiou=sqai, a)f' ou(= kai\ te/kmar to\ shmei=on, oi( meq) *(/omhron le/gousi. ‘Antiqua lingua, quam mox commemorat Aristoteles, non erat ab Homeri dialecto diversa.
Vide Il. N. 20. Od. d/. 373, et alibi. Homeri carmina ea aetate qua vixit Aristoteles propter vetustatem apud vulgus obscuriora fuisse aliunde constat. Ex. gr. Vox a)/poina invenitur in Iliadis locis minimum viginti et sex: Olympiade tamen CVII qua orationem c. Aristocratem habuit Demosthenes, ea Athenis prorsus obsoleverat. Dignus est Demosthenis locus qui hic proponatur. Vetarat scilicet antiqua lex tou\s a)ndrofo/nous —mh\ lumai/nesqai mhde\ a)poina=|n. Quam sic explicare pergit orator summus p. 630, 25. to\ me\n dh\ mh\ lumai/nesqai, gnw/rimon oi)=d' o(/ti pa=sin—to\ de\ mh\ a)poina=|n, mh\ xrh/mata pra/ttesqai: ta\ ga\r xrh/mata a)/poina w)no/mazon oi( palaioi/. Adeo universe verum est quod de Homeri tantum geographia scripsit Strabo VIII p. 484=513. ta\ d' *(omh/rou ske/yews dei=tai kritikh=s, poihtikw=s le/gontos, kai\ ou) ta\ nu=n, a)lla\ ta)rxai=a, w(=n o( xro/nos h)mau/rwke ta\ polla/.’ Gaisford.

to\ de/, oi(=on ei)/ tis...a)nagkai=on.] The auctor ad Heren. II 25, 39, gives two ‘signs’ of an opposite, fallacious, or refutable character, derived from the same sources, Necesse est quoniam pallet aegrotasse: aut, necesse est peperisse, quoniam sustinet puerum infantem. These illustrations had doubtless become traditional, and commonplaces in the rhetorical books.

pneustia=|n] ‘to have an affection or disease of the breath’. A large class of verbs in aw and iaw are either desiderative (like those in eaw and in Latin in urio) or expressive of an affection, usually some form of disease; the latter can be extended to a ‘mental’ affection. Jelf, Gr. Gr. § 330, Obs. 3 e and Obs. 4, would separate these into two classes (1) desideratives in aw and iaw, and (2) verbs in iaw, which express a state of sickness [Kühner's Ausführliche Grammatik § 328. 8]. Buttmann also in his Gr. Gr. § 119 and p. 294 (Engl. Transl.) assumes a distinction between some varieties of them, which is not very clearly made out. They fall under three heads, first desideratives, second imitatives (as
turannia=|n, to play the tyrant); “but,” he adds, “it is improper to rank verbs denoting diseases (the third), o)fqalmia=|n, u(deria=|n, ywra=|n, &c., in the same class (as the imitatives);” these belong rather to a preceding division, viz. verbs in aw formed from nouns, “and expressing, chiefly, the having a thing or quality, and performing an action; as koma=|n, xola=|n, boa=|n, goa=|n, tolma=|n.”

A much better and more exact account of these forms of verbs, in respect of the connexion and distinction of their senses, is to be found in Lobeck's learned note on Phrynichus, p. 79—83. “Verbs in a=|n and ia=|n,” (this is not true of all these verbs and requires qualification; dama=|n, geitnia=|n, pera=|n, for instance, can hardly be said to denote either a bodily, or mental affection. It should be “some verbs” or “a large class of verbs in aw”) “in both forms, are properly used of affections of mind and body. splhnia=|n, to\n splh=na a)lgei=n, liqia=|n, kriqia=|n, molubdia=|n express bodily ailments; duserwtia=|n, numfia=|n, pasxhtia=|n, and all desideratives (which have either of these terminations) express some affections of the mind, either as a malady, a longing, or in some other form.” This is an amplification of what Lobeck actually says: and it is also I think implied that the bodily affection is the primary signification, which is extended by metaphor to the mental. A long list of examples is there given, chiefly of rarer words. I have collected some examples from various Greek writers, which, as most of them do not appear in Lobeck's list, or in the grammars, I will here add.

In Aristophanes, as was to be expected, they most abound. o)fqalmia=|n Ran. 192, boubwnia=|n ib. 1280, lhmatia=|n 494, w)rakia=|n 481 and Pac. 702, daimonia=|n, daimona=|n Thesm. 1054 (and in Aeschylus, Eur., Xenoph.), strathgia=|n (quoted by Schol. on Ran. 965, Xen. Anab. VII c. 33, Dem. de F. L. § 337 “to have an itch or mania for commanding an army”), eu)rwtia=|n Nub. 44, lhma=|n 326, maqhtia=|n 183, xezhtia=|n 1387, sibullia=|n Eq. 81, korubantia=|n Vesp. 8, boulimia=|n Plut. 870, fona=|n Soph. Phil. 1209 (Hesych. to\ e)pi\ fo/non mai/nesqai), toma=|n Aj. 589 (tomh=s e)piqumei=n, Schol.), qanatia=|n Schol. ad Phil. l. c., qanata=|n (to long for death) Plut. Phaed. 64 B, nautia=|n Theaet. 191 A, Legg. 1 639 B, knhsia=|n Gorg. 494 E, ywra=|n kai\ knhsia=|n ib. c. (Arist. Eccles. 919), podagra=|n Alcib. II 139 E, 140 A. In Aristotle we have spoudarxia=|n (to be infected with the disease of office-hunting), Pol. VIII (V) 5 sub fin., a)gwnia=|n, of mental distress or anxiety, Rhet. I 9, 21. Many in the works on Nat. Hist., as taura=|n, skuza=|n, o)rga=|n, kapria=|n (or kapra=|n), all implying a sexual impulse, Hist. An. VI 18 §§ 12, 14, 17, VI 20, 4; podagra=|n VI 21, 5, saturia=|n de Gen. An. IV 3, 22, u(drwpia=|n ib. v. 8, 13, e)cudrwpia=|n ib. V 20, 5, straggouria=|n (also Arist. Thesm. 616, Plat. Legg. XI 2, 916 A, straggouria=|n, liqa=|n). Theophr. p. a)lazonei/as, w)nhtia=|n, “to have a mania, or itch, for buying”, Diog. Laert. vit. Plat. III 18 “oi( lo/goi sou, fhsi\n (o( *dionusios), gerontiw=sin” (are infected with, smack of, old age), kai\ o(/s, (o( *pla/twn), “sou= de/ ge turanniw=sin”. (If this is the passage referred to by Buttm. in quoting the verb turannia=|n in his Grammar, above cited—no reference is given—he is wrong both in attributing to it the sense of “imitation”, and in assigning it to a separate class.)
e)n toi=s a)nalutikoi=s] Anal. Pr. II 27.

a)/mfw h)=|.] This union of neuter dual with verb singular, following the analogy of neuter plural in the same construction, is illustrated in Jelf, Gr. Gr. § 384, Obs. 1. [Kühner's Ausf. Gram. § 364.]

oi(=on o(/ti e)pibouleu/ei turranni/di *dionu/sios k.t.l.] The stratagem by which Dionysius actually succeeded in obtaining his body-guard (496 B.C.) contrary to the wishes of the majority of the Syracusan citizens is related by Diodorus, XIII 95. See Grote, Hist. Gr. Vol. X. p. 610—614. Aristotle again refers to the attempt, Pol. III 15 ult. On the similar, and equally successful attempt of Pisistratus, Grote, H. G. Vol. III p. 208, 209. This occurred at his first usurpation of government B.C. 560. (Grote, Clin<*>on.) Theagenes of Megara (Grote, H. G. Vol. III p. 59, 60) is mentioned by Aristotle, Pol. VIII (V) 5 sub fin., together with Pisistratus and Dionysius, as one of those who had succeeded in making themselves tyrants of their native countries, by imposing upon the popular party; Aristotle notices the stratagem by which he effected his purpose (tw=n eu)po/rwn ta\ kth/nh a)posfa/cas, labw
 para\ to
 potamo
 e)pine/montas). Thucydides also, I 126, mentions him as having assisted Cylon in the attempt which he also made on the tyranny at Athens; Herod. V. 71. Cylon was his sonin-law, Thuc. u.s. Cylon's attempt was made in 620 B.C. (Clint. F. H. sub anno), and Theagenes kat' e)kei=non to
 xro/non e)turanneu/ei *mega/rwn (Thuc.). Cylon's attempt (and consequently the tyranny of Theagenes) took place, says Herodotus u. s., “before the age of Pisistratus.” Theagenes was contemporary with Periander of Corinth, whose reign lasted from B.C. 625—585 (Grote u.s. p. 58).

ai)tw=n th
 fulakh/n] Plat. Rep. VIII 16, 566 B, to\ dh\ turanniko
 ai)/thma to\ poluqru/lhton e)pi\ tou/tw| pa/ntes oi( ei)s tou=to probebhko/tes e)ceuri/skousin, ai)tei=n to
 dh=mon fu/laka/s tinas tou= sw/matos, i(/na sw=s au)toi=s h)=| o( tou= dh/mou bohqo/s. Herod. I 59, of Pisistratus. Infr. ad I 8, 4.

u(po\ to\ au)to\ kaqo/lou] “under the same universal”, i. e. genus or species; which stand to the species or individuals subordinate to each respectively, in the relation of universal to particular. to\ kaqo/lou is that which is universally predicable, or predicable of every member of a class. Metaph. *d 26, 1023 b 29, to\ me
 ga kaqo/lou kai\ to\ o(/lws lego/menon w(s o(/lon ti o)
 ou(/tws e)sti\ kaqo/lou w(s polla\ perie/xon tw=| kathgorei=sqai kaq' e(ka/stou kai\ e(
 a(/panta ei)=nai w(s e(/kaston, oi(=on a)/nqrwpon, i(/ppon, qeo/n, o(/ti a(/panta zw=|a. Ib. Z 13, 1038 b 11, to\ de\ kaqo/lou koino/n: tou=to ga le/getai kaqo/lou o(\ plei/osin u(pa/rxein pe/fuken. Anal. Post. I 4, 73 b 26, kaqo/lou de\ le/gw o(\ a)
 kata\ pa/nto/s te u(pa/rxh| kai\ kaq' au(to\ kai\ h(=| au)to/ (see Waitz, Comm. p. 315), of which the triangle is given as an exemplification, as the universal notion of all three-sided figures; applicable to any one of them, to\ tuxo/n, and prw=ton, the highest or primary conception of triangles (the i)soskele/s, for example, a subordinate species, being only secondary): to\ kaqo/lou de\ u(pa/rxei to/te, o(/tan e)pi\ tou= tuxo/ntos kai\ prw/tou deiknu/htai. Thus the kaqo/lou is equivalent to the ge/nos under which all the species and individuals of the entire class are included, o(\ kata\ pa/ntwn kathgorei=tai, and is opposed to kaq' e(/kaston and kata\ me/ros.

kateilhmme/nas] ‘fixed, established, settled’. katalamba/nein is ‘to lay hold of, to get into one's possession’, or ‘to occupy’, as an army occupies a conquered city or country. See the Lexicon for examples of this, the primary sense of the word. Thence it passes into the signification of ‘binding’ as by an oath, Herod. IX. 106, pi/sti te katalabo/ntes kai\ o(rki/oisi e)mme/nein te kai\ mh\ a)posth/sesqai. Thuc. V 21 (sponda\s) eu(=ron kateilhmme/nas (settled or concluded, ‘confirmed’, Schol. i)sxura/s) VIII 63, 3, ta\ e)n au)tw=| tw=| strateu/mati e)/ti bebaio/teron kate/labon (they secured, established or confirmed their interest in the army, Arnold). Plat. Legg. VII 23, 823 A, ta\ tai=s zhmi/ais u(po\ no/mwn kateilhmme/na (comprehensa et firmata, Stallbaum). Arist. Pol. IV (VII) 2, 1324 b 21, ta\ me\n no/mois kateilhmme/na ta\ de\ e)/qesin, (fest gesetzt, Stahr). Eth. Nic. X. 10, 1179 b 18, ta\ e)k palaiou= toi=s h)/qesi kateilhmme/na lo/gw| metasth=sai.
tou\s a)kroata/s] should be omitted, with Muretus, Vater, and Spengel. The ‘oversight’ in question applies only to the rhetoricians, not to the audience.

kai\ ma=llon a(pto/menoi kata\ tro/pon metabai/nousin e)c au)tw=n] ma=llon belongs to a(pto/menoi and metabai/nousin, “the more they handle their subject according to the ‘appropriate method’, the more they pass out of, or stray beyond, transgress the limits of, the true province of Rhetoric”. kata\ tro/pon is equivalent or nearly so to deo/ntws, ‘duly’, ‘in the right and proper way’; and is often found in Plato opposed to a)po\ tro/pou. po/r)r(w tou= kaqh/kontos, Schol. ad Theaet. 143 C. Gaisford from Steph. Thesaurus supplies examples from Plato and Isocrates, and others will be found in Stallbaum's note on Rep. V 16, 470 B. deo/ntws itself appears in three MSS after tro/pon, being doubtless, as Gaisford supposes, a gloss on the preceding. I have followed Mr Poste, Introd. to Transl. of Post. Anal. p. 20, n. 3, in translating kata\ tro/pon, ‘the appropriate method’, ‘in the right way, or in due order’, and it may very well bear that meaning. It will therefore be equivalent to kata\ th
 oi)kei/an me/qodon, the method which confines itself to the peculiar principles, the i)di/ai or oi)kei=ai a)rxai/, of the special science which it investigates. ma=llon a(pto/menoi kata\ tro/pon is equivalent to, and explained by, o(/sw| tis a)
 be/ltion e)kle/ghtai ta\s prota/seis, near the end of the next section, § 21; and the a)rxai/, which are spoken of immediately afterwards, a)
 ga e)ntu/xh| a)rxai=s, are the i)/diai a)rxai/, the special principles of each particular science above mentioned. Dialectics and Rhetoric have no such special principles, and their method is the ‘inappropriate’. Gaisford follows Muretus in inserting h)\ before kata\ tro/pon ‘by handling them too properly’. The other interpretation seems preferable in itself, and requires no alteration. metabai/nein is metabai/nein ei)s a)/llo ge/nos, technically used of passing from one science to another, and illicitly transferring its appropriate principles. Comp. I 4, 6. See Poste, u.s. p. 51, note 1, for examples from the Organon. Add Top. *q 11, 161 a 33. Anal. Post. I 7 treats of this subject.
On koinai\ and oi)kei=ai a)rxai/ see Introd. p. 73 note and the references there given.

peri\ w(=n tou\s to/pous le/gomen] (peri\ tou/twn peri\ w(=n): to which we apply the term ‘the to/poi’, par excellence; the koinoi\ to/poi, namely. See below, § 22; and for this treatment of them, II 19.

i)/dia de/, o(/sa e)k tw=n peri\ e(/kaston ei)=dos kai\ ge/nos prota/sewn e)sti/] ei)=dos kai\ ge/nos, species or genus, whichever you please. In any classification the same member may be either genus or species, according as it is regarded from above or below: Physics and Mathematics, for example, are either species in relation to the genus Philosophy, or again genera in relation to the subordinate species, Psychology (so all the ancient philosophers) and Natural History of the one, and Geometry and Arithmetic of the other. Only the summum genus and the infima species are not thus interchangeable.

ka)kei=na me
—e)/mfrona] ‘The former, the koinoi\ to/poi, will make no one any the wiser, will convey no intelligence or instruction to any one, about any class of things’. This is the didaskali/a or genuine instruction that belongs to science, didaskali/as ga/r e)stin o( kata\ th
 e)pisth/mhn lo/gos (I 1, 12; see note on p. 23); comp. I 4, 4, dia\ to\ mh/te th=s r(htorikh=s ei)=nai te/xnhs, a)ll' e)mfroneste/ras kai\ ma=llon a)lhqinh=s. Plato has employed the word in the. same way, Legg. VII 14, 809 D tou\s de\ a)nqrw/pous peri\ au)ta\ ma=llon e)/mfronas a)perga/zwntai.—e)/mfrwn belongs to the class of adjectives compounded with e)n, in which the preposition expresses the indwelling or inherence of something in something else, e)/myuxos (with soul in it, containing life, animated), e)/nqeos, e)/nnous, e)/nqhros, e)/mpnous, e)/myofos, e)/gxumos, e)/ntrixos, e)/ndikos, e)/ntoma (insects), Ar. Hist. An. IV 1, 5, e)/sti d' e)/ntoma o(/sa kata\ tou)/noma e)sti
 e)ntoma\s e)/xonta k.t.l.

a)/llhn e)pisth/mhn th=s dialektikh=s] a)/llos, a comparative in form as well as in sense, naturally, like e(/teros, dia/foros, diafe/rwn, et sim., takes the same construction, with the genitive. On the comparative form of a)/llos see Donaldson, New Crat. §§ 165, 166.
ou)ke/ti] See note on I 1, 7 on h)/dh &c. esp. p. 14.

kaqa/per ou)=n kai\ e)n toi=s topikoi=s—lhpte/on] ‘Cum tanta formarum (i. e. tw=n ei)dw=n) locorumque differentia sit, quantam ipse supra demonstravit: ut scilicet illae fraudi dialectico et oratori, non recte usurpatae ab ipsis, esse possint, loci nullum tale periculum secum portent: aliaque etiam discrimina sint, affirmat oportere distinguere enthymematum species appellatas ab his qui loci vocantur, ex quibus illa ipsa promuntur: ut in Topicis factum est, ita etiam in his qui oratorem instruunt libris.’ Victorius. ‘We must here also, as well as in Dialectics, carefully distinguish the sources and materials (e)c w(=n lhpte/on) from which the special and the general topics are to be derived’.

pro/tasis, a logical or rhetorical premiss or proposition, in syllogism or enthymeme: propositio praemissa; ‘est enim protei/nein (Top. *q 1, 155 b 34, 38), vel protei/nesqai (ib. c. 14, 164 b 4 &c.) eas propositiones constituere unde conclusio efficiatur.’ Trendel. El. Log. Arist. § 2, p. 53.

ta\ stoixei=a] On stoixei=a, ‘the elements’ of rhetorical reasoning, see Introd. p. 127. Add to the illustrations there given Rhet. ad Alex. c. 36 (37) 9, stoixei=a koina\ kata\ pa/ntwn, apparently in this sense.

div2.p: The triple division of Rhetoric, sumbouleutiko/n, dikaniko/n, e)pideiktiko/n, is, as we learn from Quintilian, II 21, 23, III 4, 1, and 7, 1, due to Aristotle: Anaximenes, his predecessor, had admitted only two genera, with seven species subordinate to these, III 4, 9.

Almost all writers (prope omnes) on the subject, subsequent to Aristotle, had accepted his division, as proceeding from the ‘highest authority’ (utique summae apud antiquos auctoritatis) III 4, 1. Quintilian in this fourth chapter mentions, besides Aristotle's division, those which were adopted by Anaximenes, Protagoras, Plato (in the Sophist), and Isocrates. He decides in favour of Aristotle's, as the safest to follow, both because the preponderance of authority is on its side, and also because it is the most reasonable.

div3.p: qewro\n h)\ krith/n] This classification of the different kinds of ‘audience’ is made for the purpose of determining the divisions of Rhetoric; because, the audience being the end and object of the speech, that to which every speech is ultimately referred, and everything being defined or determined by its end (te/los, Eth. Nic. III 10, 1115 b 23), the number of the varieties of audiences must fix the number of the divisions or branches of Rhetoric. Audiences are of two kinds; either mere ‘spectators’, like the qeatai/ in a theatre, at the games, or in any exhibition where amusement is the object, or at all events where there is no interest of a practical character or tendencyThuc. III. 38 (Cleon to the Athenian assembly), ai)/tioi d' u(mei=s kakw=s a)gwnoqetou=ntes, oi(/tines ei)w/qate qeatai\ me\n tw=n lo/gwn gi/gnesqai, a)kroatai\ de\ tw=n e)/rgwn, k.t.l. “You go to the public assembly as you go to the theatre, merely in quest of intellectual excitement. You go as qeatai/ or qewroi/, that is, merely for your amusement; and not as kritai/, that is, carefully weighing the matter of what is said, in order to adopt it in your practice or reject it.” Arnold.; or else ‘judges’, where some real interest is at stake, and they are called upon to pronounce a decision (pars negotialis, pragmatikh/ Quint.). But these decisions, and those who pronounce them, again fall into two classes, according as they are referred to questions, (1) of political expediency and look to the future, or (2) of right or wrong in respect of past acts or facts.

So that we have three kinds of audiences, and consequently three branches of Rhetoric. The public or national assembly, to which the deliberative kind of rhetoric is addressed; the law-courts and their ‘judges’, properly so called, the object of the forensic or judicial branch of the art; and thirdly the ‘spectators’, those who go to be amused or interested by the show-speeches, or e)pidei/ceis, the Panegyrics (in two senses), funeral orations, burlesques, or whatever other form may be taken by speeches composed merely to display skill in composition without practical interest (where the du/namis, the faculty, or skill shewn, is only in question); or, if they please, to criticise them, and so become ‘critics’.

The term krith/s, ‘judge’, which belongs properly only to the second of the three branches, may also be extended to the other two, since they all have to ‘decide’ in some sense, to choose between opposite views, either on questions of expediency in matters of state, or right and wrong in legal questions, or the merits of a composition as ‘critics’. Comp. II 18, 1, III 12, 5, and also Rhet. ad Alex. c. 18 (19), 14, where (comp. § 10) kritai/ seems to be used in this general sense for all kinds of a)kroatai/.

e)pideiktiko/n] ‘ea quae constat laude ac vituperatione. Quod genus videtur Aristoteles, atque eum secutus Theophrastus, a parte negotiali, hoc est pragmatikh=|, removisse, totamque ad solos auditores relegasse; et id eius nominis, quod ab ostentatione ducitur, proprium est.’ Quint. III 7, 1.
oi( i)di/a| sumbouleu/ontes] II 18, 1, a)/n te pro\s e(/na tis tw=| lo/gw| xrw/menos protre/ph| h)\ a)potre/ph|, oi(=on oi( nouqetou=ntes poiou=sin h)\ pei/qontes.
o(poteronou=n] Append. [This Appendix was apparently never written. S.]

xro/noi—tw=| me\n sumbouleu/onti o( me/llwn] I have already pointed out, Introd. p. 120, that Demosthenes adds to\ paro/n, ‘present time’, to the ‘future’ of Aristotle, as characteristic of the deliberative branch of Rhetoric; and Aristotle himself, in two subsequent passages of this treatise, I 6 § 1, and 8 § 7.

kuriw/tatos] On ku/rios, in its secondary and metaphorical application, see note on I 11 § 4. The kind of ‘authority’ which this ‘present time’ is here said to carry with it in the epideictic branch is, that it has of all the three the best right to be there; that it is most ‘proper’ or appropriate in that place. It has here very much the same sense as in the phrases kuri/a h(me/ra, kuri/a e)kklhsi/a, a day or assembly which has a special authority, as ‘fixed’ and ‘appointed’ for a certain purpose; opposed to all ordinary days, and irregular assemblies, which are su/gklhtoi, called together at a moment's notice on special emergencies.
ta\ geno/mena—ta\ me/llonta] The accusatives are here attracted by the participles, instead of following the principal verb in the dative.
proeika/zontes] ‘with, in the way of, an anticipatory guess or presentiment’, of future honours and distinctions of the subject of the encomium.

o( de\ a)potre/pwn w(s xei=ron: a)potre/pei] ‘Fr. A. Wolf's einleuchtende verbesserung w(s xei/ronos findet einige bestätigung in den ungrammatischen worten der paraphrase: a)potre/pei de\ tw=| xei/roni’ (Brandis, ap. Schneid. Philol. p. 45). This alteration seems to me to be totally unnecessary. It is true that the ordinary construction of the verb in the sense here intended is a)potre/pein tina/ tinos, or a)po/ tinos, as § 6, ‘to divert or dissuade some one from something’. But it is plain it can equally well be adapted to the other form of expression adopted here, ‘to divert the thing from the person—in the way of dissuasion—to turn it away from him, as (being) worse’, i. e. ‘to dissuade him from it (as the Greeks as well as ourselves usually say) as the less expedient course’. An author like Aristotle, always regardless of the ordinary usages of language, may very well be allowed such a liberty of expression. If, however, this be still objected to, we may, without alteration of the text—to be admitted I think, as a general rule, only as a last resource—understand w(s xei=ron as an absolute case, nomin. or accus., o( de\ a)potre/pwn w(s xei=ron (o)/n ti), a)potre/pei (tina\ au)tou=). See similar examples in note on II 8, 10.
pro\s tou=to] ‘with a view to, with reference to, this’; all the rest (ta\ a)/lla) as supplementary and subordinate to this.

sumparalamba/nei] ‘takes in as an adjunct, in aid of, as an auxiliary, subordinate and subsidiary, to his main purpose’; de Anima A 2, 1, ta\s tw=n prote/rwn do/cas sumparalamba/nein o(/soi ti peri\ au)th=s a)pefh/nanto. Plat. Phaed. 65 A e)a/n tis au)to\ (to\ sw=ma) e)n th=| zhth/sei koinwno\n sumparalamba/nh|. Ib. 84 D, Lach. 179 E. Spengel ad Rhet. ad Alex. XXV 8, p. 192.
toi=s de\ dikazome/nois] to\ te/los e)sti/.
e)panafe/rousi] ‘re-fer’ (a)nafe/rein) ‘to’ (e)pi/).

peri\ me\n ga\r tw=n a)/llwn k.t.l] On the ‘legal issues’ here intimated, the a)mfibisth/seis (Aristotle), or sta/seis (subsequent Rhetoricians and Lawyers), comp. I 13, 9; III 15, 2; 16, 6; 17, 1, and Introd. p. 397, Append. E to Bk. III.
w(s d' ou)k a)/dikon] (i. e. tou= le/gein w(s, or tou= w(s, ‘the fact that’), ou)de\n fronti/zousin. On the necessary limitation and qualification of this position of Aristotle, see Introd. p. 170.

e)n e)pai/nw| polla/kis tiqe/asin k.t.l.] Isocrates gives credit to the Athenian people, e)n e)pai/nw| ti/qhsin, for this kind of disinterested policy, in a passage referred to by Victorius. Paneg. § 53 *)axille/a e)painou=sin o(/ti e)boh/qhse k.t.l. Plat. Symp. 179 E pepusme/nos para\ th=s mhtro\s w(s a)poqanoi=to a)poktei/nas *(/ektora, mh\ poih/sas de\ tou=to oi)/kad' e)lqw\n ghraio\s teleuth/soi, e)to/lmhsen e(le/sqai bohqh/sas tw=| e)rasth=| *patro/klw| kai\ timwrh/sas ou) mo/non u(perapoqanei=n, a)lla\ kai\ e)papoqanei=n teteleuthko/ti. Apol. 28 C o( th=s *qe/tidos ui(o/s, o(\s tosou=ton tou= kindu/nou katefro/nhse para\ to\ ai)sxro/n ti u(pomei=nai, w(/ste e)peidh\ ei)=pen h( mhth\r au)tw=| proqumoume/nw| *(/ektora a)poktei=nai, *qeo\s ou)=sa, ou(twsi/ pws, w(s e)gw=|mai, w)= pai=, ei) timwrh/seis *patro/klw| tw=| e(tai/rw| to\n fo/non kai\ *(/ektora a)poktenei=s, au)to\s a)poqanei=: au)ti/ka gar toi, fhsi/, meq' *(/ektora po/tmos e(toi=mos (Hom. Il. *s 98 et infra au)ti/ka teqnai/hn k.t.l. v. 104) o( de\ tau=t' a)kou/sas k.t.l. comp. Il. I 410 seq. Aeschines likewise, c. Timarch. §§ 145, 150, refers to (in the one) and quotes (in the other) this same passage of Hom. Il. *s. u. s., but with a totally different purpose.

The argument of this and the two following sections of this chapter will be found in a more connected shape in the paraphrase of the Introd. pp. 171—2. The sum of it is simply this: each of the two kinds of to/poi is equally necessary in all the three branches of Rhetoric; (1) the ei)/dh, or i)/dioi to/poi, or i)/dia, from which the rhetorical propositions or premisses, the ei)ko/ta, shmei=a, and tekmh/ria are necessarily derived, § 7: and (2) the four koinoi\ to/poi, here apparently reduced to three, the possible
and impossible', ‘fact past and future’, and ‘the great and small (the topic of magnitude or importance) either (1) absolute or (2) comparative (degree)’. §§ 8, 9.

dikai/wma] is used here and in c. 13 §§ 1, 3, as the opposite to a)di/khma, in the sense of ‘an act of justice’. So Eth. Nic. V 10, 1135 a 8, diafe/rei de\ to\ a)di/khma kai\ to\ a)/dikon kai\ to\ dikai/wma kai\ to\ di/kaion: a)/dikon me
 ga/r e)sti th=| fu/sei h)\ ta/cei: (i. q. no/mw|, natural or of human institution.) to\ d' au)to\ de\ tou=to o(/tan praxqh=| a)di/khma/ e)sti, pri
 de\ praxqh=nai ou)/pw, a)ll) a)/dikon. o(moi/ws de\ kai\ dikai/wma. kalei=tai de\ ma=llon dikaiopra/ghma to\ koino/n, dikai/wma de\ to\ e)parno/rqwma tou= a)dikh/matos: where in the first clause it is used in its ordinary acceptation as ‘a just act’,=dikaiopra/ghma, and contrasted with a)di/khma, and afterwards distinguished from it in the more correct sense of ‘a rectification of an act of injustice’. It is in this signification that Plato employs it, Legg. IX 8, 864 E, tw=n de\ a)/llwn dikaiwma/twn a)fei/sqw, ‘all other penalties’, which are as it were ‘amendments of a wrong or injustice’. In Thuc. I 41 init. it stands for ‘just claims’, ‘rechtsgründe’, Poppo; rechtsanspruch’, Heitz, l. c. In Arist. de Caelo,
I 10, 1, it has a sense either derived from that rectification or amendment, an e)pano/rqwma of a wrong view or argument, ma=llon a)
 ei)/h pista\ ta\ me/llonta lexqh/sesqai proakhkoo/si ta\ tw=n a)mfisbhtou/ntwn lo/gwn dikaiw/mata: or rather, as in Thucydides, it denotes a justification or just claim, meaning what the conflicting arguments have each of them to say for themselves. dikai/wma ‘actio iuris, exsecutio iuris, iustificatio, ex qua (per arbitrum) status iustus qui erat violatus restituitur: nam dikaiou=n est facere ut quid sit di/kaion’. Fritsche ad Eth. Eudem. *d 10, 1135 a 13 (p. 109) q. v., Heitz, Verl. Schrift. Arist. p. 253.
oi(=on] ‘for example’, one of several, is used here, as constantly elsewhere, loosely and carelessly, by Aristotle, in the place of tou=t' e)sti/, id est, videlicet, as a more explanatory repetition.
On the first of the three branches of Rhetoric, to\ sumbouleutiko\n or dhmhgoriko\n ge/nos.

ei)=nai h)\ gene/sqai] This ‘fundamental antithesis’ and cardinal distinction of ancient philosophy is noticed by Gaisford, incredible as it may appear, for the sole purpose of making merry with it as a sophistical quibble! ‘Has Sophistarum ineptias facete ridet Antiphanes apud Athenaeum, III 99 A.’
peri\ de\ tou/twn] See note on dh=lon de/, C. 1 § 11 p. 20.

kai\ fu/sei...kai\ a)po\ tu/xhs gino/mena a)gaqa/] This same distinction of goods naturally and accidentally accruing to us, is found in Eth. Eud. 1 3, 5, 1215 a 12, ei) me
 ga e)n toi=s dia\ tu/xhn genome/nois h)\ toi=s dia\ fu/sin to\ kalw=s zh=|n e)sti
, a)ne/lpiston a)
 ei)/h polloi=s. These are opposed to those advantages and objects of desire the acquisition of which depends upon ourselves and our own exertions and studies. ou) ga/r e)sti di) e)pimelei/as h( kth=sis ou)de\ e)p' au)toi=s ou)de\ th=s au)tw=n pragmatei/as compared with o(/sa pe/fuken a)na/gesqai ei)s h(ma=s (to be referred to ourselves), kai\ w(=n h( a)rxh\ th=s gene/sews e)f' h(mi=n e)sti/n. The gifts of nature and the good things that result from accident cannot be included amongst the possible advantages,
the ‘profitable’ or ‘expedient’, which are the object and aim of the deliberative speaker, because they are not attainable by any exertions of our own; and so for the purposes of Rhetoric are just as useless as things necessary and impossible. The subjects of Rhetoric are the subjects of deliberation, and no one deliberates about anything which is beyond the sphere of his influence.
pro\ e)/rgou] Note on c. 1 § 10 p. 17.
a)lla\ dh=lon o(/ti] (to\ sumbouleu/ein e)sti\) peri\ o(/swn k.t.l.

The following passage, §§ 4—6, descriptive of the rhetorical method and its necessary limitations, and the distinction between it and the method of scientific demonstration, one of the most important in the entire work, will be found almost literally translated in the Introduction, pp. 173—4, to which the reader is referred.

a)kribw=s diariqmh/sasqai] ‘to make an exact numerical division’, or ‘to enumerate in an exact division or analysis’. Plat. Phaed. 273 E, Crat. 437 D, Gorg. 501 A, Legg. I 633 A, et alibi. It is used in a general sense of ‘accurate distinction’.

dialabei=n] ‘to part, separate, divide, distinguish’, is also familiar to Plato, Polit. 147 E, to
 a)riqmo
 pa/nta di/xa diela/bomen, Symp. 222 E, i(/na xwri\s h(ma=s diala/bh|, Phileb. 23 C, pa/nta ta\ nu=n o)/nta...dixh=| diala/bwmen, and numerous examples in Ast's Index, s. v.; and still more so diairei=n in the same sense, and diai/resis, Sophist. 225 A, diairei=n au)th
 di/xa, Polit. 262 D, kat' ei)/dh du/o diairei=n, ib. 283 D, die/lwmen au)th
 du/o me/rh, Phaedr. 273 E, kat' ei)/dh diairei=sqai ta\ o)/nta. dialabei=n ei)s ei)/dh, ‘to classify by genera and species’. Similarly diori/zein.

peri\ w(=n ei)w/qasi xrhmati/zein] ‘the subjects of ordinary business, i. e. deliberation (in the assembly)’. xrhmati/zein, which is properly to ‘transact xrh/mata or business’ in general, is here ‘transferred’ by metaphor (of the class a)po\ ge/nous e)pi\ ei)dos, Poet. XXI 7), to the special signification of the particular kind of business which is transacted in the general assembly, its debates and consultations; so Pol. VI (IV), 14, 1298 b 29, kai\ peri\ tou/twn xrhmati/zein (of a general assembly as opposed to a boulh/ or pro/bouloi) peri\ w(=n a)
 ou(=toi probouleu/swsin. Ib. c. 15, 1299 b 39, e)n tai=s toiau/tais dhmokrati/ais e)n ai(=s o( dh=mos xrhmati/zei peri\ pa/ntwn (holds its assemblies and discusses everything). Also to the consultations of the law-courts,
Demosth. c. Timocr. p. 717, 26, peri\ w(=n a)
 gnw=| to\ dikasth/rion, pa/lin xrhmati/zein: and again, v. 28, to the deliberations of the assembly. Æschin. c. Timarch. § 23, of the pro/edroi. Lastly, Demosth. de F. L. p. 430, 24, § 317, applies it to the intrigues of individuals, ou(=toi d' ou)de
 e)pau/santo i)di/a| xrhmati/zontes.

kata\ th
 a)lh/qeian...e)mfroneste/ras kai\ ma=llon a)lhqinh=s] of the scientific method which has ‘certainty’ or necessary truth for its aim and object, as opposed to the popular method of Dialectics and Rhetoric, which has no higher aim than probable opinion, pro\s do/can. Top. A 14, 105 b 30, pro\s me
 ou)=n filosofi/an (true philosophy, science) kat' a)lh/qeian peri\ au)tw=n pragmateute/on, dialektikw=s de\ pro\s do/can. See references in Introd. p. 173, note 1. Add, Anal. Post. I 33, 88 b 30, to\ d' e)pisthto
 kai\ e)pisth/mh diafe/rei tou= docastou= kai\ do/chs, o(/ti h( me
 e)pisth/mh kaqo/lou kai\ di) a)nagkai/wn, to\ d) a)nagkai=on ou)k e)nde/xetai a)/llws e)/xein k.t.l. Eth. Nic. III 4, 1112 a 8, doca/zomen a(\ ou) pa/nu i)/smen. On do/ca in general, see Waitz Comm. ad Org. p. 444. On e)mfroneste/ras, ‘more intelligent, wiser, more instructive’, see above, note on c. 2 § 21 p. 50.

dia\ to\ mh/te...pollw=| de/...] Wolf and MS A^{c} have pollw=| te, which is of course the more regular and strictly grammatical usage. On the general question of the meaning and distinctions of kai/, de/, and te, with and without the negative, see Hermann's excellent dissertation in his Review of Elmsley's Medea, on lines 4, 5. Porson, Elmsley, and their English followers were in the habit of laying down rigorous and inflexible rules of Greek grammar, which were supposed to admit of no exception; any apparent violation of them was to be summarily emended: one of the great services rendered by Hermann to the study of the Greek language is the relaxation of these over exact rules, and the substitution of a rational and logical explanation of these differences of expression, and the analysis of their distinctions, for these often unwarranted alterations of the text. ‘*kai\ particula est coniunctiva’, says Hermann; ‘te adiunctiva; de/ disiunctiva’. In the case of ou)de/ and mhde/, ou)/te and mh/te, when several things are subordinated to, and included under, one negative conception, the one or the other (de/ or te) is used according as the writer had or had not any notion of a difference between them. If the things under the general negative conception are represented merely as subordinate and with no expression of difference of opposition between them, the adnexive te is employed, and the formula is ou)...te...te, or ou)...ou)/te...ou)/te, and similarly with mh/: on the other hand, if some difference between any of the subordinate members of the division is to be marked, te must be replaced by de/, and the formula will be ou)...ou)de/, or ou)de/...ou)de/, or ou)... ou)/te...ou)/te...ou)de/, and so on for other similar cases. And the change of te into de/ in the second clause of the sentence before us, represents the sudden occurrence to the writer's mind of the thought that there is an important difference between the two things that are assigned as reasons for not introducing a regular scientific division into the treatment of Rhetoric (viz. its necessarily unscientific character, and the fact that its
province has already been unduly extended by previous professors), which requires to be marked, and accordingly is marked by the change of the particle. This, however, is not the only irregularity in Aristotle's sentence; for, evidently intending at the commencement to include both the subordinate members under the original negative, he introduces in the second clause a positive conception; contributing perhaps to enforce the distinction of the two, but in violation of grammatical accuracy.

plei/w dedo/sqai...tw=n oi)kei/wn qewrhma/twn] ‘far more has been already assigned to it than its own proper subjects of inquiry’, refers doubtless to the sophistical professors of Rhetoric, his predecessors and contemporaries; who u(podu/ontai u(po\ to\ sxh=ma th=s politikh=s, and lay claim to the whole extent of the field of Politics, Rhet. I 2, 7. What this assumption of the Sophists implies is explained in Eth. Nic. X 10, 1181 a 1, ta\ de\ politika\ e)pagge/llontai me
 dida/skein oi( sofistai/, pra/ttei d' au)tw=n ou)dei/s, a)ll) oi( politeuo/menoi k.t.l., infr. v. 13, tw=n de\ sofistw=n oi( e)paggello/menoi li/an fai/nontai po/rrw ei)=nai tou= dida/cai: o(/lws ga ou)de\ poi=o/n ti e)sti
