th=s a)nalutikh=s e)pisth/mhs] See note on c. 1 § 11, p. 19, h( de\ pi/stis a)po/deici/s e)sti.

a)nalutikw=s, opposed to logikw=s (which is equivalent to dialektikw=s, Waitz on Anal. Post. 82 b 35, p. 353, Poste, u. s., p. 19), properly implies scientific demonstration; and ‘analytical’ reasoning follows that method: see Anal. Post. I 22, 84 a 7 seq. It is there said to be exercised e)n tai=s a)podeiktikai=s e)pisth/mais...h( me\n ga\r a)po/deici/s e)sti tw=n o(/sa u(pa/rxei kaq' au(ta\ toi=s pra/gmasin. On ‘Analytics’ comp. Trendel. El. Log. Arist. p. 47 sq. Waitz Comm. ad Anal. Pr. p. 366, 7. When Dialectics is here called an ‘analytical’ science, either ‘analytical’ stands for ‘logical’ in general (which is Mr Poste's view, l. c.), or else it represents and includes methodical systematic reasoning of all kinds, which proceeds by way of ‘analysis’, ‘resolving’ the objects of knowledge into their ultimate elements, to discover their causes (Trendelenburg, l. c.); and the latter is the explanation that I should prefer.

th=s peri\ ta\ h)/qh politikh=s] Ethics being a department or branch of the more general and comprehensive science of Politics, Eth. Nic. I 1, 1094 b 11, h( me\n ou)=n me/qodos (h( h)qikh/) tou/twn e)fi/etai, politikh/ tis ou)=sa: the end of both being the same, viz. human good, v. 6. Ib. I 10, 1029 b 29, and c. 13, init. Ib. X 10, 1180 b 31, mo/rion ga\r e)do/kei th=s politikh=s ei)=nai. So that the two together make up the ‘philosophy of humanity’, of man as an individual and in society, h( peri\ ta)nqrw/pina filosofi/a, X 10, 1181 b 16.
kaqa/per a)/n] On kaqa/per a)\n (kataskeua/zoi), see above, note on I 1, 5 p. 9.
duna/meis] sc. tou= pori/sai lo/gous, I 2, 7. On Rhetoric as a practical faculty, see Introd. pp. 14—19.

It may be as well here to sum up the characteristics of Rhetoric which respectively entitle it to the name of ‘art’ and ‘faculty’. In so far as it is systematic, and follows a method—a logical method—and can look forward to results (implying a knowledge of causes and effects) in persuading its hearers, it is an art; as a practical exercise, not admitting of absolute exactness, or universal conclusions, employing the propositions of all arts and sciences, and the axioms common to them all, only as probable and popular, and having itself no special subject-matter, taking opposite sides of the same question indifferently and arriving at opposite conclusions (so Alexander Aphrodisiensis), it is a du/namis, a faculty, capable of development and to be exercised in practice.

metabai/nein] See on I 2, 20. Vater (who seems to have misunderstood the passage), without reason or authority, would omit the words tw=| metabai/nein, as not properly applicable to the context a)lla\ mh\ mo/non lo/gwn. And his view is so far supported by the Paraphrast, who also rejects them. Brandis, u. s. p. 46. No one but himself, however, would prefer to connect ei)s e)pisth/mas with e)piskeua/zwn rather than metabai/nein—a much more natural construction, though this often is certainly admissible—and secondly, the two words, though not absolutely necessary to the sense, are at least in perfect accordance with it when the passage is properly interpreted. ‘In proportion as...he will be unconsciously, unintentionally, effacing their real nature by passing over, in his attempt to reconstruct them (alter their formation or system), into sciences of definite special subjects, instead of those (e)pisth/mas) which deal with mere words’, i.e. instead of confining himself to these latter. This is in fact a case of that very common violation of an ordinary grammatical rule which is called the ‘figure’, zeu=gmaOf this so-called ‘figure’, zeu=gma, the illicit conjunction of the two heterogeneous notions or expressions under one vinculum, there are in fact two varieties, explained and abundantly illustrated from the works of Tacitus by Bötticher in his Lex. Tacit., Proleg. de Stili Taciti brevitate, p. LXXVIII sq., su/llhyis and zeu=gma proper. The figure in general is thus described, ‘qua aut genere aut personis aut alio quo modo diversa uno eodemque constructionis genere comprehenduntur’; but as I have failed to enter into the distinction which Bötticher makes between the two varieties I will substitute my own explanation of the difference. In su/llhyis the two terms are united in one construction with a third, to which one is referred literally, the other metaphorically, or at all events in different senses. This appears in the instances given, as dissimulationem nox et lascivia exemerat: nocte ac laetitia incaluisse: praeda famaque onusti: mixti copiis et laetitia. To these I will venture to add from a modern English writer the case of Miss Bolo in Pickwick, who after her defeat at whist in the Bath Assembly Rooms retires ‘in a flood of tears and a sedan chair’; to which Eur. Hel. 182, au)gai=sin e)n tai=s xruse/ais e)/n te do/nakos e)/rnesin, is an exact parallel. In zeu=gma proper, this third term will not apply in any sense to both of the others, and some other word or phrase must necessarily be supplied to complete the sense; as in the passage of Herodotus quoted above, and in the text of Aristotle. Add to the examples collected from Tacitus by Bötticher, Hor. Od. III 4. 11, ludo fatigatumque somno. Liv. XXVII 46 sub fin. fessi somno ac vigiliis (fessi vigiliis ac propterea somno graves). Hom. Il. K 98, kama/tw| a)dhko/tes h)de\ kai\ u(/pnw|. Soph. Oed. R. 271, Electr. 72, 435, 6. Eur. Heracl. 312 Elms. ad loc., 839, 1040. Dem. de F. L. § 93, mh\...e)a=te, a)ll' w(s k.t.l. Dorvill. ad Charit. p. 394, seq. and Matth. Gr. Gr. 634, Obs. 3, supply examples. Ernesti, in Lex. Techn. Gr. s. v., thus defines zeu=gma: in qua figura unum ad verbum plures sententiae referuntur, quarum unaquaeque desideraret illud, si sola poneretur. This use of the figure he has not illustrated. It seems to represent something quite different from the other; but what? The zeu=gma in fact is a kind of grammatical bracket, under which two heterogeneous expressions are improperly included. Another well-known example of this figure is the truly Irish epitaph on Boyle the Philosopher: ‘He was the father of Chemistry, and grand-uncle of the Earl of Cork.’ (a mere carelessness of expression dignified by
that name), ‘a figure of speech’, as it is briefly expressed in Liddell and Scott's Lexicon, ‘wherein two subjects are used jointly with the same predicate, which strictly belongs only to one, as in Il. A 533, where e)/bh must be supplied with *zeu/s.’ So Herod. I 90, xrhsta\ e)/rga kai\ e)/pea poie/ein, where of course le/gein is required with e)/pea. Under this head comes the case before us, where to complete the intended sense we must supply a)lla\ mh\ mo/non (not tw=| metabai/nein, but tw=| e)piskeua/zein e)pisth/mas) lo/gwn.

e)piskeua/zein, ‘to re-construct or re-constitute’, is opposed to kataskeua/zein. The latter is ‘to lay down (kata/), settle or establish a system’; the former, ‘to construct anew or afresh, to renew’. e)pi/, from the primary sense of direction to, in place, passes into a secondary one of direction or succession in time, ‘after’; hence, thirdly, it takes the meaning of repetition, as anew, afresh, re- (in comp.), and of development in the way of growth, as in e)pidido/nai ‘to augment or grow’. Hence e)piskeua/zein is properly to ‘refit’, ‘renew’, ‘repair’, ‘restore’, as walls, ships, bridges, roads (Thucyd., Xenoph., Demosth., see the Lexx.), and thence transferred to ‘reconstruction’ of a science or study. A similar sense of e)pi/ appears in the verbs, e)peipei=n ‘to say after, or add the words’, e)pagei/rein ‘to collect after or in addition’, e)pimanqa/nein, e)pakolouqei=n, e)panqei=n, e)pibiou=n (to live after, outlive), e)panaqea=sqai (Xen. Cyr. V. 4, 11, to look at repeatedly, over and over again), e)panaxwrei=n ibid., e)panie/nai, e)pane/rxesqai, e)panorqou=n. Rost. u. Palm, Lex. Art. e)pi/, p. 1046 a.

o(/sapro\ e)/rgou me/n e)sti dielei=n, e)/ti d' u(polei/pei ske/yin] Another case of grammatical irregularity and of the ‘figure’ zeu=gma. o(/sa in the first clause is the accus. after dielei=n: in the second it must be repeated, as the nomin. to u(polei/pei.—On pro\ e)/rgou, see supr. c. I § 10 p. 17.

sxedo\n ga/r, peri\ w(=n bouleu/ontai pa/ntes k.t.l.] The unaccountable difference between the list here given of the principal subjects of Politics with which the deliberative or public speaker will have to deal, viz. (1) po/roi, supplies, ways and means, revenue, finance; (2) war and peace (possibly including alliances); (3) the defence of the country; (4) exports and imports (commerce, trade); and (5) legislation; with that which is found in Polit. VI<*>IV), 4, has been already pointed out in the Introd. p. 176. In the corresponding chapter of the Rhet. ad Alex. 2 (3 Oxf.) § 2, we have seven such subjects enumerated: religion, peri\ i(erw=n; legislation, peri\ no/mwn, (no/mwn sumfero/ntwn qe/seis, Dem. de Cor. § 309, in a parallel passage); the constitution of the state (peri\ th=s politikh=s kataskeuh=s); alliances and commercial treaties (sumbolai/wn) with foreign nations; war; peace; and revenue (peri\ po/rou xrhma/twn).

In Xenophon, Memor. III 6, a conversation is reported between Socrates and Glaucon, whom the former cross-examines on the subject of his political knowledge, with the view of shewing him that he is not yet ripe for a statesman. The principal objects of a statesman's care there enumerated are, the pro/sodoi, Aristotle's po/roi, the revenue: the state expenses, with the view of reducing them, ta\ a)nalw/mata: war, and the means of carrying it on: the enemy's forces, naval and military, and your own: the defence of the country, h( fulakh\ th=s xw/ras: mines, and the supply of silver (this is from the Athenian point of view): and the supply of corn and other food. These details, and in the same order, are all, with the exception of the mines in Aristotle, and the legislation in Xenophon, enumerated by Aristotle in the following sections, 8—11, so that Gaisford may possibly be right in his suspicion, ‘respexit fortasse Aristoteles Xenophontis Mem. III 6.’
a)faireqh=|] ‘it may be reduced, curtailed, retrenched’.

pro\s ta\ u(pa/rxonta prostiqe/ntes k.t.l.] Not of course = pro\s toi=s u(pa/r-
xousin, ‘by adding to present resources’, but ‘with reference to them’, as pro\s tou=to sumparalamba/nei, and sumparalamba/nousi pro\s tau=ta, supr. c. 3, § 5. ‘For not only in respect of their existing resources do they become wealthier by adding to them (prostiqe/ntes au)toi=s)’.

e)k th=s peri\ ta\ i)/dia e)mpeiri/as] ‘from one's own personal experience’. ta\ i)/dia are the facts which have come under one's own personal observation, i. e. the resources of our own country, and the system followed and methods adopted in providing, maintaining, and augmenting them, at home; not these alone are to be ‘inquired into’, i(storiko\n ei)=nai, by the statesman and public speaker, but also the ‘inventions’, the practices and policy of other nations in regard of these same matters.
sunora=n] ‘to take a comprehensive view’, ‘to look at together’, for the purpose of comparison. See note on suva/gein, c. 2 § 13 p. 41.

i(storiko/n] The termination -ikos corresponds to the English -ive, and denotes a capacity for, or tendency to. poihtiko/s productive, ai)sqhtiko/s sensitive, dektiko/s receptive, praktiko/s active, eu(retiko/s inventive, a)podeiktiko/s demonstrative, and so on: though in some cases there is no corresponding English word actually in use. According to this analogy i(storiko/s is ‘inquisitive’, qualified and disposed to inquire into things in general.

When Herodotus at the opening of his work uses the term i(stori/h, he means no more than the ‘inquiries’ or ‘researches’ which he is now collecting into a continuous narrative. (Comp. § 13, ai( peri\ ta\s pra/ceis istori/ai and the note there.) It is not till we come to Polybius that the word assumes its modern signification, a scientific history, a systematic work that can be employed in education, Hist. I 1, 2. It is now defined, and distinguished from other departments of study by the addition of pragmatikh/, I 2, 8, the study of human actions and affairs. Its scientific character, which entitles it to the epithet ‘demonstrative’, i(stori/a a)podeiktikh/, II 37, 3, a)pod. dih/ghsis, IV 40, 1, is derived from its method of tracing causes and motives of actions: i(stori/as ga e)a
 a)fe/lh| tis to\ dia\ ti/, kai\ pw=s, kai\ ti/nos xa/rin e)pra/xqh, kai\ to\ praxqe
 po/tera eu)/logon e)/sxe to\ te/los, to\ kataleipo/menon au)th=s a)gw/nisma me
 ma/qhma de\ ou) gi/gnetai: kai\ parauti/ka me
 te/rpei, pro\s de\ to\ me/llon ou)de
 w)felei= to\ para/pan.

But it is only the term, not the thing, that is new in Polybius' time. Thucydides' History, though not so called, (Thucydides is called a cuggrafeu/s, see Poppo on 1, 1, 2,) is at least as scientific in all essential points as that of Polybius, or indeed any other.
On the distinction of lo/gios, logopoio/s, and i(storiko/s, see some good observations in Dahlmann's Life of Herod. c. 6 § 2.
u(pa/rcai, a)rkei=n, Anonymus, ap. Brandis, u. s., p. 44.

The verbs u(pa/rxein, ei)=nai, gi/gnesqai, stand to one another in the relation of past, present, and future; to be already in existence, to be (simple and absolute being, independent of time), and to become, to come into being from a state (if that be possible) of non-being. The aorist infin, gives u(pa/rcai here a future sense, ‘to become or to be made’, which does not naturally, ex vi verbi, belong to it. Hermann, in one of those notes which have thrown so much light upon the niceties of Greek grammar (on Ajax 1061 subsequently referred to without further discussion in the treatise de Part. a)/n IV, 2, Opuscula, Vol. IV), contends against Elmsley (who had condemned as a solecism this use of the aorist infin. without a)/n, after verbs such as dokei=n, nomi/zein, oi)/esqai, fa/nai, e)lpi/zein, prosdoka=n, in reference to future time) in support of the usage; and distinguishes three modes of expression in which futurity is conveyed by the infinitive: first, the simple future inf. as dokei=n pesei=sqai, which conveys directly the simple and absolute notion of futurity, without modification or qualification; second, the infin., aorist or present, with a)/n, pi/ptein a)/n, pesei=n a)/n, which indicates a merely conditional futurity, might or would fall, under certain circumstances or conditions; and thirdly, the present or aorist infin. without a)/n, pi/ptein, or pesei=n, which, corresponding to the indefinite (in point of time) present and aorist, pi/ptei and e)/pese, denote simply the possibility or likelihood of the object falling at some uncertain future time; caducum esse. The distinction between the present and aorist infinitive is this: ‘Praesentis autem et aoristi infinitivis, sive accedat a)/n sive non, ita utuntur, ut aoristus rei transeunti, praesens duranti adhibeatur.’

Without disputing the truth of this, it is yet possible to explain the difference otherwise. Permanence (‘duranti’) does not seem to me to be in any way connected with the conception of present time, though the perfect often is; as when we say ‘this has been’ up to the present time, we often imply our belief in its continuance; and I should rather explain the present infin. in these cases as expressing the mere fact of the existence of the thing named, or the abstract notion of it. The present tense, as it is called, I act, I do, to act, to do, is in reality independent of time: the time present is, I am acting, I am doing; and the present infin. ‘to do’ is the naked conception of ‘doing’ without any connotation of time (so the present infinit. with the definite article stands for a substantive; to\ ei)=nai is the mere notion of being). The aorist infin. again may derive its notion of futurity and likelihood, either, as Hermann thinks, from the indefiniteness expressed by the tense, or, in other cases, from the connotation of habit, implying liability, which is also one of its acquired senses. The broad distinction will be, dokw= pesei=sqai, ‘I think it will fall’, at some future time, and nothing more: dokw= pi/ptein or pesei=n a)/n, ‘I think it could, would, or might fall’, under certain conditions; dokw= pi/ptein, ‘I think the notion of falling belongs to it’, ‘I think it may fall’; that is, that it is liable, or likely, to fall, caducum esse: and dokw= pesei=n, implying also the liability or likelihood of the preceding, is distinguished from it (according to Hermann) by
representing the act or event as transient and not permanent. But such a distinction as this last, though it be intelligible, is at least untranslatable; as in such a case as noei=s dra=sai (Soph. Phil. 918), ‘what dost thou intend to do’, where the expression of the liability must needs be omitted, and still more the transient nature of the proposed act. But we can hardly suppose that any distinction can be seriously intended when Sophocles writes noei=s dra=sai: and then, three lines afterwards, v. 921, dra=|n noei=s. The choice between the two seems to be dictated rather by convenience than by any other motive.

With regard to the distinction of the present and aorist infin., it may be observed, that we are often obliged, as the practice of translation shews, to disregard whatever difference there may be conceived to be between them, as either inappreciable or at all events inexpressible, and to render them by the same English words. Take, for example, the ordinary phrase dei= labei=n (it occurs, for instance, II 8, 12). It is quite certain that in this case past time is not directly signified; though it may possibly be included as an accessory in the notion of it in the way of an addition to the abstract conception of ‘taking up, acquiring’—as representing the previous formation of the opinion, which has been taken up before. But at all events no one would think of translating dei= labei=n in any other form than that of the simple verb ‘to assume or suppose’.
h(/ tis e)nde/xetai] e)nde/xesqai is here used, as is customary with other writers, as a personal verb; Aristotle generally employs it as an impersonal. Comp. note on c. 2, 14.

h)\ kai\ ou(\s e)pi/docon] ‘or indeed of those with whom war may be expected’. Supply for the sense, h)\ kai\ (dei= ei)de/nai th\n du/namin tou/twn) pro\s ou(\s e)pi/docon (h(mi=n or h(ma=s) polemei=n. e)pi/docos, ‘subject to, liable to expectation’, e)pi/ penes, note on I 1, 7, e)pi\ toi=s kri/nousi. Similarly e)pi/dikos, subject to a di/kh, e)pizh/mios infr. I 14, 7, II 23, 21, e)pai/tios liable to blame, e)pa/cios, e)piki/ndunos, e)piqa/natos (Demosth.), e)pi/klhros, e)pisfale/s (liable to trip) Pol. II 5, e)pi/maxos, e)pi/batos, e)pi/dromos. This notion is more directly expressed by u(po/ in composition, u(po/dikos, u(peu/qunos, &c.

ei)rhneu/htai] ei)rhneu/ein, though used as a neuter in Plat. Theaet. 180 B, and in other authors, is properly transitive, ‘to bring into a state of peace, pacificate, or reconcile’ contending parties, and hence employed here as a passive.
e)p' au)toi=s] Note on I 1, 7 p. 10; and on I 1, 12 p. 22, di) au)tw=n: 1 7, 35, tw=| au)tw=| kai\ a(plw=s, and note there.

kai\ ta\s duna/meis] (tw=n o(mo/rwn a)nagkai=on ei)de/nai) po/teron o(/moiai h)\ a)no/-
moiai (ei)si tai=s oi)kei/ais). This rule is well illustrated by Archidamus' comparative estimate of the Athenian and Lacedaemonian forces preparatory to engaging in the war, Thuc. I 80, 3.

pleonektei=n h)\ e)lattou=sqai] properly contrasted. ple/on h)\ e)/latton e)/xein, ‘to have too much or too little’, ‘more or less than your due’. So in Thucyd. I 77, e)lassou=sqai and pleonektei=sqai (the irregular passive of pleonektei=n) represent the same notion, ‘to come by the worse, or to be overreached’. And so here, ‘for in this point also we may be at an advantage or disadvantage’.
a)po\ ga\r tw=n o(moi/wn k.t.l.] ‘for similar circumstances are naturally followed by, or naturally give rise to, similar results’.
i(/n' ei)/t) e)la/ttwn] (e)sti\n h( fulakh\), h( ful. prosteqh=|, or perhaps rather, ei)/t' e)lla/ttwn (e)sti\n) h( fulakh\, (au(/th) prosteqh=|.

peri/ergos] is properly said of one ‘who troubles himself over much’ (peri/), either about his own affairs, or those of others; (these two significations will be found illustrated in the Lexicons). Hence it acquires the general sense of ‘superfluity’, as here. Comp. Plat. Polit. 286 C, peri/erga le/gein, and Apol. 19 B, *swkra/th...perierga/zetai zhtw=n ta/ te u(po\ gh=s kai\ ta\ e)poura/nia (of an idle curiosity). Dem.? Phil. d) 150, 24, e)c w(=n e)rga/zh| kai\ perierga/zh| tou\s e)sxa/tous o)/ntas kindu/nous. Ib. 143, 17, peri/ergon kai\ ma/taion a)na/lwma, and elsewhere in Dem. and the other orators. Arist. Eccles. 220, ei) mh/ ti kaino\n a)/llo perieirga/zeto. See also in Ind. ad Fragm. Com. Graec. Meineke, Vol. v. Pt. 2.

kai\ tou\s e)pithdei/ous to/pous thrw=si ma=llon] Translate the whole passage, ‘in order that whether the defence (defensive preparation) be too little, addition be made to it, or if superfluous, it be retrenched, and their attention be rather directed to the watching or guarding (fortification) of favourable positions’. e)pithdei/ous to/pous are places favourable, defensible, suitable to the purpose for which they were intended, viz. for protecting the country. Thuc. II 20, o( xw=ros e)pith/deios e)fai/neto e)nstratopedeu=sai: Herod. IX 2, xw=ros e)pithdew/teros e)nstratopedeu/esqai: VI 102, e)pithdew/taton xw/rion e)nippeu=sai, always apparently of a ‘favourable’ position, and this seems to be here the natural, as it is the usual, sense of e)pith/deios and of the passage in general. And so Victorius, ‘et ut relictis parum opportunis
locis magis idoneos tueantur.’ (There is another possible—but I think not probable—interpretation of e)pithdei/ous to/pous, viz. loca commoda or opportuna, suitable or convenient to the enemy, easy of access, readily assailable: threi=n, as before, being to guard or defend.)
pro\s tou/tous] i. e. par' oi(=s e)stin w(=n de/ontai: those that are capable of providing them with that they want.
sunqh=kai kai\ sumbolai/] On sumbo/laia and sunalla/gmata see above, note on I 1, 10 p. 16.

sunqh/kh is a general term for a treaty, compact, contract, convention, usually of a public nature, between two states, but also all private contracts, covenants, and bargains; see Rhet. I 15, 20—23, peri\ sunqhkw=n. su/mbola—here called sumbolai/, apparently a a(/pac lego/menon in this sense; in Pol. III 9, 1280 a 38, sunqh=kai and su/mbola are contrasted—are technically confined by the grammarians to a particular and special kind of contract, international commercial treaties. Meier ü. Schömann, Att. Process, p. 494, note 49. In the passage referred to, su/mbola first occurs apparently in its proper sense, pa/ntes oi(=s e)/sti su/mbola pro\s a)llh/lous: and then, as distinguished from sunqh=kai, which here stand for commercial treaties in general, sunqhkai peri\ tw=n ei)sagwgi/mwn, seems to be applied to those special and subordinate articles of commercial contracts which made provisions against the infliction of mutual damage and wrong, or established a system of compensation which protected the contracting parties against mutual injury, su/mbola peri\ tou= mh\ a)dikei=n. In the usual sense, Pol. III 1, 1275 a 9, tou=to ga\r u(pa/rxei kai\ toi=s a)po\ sumbo/lwn koinwnou=sin, ‘even the members of different states who are connected by international commercial treaties have reciprocal legal rights, so that it cannot be this which constitutes a citizen’. In Thuc. I 77, the cumbo/laiai pro\s tou\s cumma/xous di/kai denote the actions at law which arise out of these cu/mbola. Dem. c. Mid. 570, ta\ su/mbola sugxe/wn. See Buttm.'s Ind., s. v.

pro\s du/o ga\r diafula/ttein k.t.l.] ‘for there are two classes of persons between whom and the citizens it is necessary that irreproachable conduct or behaviour, or a thoroughly good understanding, should be steadily, persistently (dia/, thoroughly, throughout), maintained’.
peri\ nomoqesi/as e)pai+/ein] ‘to understand the subject of legislation’.

In this section occur several points in common between the Rhetoric
and Politics, which, though they may not be direct references from one to the other, yet serve to illustrate the relation between them. They are noticed by Brandis, in Schneidewin's Philologus, u. s. p. 33. I will compare them in the order in which they stand.

e)n ga\r toi=s no/mois e)sti\n h( swthri/a th=s po/lews] On legislation comp. I 1, 7. That the laws ought to be supreme in a state, and not any one or several, or the entire body of citizens, is argued and concluded in Polit. III 15, 1286 a 7 seq. and again c. 16, 1287 a 18, to\n a)/ra no/mon a)/rxein ai(retw/teron ma=llon h)\ tw=n politw=n e(/na tina/ k.t.l. The different forms of constitutions, and what is salutary and conservative or destructive of each of them, are treated, for instance, in Pol. III 6, and VIII (V) 1 et seq. And not only is the substance of the next sentence, le/gw de\ to\ u(po\ oi)kei/wn fqei/resqai k.t.l., found in the discussions of the Politics VIII (V) 1, but the very same metaphor, from the tightening and relaxation of the strings of the lyre, is employed there, 1301 b 17, as here; and in c. 9, 1309 b 18, the same illustration, derived from the flat and aquiline nose, is used to represent the excessive exaggeration and intensification, or depression and relaxation of the constitution, as of the feature, which altogether effaces its true character.

a)nie/menai kai\ e)piteino/menai] This metaphor from the screwing up or relaxation of the strings of the lyre, producing a difference of musical pitch or tone, which it raises or lowers, is a very favourite one both with Plato and Aristotle, and is used to represent, as I have already said, exaggeration or intensification on the one hand, (exactly as we speak of ‘screwing up our courage’ Macbeth I 7, 60), and depression or relaxation on the other. If for example the nose is lowered or depressed to excess in the way of flatness as a snub-nose, or exaggerated in the other direction to excessive sharpness and prominence as an aquiline nose, it ends by losing the character of a nose altogether, and is either altogether effaced or becomes a beak: and so with the constitutions of states.

to\ u(po\ oi)kei/wn fqei/resqai therefore means that forms of government are destroyed or change their character by the exaggeration or relaxation of their own proper and peculiar institutions, and it is in the ‘mean’ state alone between these two excesses that the constitution can be said to maintain its true character. For instance the o(/ros, definition or principle, of a democracy is equality; if this be intensified or exaggerated, or carried to excess, if the thing be logically carried out, and everybody actually becomes equal, the government degenerates into mob-rule or anarchy and thus loses its true democratic character; if it be relaxed and the equality diminished, the democratic principle and its institutions become
so enfeebled, that the inequalities increase until at last it becomes an oligarchy, a)nieme/nh a)sqeneste/ra gi/netai w(/ste te/los h(/cei ei)s o)ligarxi/an.

 de\ e)llei/ph| a)nie/ntas, ib. c. 9, 1309 b 18, u. s., VII (VI) 6, 1320 b 30, VI (IV) 6, 1293 a 26 and 30 u(pertei/nein, Eth. Nic. VI 1, 1138 b 23, e)/sti tis skopo\s pro\s o(
 a)poble/pwn o( to
 lo/gon e)/xwn e)pitei/nei kai\ a)ni/hsin. In Pol. V (VIII) 7 1341 b ult., he says of music as a ‘relaxation’ pro\s diagwgh/n, that it is pro\s a)/nesi/n te kai\ pro\s th
 th=s suntoni/as (overstraining or exertion) a)na/pausin. Comp. Pol. VI (IV) 3, ult. a(rmoni/as suntonwte/ras and a)neime/nas; whence e)/ntonos (intense), su/ntonos, a)neime/nos, a)neime/nws, are applied, the two first to braced nerves, vigorous exertion or character; the latter to relaxation or dissoluteness of life and manners, or to slackness, laxity, and effeminacy. In Pol. IV (VII) 17, 1336 a 30, it is said that children's sports should be neither e)pipo/nous nor a)neime/nas; and c. 4, 1326 a 26, that no well-constituted state should be a)neime/nhn, uncontrolled, slack, loose, relaxed, i. e. allowed to run to excess, in its numbers. Eth. Nic. II 4 sub. init. o)rgisqh=nai sfodrw=s h)\ a)neime/nws, ib. III 7, 1114 a 5, a)neime/nws zh=n, open, easy, careless, dissolute life. Comp. Thuc. I 6, II 39 a)neime/nh| th=| diai/th|, a)neime/nws diaitw/menoi. The corresponding Latin terms are intendere and remittere, Cic. Orat. § 59, Quint. X 3, 24, doubtless borrowed from the Greek.
ou(/tw diati/qetai w(/ste k.t.l.] ‘it assumes such a condition or shape that it seems to be no nose at all’.
e)k tw=n parelhluqo/twn qewrou=nti] ‘by studying out of’, i. e. ‘drawing conclusions or deriving observations from the study of the past’.

a)lla\ kai\ ta\s para\ toi=s a)/llois k.t.l.] Aristotle had already probably, when this was written, supplied the deliberative orators of his time with the means of acquainting themselves with this branch of political study, by his work called *politei=ai, a collection of the constitutions
of 158 states existing at that period, and serving apparently as an appendix to the extant Politics. It is included in the lists both of Diogenes, V 27, and of the Anonymus in Buhle, Arist. Vol. I p. 65. Diogenes' title, which is more descriptive than the other, runs thus: *politei=ai po/lewn duoi=n deou/sain e(ch/konta kai\ e(kato\n, kai\ i)di/a| dhmokratikai/, o)ligarxikai/, a)ristokratikai/, kai\ turannikai/. The extant fragments of this work are collected in Rose's Arist. Pseudepigraphus, Pt. 2, p. 391—537 (this collection is much more complete than that of Neumann, which is printed in the Oxf. ed. of Bekker's text, Vol. X p. 234, as an appendix to the Politics). The latest results of the researches on this subject are given by Heitz, Verlor. Schrift. Arist. p. 230, seq.

ai( th=s gh=s peri/odoi] ‘Travels round the world’, ‘survey of the earth’. These were books of Geography physical and descriptive, containing not only an account of the relative position of cities and countries, but also observations upon the manners and customs of the inhabitants. Hence they are recommended to the study of the Politician. These were founded either upon personal observation, or upon the reports of travellers; whence the name peri/odoi. Ar. Meteor. I 13, 13, dh=lon d' e)sti\ tou=to qewme/nois ta\s th=s gh=s perio/dous: tau/tas ga\r e)k tou= punqa/nesqai par) e(ka/stwn ou(/tws a)ne/grayan, o(/swn mh\ sumbe/bhken au)to/ptas gene/sqai tou\s le/gontas (quoted by Victorius). For a similar reason books of the same kind were called peri/ploi, ‘circumnavigations or nautical surveys’, as those of Scylax, Hanno, &c. or perihgh/seis. (*dionu/sios o( perihghth/s. *dio/dwros o( perihghth/s, Athen. XIII 591 E. *pole/mwn o( perihg., ib. IX 372 A, XXI 552 B.) One of the earliest and best known of them was that of Hecataeus, referred to by Herodotus, IV 36 gelw= de\ o(re/wn *gh=s perio/dous gra/yantas pollou\s h)/dh...oi( *)wkeano/n te r(eo/nta gra/fousi pe/ric th\n gh=n e)ou=san kuklotere/a w(s a)po\ to/rnou, kai\ th\n *)asi/hn th=| *eu)rw/ph| poieu=ntas i)/shn. In V 49 the term is applied to Aristagoras of Miletus' famous map, (by Strabo assigned to Anaximander), pi/naka e)n tw=| gh=s a(pa/shs peri/odos e)nete/tmhto, kai\ qa/lassa/ te pa=sa, kai\ potamoi\ pa/ntes. From the hints in Herod. IV. 36, Ar. Meteor. II 5, dio\ kai\ geloi/ws gra/fousi nu=n ta\s perio/dous th=s gh=s: k.t.l. (where the author proceeds to say, following Herodotus, that the circular shape of the earth assigned to it by these writers is impossible), and from Pol. II 3, 1262 a 12, sub fin., the general nature of the contents of these works may be gathered. Eudoxus, the mathematician and astronomer, of Cnidos, was the author of one of these works, referred to by Athen. VII 288 C, e)n e(/ktw| gh=s peri/odou (Victorius), also Ctesias, Dionysius, Diodorus, Polemo. An account of Hecataeus' peri/odos is given by Mure, Hist. Gk. Lit. IV 144, Bk. IV ch. 3 § 3.

ai( tw=n peri\ ta\s pra/ceis grafo/ntwn i(stori/ai] See note on i(stori/ai, § 7. The addition ‘about men's actions’ is still required to define the kind of ‘inquiries’ in which ‘history’ engages: i(stori/a has not yet become technical, indicating a special department of study.

e)/xein] ‘to be informed or furnished’. ‘The information’ which he must ‘have’ is left to be supplied. Understand ta\s prota/seis, which generally stands in Aristotle for the ‘materials’ of Rhetoric which the speaker must have at his command.

le/gwmen pa/lin] ‘let us go back, begin again, take a fresh start as it were, and proceed to state...’ Compare the end of the first chapter. This form of expression and use of pa/lin are very familiar to Aristotle in commencing a new subject. See, for example, de Anima II 1 init., c. 2 init.

div2.head: The analysis of Happiness.
div2.p: The object of the public or deliberative speaker lies in the future, and is always something attainable; no one deliberates about that which is altogether out of his power. Now happiness or some form or part of it is the universal aim; the complete analysis of happiness, therefore, will include every object of pr/otroph/ and a)potroph/ which he can suggest to his audience, and every kind of political expediency.

div3.p:
Eth. Nic. I 1 init. pa=sa te/xnh kai\ pa=sa me/qodos, o(moi/ws de\ pra=ci/s te kai\ proai/resis, a)gaqou= tino\s e)fi/esqai dokei=: dio\ kalw=s a)pefh/nanto ta)gaqo
, ou(= pa/nt' e)fi/etai. Ib. 1094 b 3, xrwme/nhs de\ tau/ths (th=s politikh=s) tai=s loipai=s praktikai=s tw=n e)pisthmw=n, e)/ti de\ nomoqetou/shs ti/ dei= pra/ttein kai\ ti/nwn a)pe/xesqai, to\ tau/ths te/los perie/xoi a)
 ta\ tw=n a)/llwn, w(/ste tou=t' a)
 ei)/h ta)nqrw/pinon a)gaqo/n. X 6 init. e)peidh\ te/los au)th
 (th
 eu)daimoni/an) ti/qemen tw=n a)nqrwpi/nwn. Polit. I 1 init. e)peidh\ pa=san po/lin koinwni/an tina\ ou)=san kai\ pa=san koinwni/an a)gaqou= tino\s e(/neken sunesthkui=an, tou= ga ei)=nai dokou=ntos a)gaqou= xa/rin pa/nta pra/ttousi pa/ntes, dh=lon w(s pa=sai a)gaqou= tino\s stoxa/zontai. Plat. Symp. 205 A kai\ ou)ke/ti prosdei= e)/resqai i(/na ti\ de\ bou/letai eu)dai/mwn ei)=nai o( boulo/menos, a)lla\ te/los dokei= e)/xein h( a)po/krisis. Phileb. 54 C to/ ge mh
 ou(= e(/neka to\ e(/neka/ tou gigno/menon a)ei\ gi/gnoit' a)/n, e)n th=| tou= a)gaqou= moi/ra| e)kei=no/ e)sti. Gorg. 499 E to\ a)gaqo
 te/los ei)=nai a(pasw=n tw=n pra/cewn, kai\ e)kei/nou e(/neken dei=n pa/nta ta)=lla pra/ttesqai, k.t.l. Euthyd. 278 E alibi.
e)n kefalai/w| ei)pei=n] ‘to speak summarily’, to sum up in one notion, to describe all human ends and aims by the single phrase ‘happiness and its parts’.
w(s a(plw=s ei)pei=n] speaking broadly and generally, without descending to particulars. Opposed to kaq' e(/kaston. See note on I 2, 4, p. 30.

e)/stw dh\ eu)daimoni/a] Brandis, u. s. p. 48, note 42, (after Spengel) remarks upon this use of e)/stw as marking the popular character of the definitions that follow—as if it were a matter of indifference whether they are right or not, provided that they are so generally acceptable as to be certain to satisfy the audience. The same form is repeated c. 6, 2; 7, 2; 10, 3; II 2, 1, and throughout the chapters on the pa/qh. On the definition of Rhetoric, see Introd. p. 13; and on this definition of happiness, p. 176.

Aristotle's own definition of happiness in the Eth. Nic., the result of his inquiries in that work, is something far different, e)ne/rgeia yuxh=s kat' a)reth/n, the fully developed activity or active exercise (implying full consciousness) of the soul in respect of its proper (and therefore highest) excellence: that is contemplation, qewri/a, the exercise of the highest faculty, the nou=s, or intuitive reason; the highest faculties being the intellectual. This is the theory; but practically a lower view of happiness is admitted (Bk. X), which consists in the exercise of the moral as well as the intellectual virtues. Of the definitions here given, au)ta/rkeia zwh=s comes nearest to his own: it expresses a self-sufficing life, complete in itself, independent of all external aids and advantages, and is in fact essential to the notion of happiness. See Eth. Nic. I 5 (quoted below).

The essentials of the three first of these definitions are found all united in the conception of happiness, the ultimate end of all human desire and effort, which forms the conclusion of the tenth book of the Nicomachean Ethics, from the sixth chapter to the end. It contains first, the eu)praci/a met' a)reth=s, in the exercise of moral and intellectual virtue, the intellectual being the higher and more perfect form of it, and in that the intuitive contemplative energy; secondly, the au)ta/rkeia th=s zwh=s, the self-sufficiency and independence of everything external, which is necessary to perfection and happiness; and thirdly, the life met' a)sfalei/as, the happiness residing in qewri/a being most secure because it is most independent and the nearest approach to the happiness of the Gods, who have all their wants and faculties satisfied in themselves, and want nothing <*>m without (c. 7); and also h(/distos, because pleasure is the necessary accompaniment of
every e)ne/rgeia (active exercise, realisation in exercise, of any du/namis or capacity), and qewri/a being the most perfect form of e)ne/rgeia, the pleasure that accompanies it must needs be the highest and most complete; and the exercise of the moral faculties in proportion to their comparative excellence. kai\ tw=| a)nqrw/pw| dh\ o( kata\ to\n nou=n bi/os (h(/distos kai\ kra/tistos), ei)/per tou=to ma/lista a)/nqrwpos. ou(=tos a)/ra kai\ eu)daimone/statos. Eth. N. X 7 ult. (In the popular and lower sense of the words this definition of happiness would belong to the Epicurean school.) The fourth definition, eu)qhni/a kthma/twn kai\ swma/twn meta\ duna/mews fulaktikh=s te kai\ praktikh=s tou/twn: is only applicable to a state. The Stoic definition of happiness was eu)/roia bi/ou. Sext. Emp. Pyrrh. Hypot. *g § 172, pro\s *)hqikou/s § 30.

eu)praci/a met' a)reth=s] Comp. Pol. IV (VII) 1, 1323 b 20, o(/ti me
 ou)=n e(ka/stw| th=s eu)daimoni/as e)piba/llei tosou=ton o(/son per a)reth=s kai\ fronh/sews kai\ tou= pra/ttein kata\ tau/tas, e)/stw sunwmologhme/non h(mi=n, ma/rturi tw=| qew=| xrwme/nois, o(\s eu)dai/mwn me/n e)sti kai\ maka/rios, di) ou)qe
 de\ tw=n e)cwterikw=n a)gaqw=n a)lla\ di) au(to
 au)to\s kai\ tw=| poio/s tis ei)=nai th
 fu/sin, e)pei\ kai\ th
 eu)tuxi/an th=s eu)daimoni/as dia\ tau=t' a)nagkai=on e(/teron ei)=nai k.t.l. Ib. c. 3, 1326 b 12, a)ll' ei) tau=ta le/getai kalw=s kai\ th
 eu)daimoni/an eu)pragi/an qete/on, kai\ koinh=| pa/shs po/lews a)
 ei)/h kai\ kaq) e(/kaston a)/ristos bi/os o( praktiko/s. By comparing this latter passage with the definition, it would seem that the sense of eu)praci/a in the latter must be limited to ‘well doing’, and not extended to ‘welfare’, which it, like eu)= pra/ttein, is capable of including. Pol. IV (VII) 1, kai\ po/lin eu)dai/mona th
 a)ri/sthn ei)=nai kai\ pra/ttousan kalw=s: a)du/naton de\ kalw=s pra/ttein th
 mh\ ta\ kala\ pra/ttousan. Ib. c. 3 sub init. a)du/naton ga to
 mhqe
 pra/ttonta pra/ttein eu)=, th
 d' eu)pragi/an kai\ th
 eu)daimoni/an ei)=nai tau)to/n. Ib. c. 8, eu)daimoni/a...a)reth=s e)ne/rgeia kai\ xrh=si/s tis te/leios. c. 13, 1332 a 7.

au)ta/rkeia zwh=s] Eth. Nic. I 5, 1097 b 7, fai/netai de\ kai\ e)k th=s au)tarkei/as to\ au)to\ sumbai/nein (the notion of au)/tarkes leads to the same result, or conception of happiness as that of te/leion, previously applied to determine it). to\ ga te/leion a)gaqo
 au)/tarkes ei)=nai dokei=...to\ d' au)/tarkes ti/qemen o(\ monou/menon ai(reto
 poiei= to
 bi/on kai\ mhdeno\s e)ndea=: toiou=ton de\ th
 eu)daimoni/an oi)o/meqa ei)=nai. Comp. X 6, 1176 b 5, ou)deno\s ga| e)ndeh\s h( eu)daimoni/a a)ll' au/ta/rkhs. c. 7, 1177 a 28, h(/ te legome/nh au)ta/rkeia (which is essential to happiness) peri\ th
 qewrhtikh
 ma/list' a)
 ei)/h: (and therefore the highest and most perfect happiness must consist in qewri/a). A similar au)ta/rkeia or independence is attributed to the perfect state in the Politics. On the notion of the perfect state or constitution in the second degree, that is, under the necessary limitations incident to a human condition, so far as humanity allows of perfection at all, see Pol. VI (IV) 11 init. In Pol. IV (VII) 5 init. au)ta/rkeia is thus defined, to\ pa/nta u(pa/rxein kai\ dei=sqai mhqeno\s au)/tarkes.

eu)qhni/a] and eu)qhnei=n are Ionic and also late Greek forms belonging to the koinh\ dia/lektos, for the Attic eu)qenei=n and eu)qeni/a or eu)qe/neia, and denote a ‘flourishing state’, or ‘prosperity’ in general. ‘eu)qenei=n enim non tam robur (quod verbo eu)sqenei=n subiectum est) quam vigorem et vitalitatem declarat, ut v. c. Aiax aliquis aut Hercules eu)sqenei=n dicatur, sed vel
tenerrima planta, quum laeto iuventae flore nitet, eu)qenei=n dici possit. Et maximi quidem proprie de succo sanitatis et corporis incremento deque uberi proventu et auctu, sed non minus apte de prospero rerum publicarum privatarumque successu, deque omni ubertate et affluentia dicitur.’ (From an excellent note by Lobeck on these words ad Phryn. &c. p. 465—7: Lobeck derives eu)qenei=n from eu)= and qe/w (ti/qhmi), comparing it with other verbs of similar formation. The MSS of Arist. give sometimes eu)qeni/a and eu)qenei=n, but generally eu)qhni/a and eu)qhnei=n. Lobeck's note may be applied as a corrective of Victorius' ad h. l.)

kthma/twn kai\ swma/twn] ‘property’ of all kinds, goods and chattels, including especially flocks and herds; and ‘population’, here estimated by ‘bodies’, not by ‘souls’ as Christianity has taught us to reckon it.

eu)tekni/a (eu)/teknos, eu)/pais, eu)paidi/a, eu)teknei=n, Aeschylus and Euripides), and eu)ghri/a, eu)/teknos, and eu)gh/rws, ‘blessing in children, and in old age’, are applied by Aristotle to animals, as well as to the human race, in his works on Natural History: e.g. to birds, in the sense of ‘prolific’, Hist. An. IX II, 1; 12, 3; 17, 1; IX 12, 3; eu)/ghroi o)/rniqes.

polufili/a, xrhstofili/a, both defined by Aristotle himself in § 16, ‘number of friends, worthiness of friends’. The latter is defined by Liddell and Scott, ‘the love of good men or good deeds’, [a slip corrected, however, in a subsequent edition. S.]

ta\s tou= sw/matos a)reta/s] The a)reth/ or ‘excellence’ of anything is determined by its e)/rgon or special function or business; that which it was made to do. On this notion of e)/rgon, see the reff. given in note on c. 2, § 12. a)reth/ therefore is so far from being confined to moral virtue, though it is applied to this kat' e)coxh/n, that it may be extended to everything which has any use or object, animate or inanimate; but in the highest and most appropriate sense is attributed to human faculties bodily, mental, and moral.

me/geqos] So Homer and Hesiod reckon size as well as strength and beauty amongst personal advantages. Od. z 276, ti/s d' o(/de *nausika/a e(/petai kalo/s te me/gas te cei=nos; Ib. s 248, peri/essi gunaikw=n ei)=do/s te me/geqo/s te. w 252, ou)de/ ti/ toi dou/leion e)pipre/pei ei)sora/asqai ei)=dos kai\ me/geqos. s 218. w 373. Il. B 58, &c. Hesiod, Scut. Herc. 3, and Plato, Alc. I p. 123 E, in an enumeration of the personal qualities and other advantages that a young man might be proud of, ei) ou)=n le/goimen o(/ti ka/llei te kai\ mege/qei kai\ ge/nei kai\ plou/tw| kai\ fu/sei th=s yuxh=s... Charmid. 154 C, qaumasto\s e)fa/nh to/ te me/geqos kai\ to\ ka/llos. So Ovid's Romulus, after his deification, pulcer et humano maior. Arist. Eth. Nic. IV 7, 1323 b 7, e)n mege/qei
ga\r h( megaloyuxi/a, w(/sper kai\ to\ ka/llos e)n mega/lw| sw/mati, oi( mikroi\ d' a)stei=oi (pretty or neat) kai\ su/mmetroi, kaloi\ d' ou)/. Pol. IV (VII) 4, 1326 a 33, to/ ge kalo\n e)n plh/qei kai\ mege/qei ei)/wqe gi/nesqai. Poet. VII 4, to\ ga\r kalo\n e)n mege/qei kai\ ta/cei e)sti/, ap. Zell, ad loc. Eth.

do/can] ‘reputation’, estimation in men's thoughts or opinion. (‘Fame is the spur that the clear spirit doth raise, that last infirmity of noble minds, to scorn delights, &c.’ Lycidas).—timh/n honours, substantial and externally manifested, which are conferred upon a man, offices, titles, proedri/ai, civil privileges, and such like. See further in § 9. On the value of timh/ in general, Eth. Nic. IV 7, 1123 b 18, me/giston de\ tou=t' a)\n qei/hmen o(\ toi=s qeoi=s a)pone/momen, kai\ ou(= ma/list) e)fie/ntai oi( e)n a)ciw/mati, kai\ to\ e)pi\ toi=s kalli/stois a)=qlon. toiou=ton d) h( timh/. me/giston ga\r dh\ tou=to tw=n e)xto\s a)gaqw=n, 1124 a 17.
eu)tuxi/an] distinguished from eu)daimoni/a, Pol. IV (VII) 1, 1323 b 20 seq., quoted above in note on § 3.
h)\ kai\ ta\ me/rh au)th=s, fro/nhsin a)ndri/an dikaiosu/nhn swfrosu/nhn] These words are omitted by MS A^{c}, put in brackets as doubtful by Bekker [4to ed. 1831], and rejected by Spengel.
au)tarke/statos] referring to the second definition, § 3. See note on § 3, p. 73.

ta/ t' e)n au)tw=| kai\ ta\ e)kto\s a)gaqa/] When Aristotle adds ‘besides these there are no others’, he includes, as he tells us in the following sentence, the goods of body and mind under the first head, ta\ e)n au)tw=|. His usual division of goods, called the Peripatetic division, is into three kinds; goods of ‘mind, body, and estate’. This division, however, was not his own invention; as he tells us in Eth. Nic. I 8, 1098 b 17, tau/thn th
 do/can (the opinion in question) palaia
 ou)=san kai\ o(mologoume/nhn u(po\ tw=n filosofou/ntwn. Cic. Tusc. V 30, tria genera bonorum, maxima animi, secunda corporis, externa tertia, ut Peripatetici, nec multo veteres Academici secus. Eth. Nic. I 8, sub init. nenhmhme/nwn dh\ tw=n a)gaqw=n trixh=|, kai\ tw=n me
 e)kto\s legome/nwn tw=n de\ peri\ yuxh
 kai\ sw=ma, ta\ peri\ yuxh
 kuriw/tata le/gomen kai\ ma/lista a)gaqa/. Pol. IV (VII) 1 sub init. triw=n ou)sw=n meri/dwn, tw=n te e)kto\s kai\ tw=n e)n tw=| sw/mati kai\ tw=n e)n th=| yuxh=|, pa/nta tau=ta u(pa/rxein toi=s makari/ois dei=. Zell ad Eth. Nic. I 8, 2. Cic. de Fin. III 13, 43, et alibi. Schrader ad h. l. This division cannot be at all events confined to the Peripatetics or derived from them alone, for it appears in the Rhet. ad Alex. c. I (2 Oxf.) 8, diairh/seis de\ tou=to (to\ sumfe/ron) toi=s me
 i)diw/tais ei)s sw=ma kai\ yuxh
 kai\ ta\ e)pi/kthta: unless indeed this be taken as an argument of the later authorship of the Rhet. ad Alexandrum.

duna/meis] either ‘power’ of various kinds, ‘opes ac civilem potentiam’,
Muretus, Victorius, ‘potentiam’, Vet. Transl.; or faculties and capacities, bodily and mental, ‘facultates’, Riccob. The nrst seems to agree better with eu)tuxi/an.
a)sfale/statos] referring to the third definition of § 3.

eu)ge/neia] in an individual or family is defined in Pol. VI (IV) 8, 1294 a 21, h ga\r eu)ge/neia/ e)stin a)rxai=os plou=tos kai\ a)reth/, and VIII (V) I, 1301 b 2, eu)genei=s ei)=nai dokou=sin oi(=s u(pa/rxei progo/nwn a)reth\ kai\ plou=tos. Rhet. II 15. 2, 3. Plat. Theaet. 174 E, ta\ de\ dh\ ge/nh u(mnou/ntwn, w(s gennai=o/s tis e(pta\ pa/ppous plousi/ous e)/xwn a)pofh=nai, which seems to have been the current definition of eu)ge/neia at Athens in Plato's time.

au)to/xqonas] Herod. I 171, Thuc. I, 2 and 6, Arist. Vesp. 1076, Eur. Ion 29, 589, 737, of Athens; Isocr. Panath. § 124, also of Athens; Paneg. § 24, 25, Dem. de F. L. § 296, of the Athenians and Arcadians. Quint. III 7, 26, laudantur autem urbes similiter atque homines. Nam pro parente est conditor; et multum auctoritatis affert vetustas, ut iis qui terra dicuntur orti.
kai\ h(gemo/nas tou\s prw/tous e)pifanei=s] ‘and to have had for their first rulers famous men’, like Theseus at Athens.

kai\ pollou\s e)pifanei=s—e)pi\ toi=s zhloume/nois] ‘and many men sprung from their race renowned for things (personal qualities, feats of arms, noble deeds, and such like) that are esteemed and admired’. e)pi/, ‘standing, resting upon’, ‘upon the basis, terms, or condition of...’.
i)di/a| de\ eu)ge/neia h)\ a)p' a)ndrw=n h)\ a)po\ gunaikw=n] ‘privately, in a family, it may be derived either from the father's or the mother's side’, i. e. from famous ancestors on either.

gnhsio/ths a)p' a)mfoi=n] ‘legitimacy on both sides’, in birth and citizenship. gnh/sios, opposed to no/qos, Il. *l 102, ui(=e du/w *pria/moio no/qon kai\ gnh/sion, Plat. Rep. VII 536 A, to
 no/qon te kai\ to
 gnh/sion, and also to poihto/s, ei)spoi/htos, qeto\s ui(o/s, Dem. c. Leoch. 1095, 5, to\ me
 ga gnh/sio/n e)stin o(/tan h)=| go/nw| gegonw/s, kai\ o( no/mos tau=ta marturei= le/gwn, h(
 a)

gh=s, xwri/wn kth=sis] gh=, ‘territory’, the acquisition or possession of public property, xw/ria (dim. of xw=ros or xw/ra, little places, regions, countries, ‘spots’,) ‘farms’, ‘estates’, ‘domains’, private properties. Or perhaps rather, gh merely ‘land’ in general, and xw/ria the divisions of land, the actual private properties.

e)/pipla, (a division of property) ‘moveables’, moveable furniture or property of all kinds: opposed to ‘fixtures’, such as houses and land. Xen. Oecon. IX 6 includes in it all sacrificial furniture or apparatus; and articles of dress, shoes, female ornaments; and of house furniture, as beds. In Thuc. III 68, a(\ h)=n e)n tw=| tei/xei e)/pipla, xalko\s kai\ si/dhros, it stands for household furniture of bronze and iron: everything of this kind which was in the fort, the Laced., after the capture of Plataea, converted into couches (kli=nai) and dedicated to *(/hra. In Arist. Pol. II 7, 1267 b 12, kai\ kataskeuh\ pollh\ (a large stock) tw=n kaloume/nwn e)pi/plwn, it is opposed, first, with money, slaves and cattle, to land, and then, secondly, to the three former. Similarly in the present passage, they are distinguished from cattle and slaves as inanimate moveable furniture, or ‘plenishing’. Herodotus writes the word e)pi/ploa in I 94; elsewhere, as usual, e)/pipla. The derivation appears to be, ta\ e)pipolh=s skeu/h, ta\ e)pipo/laia, superficial’. They are said to be ‘superficial’, to ‘lie on the surface’, because they are not fixed or rooted, like land, houses, trees; which are all ‘property’ nevertheless.

tau=ta de\ pa/nta kai\ a)sfalh= kai\ e)leuqe/ria kai\ xrh/sima] All the kinds of property just mentioned are ‘secure’, (in the sense, ‘that the use of it is always in your own power’, infra), not liable to risk, as money made and employed in trade or commerce; and ‘liberal’, such as befit a gentleman, a man of ‘liberal’ education and pursuits, cultivated and accomplished and refined, o( pepaideume/nos (paidei/a, h(=| diagignw/skomen ta\ kala\ kai\ ta\ ai)sxra/, Aesch. c. Ctesiph. § 260); and also ‘useful’, pro\s to\ zh=|n kai\ to\ eu)= zh=|n, and therefore a part of genuine wealth (with which money is here included, contrary to the true theory).

e)leuqe/rios, as here applied, expresses the general notion of liberality, in character and habits of mind. In the Ethics, and most frequently in the ordinary language, it is restricted as a moral virtue to a species of liberality, that namely which manifests itself peri\ do/sin xrhma/twn kai\ lh=yin. Eth. Nic. II 7. The e)leuqe/rios represents the gentleman
from the democratic point of view; he embodies the notion of ‘freedom which is the o(/ros, the principle, and the end and aim of the democratic commonwealth; he is the type of a free citizen, and therefore as expressive of character the term denotes ‘that which a model free citizen ought to be’; and connotes or implies those qualifications, particularly education and enlightenment, which enable him efficiently to discharge the proper functions of a free citizen, and those social qualities and habits which fit him for such a society. This is opposed to the aristocratic conception of a gentleman which makes the character or notion depend rather upon birth, wealth and station; and according to which the a)gaqoi/, a)/ristoi, a)risth=es, the boni, optimi, optimates, &c., are the nobles, the men of rank, and of good family in a state. See further on this subject, Donaldson, New Cratylus, §§ 321—328.

Another characteristic of Greek feeling, which deserves notice, is brought into view in the application of the term e)leuqe/ria to distinguish a particular kind of property; and this is, the contempt for trade and commerce as a profession and a means of acquiring wealth, which as B. St Hilaire observes (note on Transl. of Ar. Pol. p. 36) was common to all antiquity. A similar observation is made by Böckh, Publ. Econ. of Athens, Bk. I c. 8 p. 43 (Transl.).

Plato's writings abound with contemptuous epithets and expressions applied to e)mpori/a, kaphlei/a, xrhmatistikh/, xrhmatismo/s, and all arts and professions of which money-making was the only object; for instance, Legg. IV 1, 705 A, e)mpori/as ga kai\ xrhmatismou= dia\ kaphlei/as e)mpipla=sa au)th/n, h)/qh pali/mbola kai\ a)/pista tai=s yuxai=s e)nti/ktousa, au)th/n te pro\s au)th
 th
 po/lin a)/piston kai\ a)/filon poiei= kai\ pro\s tou\s a)/llous a)nqrw/pous w(sau/tws, where trade is represented as corrupting and demoralizing. In XI 4, 918 D, in the course of a discussion on the legitimate objects and uses of trade, he makes the remark, dio\ pa/nta ta\ peri\ th
 kaphlei/an kai\ e)mpori/an kai\ pandokei/an ge/nh (in the actual practice of them) diabe/blhtai/ te kai\ e)n ai)sxroi=s ge/gonen o)nei/desin, which results from their general tendency to corrupt the character of those who follow these pursuits, by the immoderate desire of gain which they stimulate and foster. Accordingly no citizen of the model state is allowed to follow any retail trade; this must be confined to metics and strangers, me/toikon ei)=nai xrew

Aristotle similarly condemns trade and the business and practice of interchanging commodities, so far as its object is mere money-making, xrhmatistikh/. This is the accumulation of unnatural, artificial property: the only kind of property or wealth that is natural, fu/sei, is that which can be applied directly to one's own use, pro\s xrh=sin, and ultimately pro\s to\ eu)= zh=|n, and falls under the province of oi)konamikh/, from which xrhmatistikh/ is excluded. Pol. I 9. Hence of the two kinds of kthtikh/, the one, which may be called oi)konomikh/, because it forms part of the science of œconomics (domestic economy) properly understood, is neces
sary and laudable; the other, h( kaphlikh/ or metablhtikh/, with its offspring usury, which breeds money out of money, and is thence called to/kos, ‘is justly reprehended’ and usury ‘most reasonably the object of abhorrence’. th=s de\ metablhtikh=s yegome/nhs dikai/ws, ou) ga\r kata\ fu/sin a)ll' a)p) a)llh/lwn e)sti/n, eu)logw/tata misei=tai h( o)bolostatikh\ dia\ to\ u(p) au)tou= tou= nomi/smatos ei)=nai th\n kth=sin kai\ ou)k e)f) o(/per e)pori/sqh. k.t.l. I 10 sub fin.

On the character and tendencies of e)/mporoi, compare Xen. Oecon. XX 27, 28. In the same treatise, c. I 12, 13, 14, a distinction is taken, similar to that of Aristotle, between xrh/mata, wealth or property which you can use directly, which does you direct service, and money, which is excluded from the notion of property in this sense. Xenophon, like Aristotle, approves of nothing but the agricultural mode of life as the best both for mind and body, and as cultivating and promoting the habits which go to form the best of citizens. See Oecon. c. VI 8, 9, 10, c. XV 9.

These extracts will throw light upon the meaning of the word e)leuqe/ria as applied to the land and stock and buildings and moveables of the landed gentleman or country proprietor. They are said to belong to the gentleman or man of cultivation, in contrast with the degrading or corrupting habits engendered by trade and commerce.

e)/sti de\ xrh/sima ma=llon k.t.l.] Property employed in business, and therefore productive, a)f' w(=n ai( pro/sodoi ‘from which one derives one's income’, is more useful, but carries with it the notion of sordidness or meanness; the other, because it produces nothing but the enjoymenta)po/lausis is properly ‘sensual enjoyment’. In Eth. N. 1 3, where the three kinds of lives, the a)polaustiko/s, praktiko/s or politiko/s, and qewrhtiko/s are distinguished and compared, the first is that which has h(donh/ for its sole object, the gratification of the animal appetites and desires, the satisfaction of to\ e)piqumhtiko/n; the second has a)reth/ moral virtue for its te/los; the third, qewri/a, the highest activity of the intellect., which proceeds from using it, because it is not corrupted and degraded by any contact or connexion with money-making, better befits the cultivated man, who should hold himself aloof from such pursuits, and partakes more of the notion of kalo/n. Comp. I 9, 25, kai\ ni/kh kai\ timh\ tw=n kalw=n, ai(reta/ te ga\r a)/karpa o)/nta. § 26, kai\ kth/mata a)/karpa (kala/ e)sti). e)leuqeriw/tera ga/r. Eth. N. IV 8 sub fin. (of the megalo/yuxos), kai\ oi(=os kekth=sqai ma=llon ta\ kala\ kai\ a)/karpa tw=n karpi/mwn kai\ w)feli/mwn—the contrast of ‘honour’ and ‘profit’.

a)polaustika\ de/ k.t.l.] Comp. Metaph. A 1, 981 b 17, on the ascending scale of arts, in the order of superiority in knowledge and general excellence. plei/onwn d' eu(riskome/nwn texnw=n, kai\ tw=n me\n pro\s ta)nagkai=a tw=n de\ pro\s diagwgh\n (passe-temps, pastime, diversion) ou)sw=n, a)ei\ sofwte/rous tou\s toiou/tous e)kei/nwn u(polamba/nomen, dia\ to\ mh\ pro\s xrh=sin ei)=nai ta\s e)pisth/mas au)tw=n. The highest in degree are ‘sciences’, the invention of which is due neither to necessity nor to the mere desire of amusements, and requires ‘leisure’: whence it happened that mathematics were first studied in Egypt by the priestly class.

Hippol. 91, tou= de\ kai\ m' a)nistorei=s pe/ri; 224, ti/ kunhgesi/wn kai\ soi\ mele/th; (what is thy concern with hunting?), Ion, 241, o(/ti kai\ qe/mis, 346, tau=ta kai\ manteu/omai. Aesch. Agam. 97, o(/ti kai\ dunato/n. 279. Dem. de F. L. § 87, o(/per kai\ ge/gonen. § 97, o(\ kai\ qauma/zw (Schäfer's note). Porson ad Phoen. 1373; in interrogation, Wunder ad Antig. 720.

h( e)ne/rgeia] This technical term, and the opposition of du/namis and e)ne/rgeia which pervades Aristotle's entire philosophy, represents plou=tos as a mere du/namis or dormant faculty or capacity, until it is ‘developed’ or ‘realised’ and ‘set in action’ (energized) by use (xrh=sis), by application to the ‘service’ of its owner. On this ‘fundamental antithesis’ of do/namis and e)ne/rgeia as a physical, moral, and metaphysical conception, consult Metaph. *q 6—9, and Bonitz Comm.; Trendel. El. Log. Arist. § 6, p. 61, Kategorienlehre, p. 157 seq., Comm. ad Ar. de Anima, Lib. II p. 295—312; Grant, Essays on Ethics, Ess. IV. p. 181 seq. (1st ed.) [p. 231 (3rd ed.)].

spoudai=on] As e)pieikh/s is transferred from the special sense of a particular kind of goodness, i.e. equity, or merciful consideration, to the sense of ‘good’ in general, (see ante, note on I 2, 4); so spoudai=os (serious, earnest, Xen. Cyrop. II 2. 9, 3. 8, as opposed to pai/zwnEth. Nic. X 6, 1177 a. 3, belti/w te le/gomen ta\ spoudai=a tw=n geloi/wn kai\ tw=n meta\ paidia=s, kai\ tou= belti/onos a)ei\ kai\ mori/ou kai\ a)nqrw/pou spoudaiote/ran th\n e)ne/rgeian. ‘in jest’), to levity and frivolity; and thence, in the sense of something solid and substantial,
sound and true, to fau=los, light, empty, trifling and worthless) acquires a moral sense coextensive with a)gaqo/s, and is opposed to fau=los, Plat. Rep. VII 519 D, Legg. VI 757 A, &c. as the sound and solid to the light, empty, and unsubstantial. This familiar application of the word is recognized (as in the parallel case of e)pieikh/s, Eth. N. v 14) by Aristotle, Categ. c. 8, 10 b 7, oi(=on a)po\ th=s a)reth=s o( spoudai=os: tw=| ga\r a)reth\n e)/xein spoudai=os le/getai, a)ll' ou) parwnu/mws a)po\ th=s a)reth=s (i. e. the notion is derived from a)reth/, but not the word itself). Plat. o(/roi, p. 415 D (ed. Tur. p. 888) spoudai=os o( tele/ws a)gaqo/s.

There is however one point of difference between e)pieikh/s and spoudaios, that spoudai=os is extended to every kind of excellence, like a)gaqo/s, whereas e)pieikh/s is confined to the expression of excellence in human character. Also spoudai=os has another sense distinguishable from the preceding, as opposed to geloi=os, the ‘serious’ to the ‘jocose’ or ‘ridiculous’. Xen. Cyrop. II 3. 1, toiau=ta kai\ geloi=a kai\ spoudai=a e)le/geto, and Symp. VIII 3, spoudai=ai o)/frues, ‘grave and serious’. spoudh/ and paidi/a ‘jest’ and ‘earnest’, ‘serious work’ and ‘play’ or ‘sport’, are constantly brought into contrast by Plato.

polloi\ ga\r dia\ mikra\ dokou=nta k.t.l.] Trifles acquire importance, and confer honour, on special occasions, under special circumstances of time and place. Thus what is in ordinary cases a very trifling and unimportant action, as the gift of a cup of cold water, becomes under the circum
stances in which Sir Philip Sidney gave it at the battle of Zutphen a renowned act of self-denial and heroism. And under other and different circumstances the same cup of water may assume an importance which does not naturally belong to it. ‘For whosoever shall give you a cup of water to drink in my name, because ye belong to Christ, verily I say unto you, he shall not lose his reward.’ Mark ix. 41, Matth. x. 42.

mnh=mai e)n me/trois kai\ a)/neu me/trwn] ‘Memorials in prose and verse’, possibly epitaphs; but rather, as these may be included in ta/foi, to be understood (as Vict.) of poems and prose compositions in memoriam, such as the English work that bears this title, poems in honour of the illustrious dead, and panegyrics in prose, like some of Isocrates' speeches and Xenophon's Agesilaus. ta\ barbarika/, oi(=on proskunh/seis] prosku/nhsis, from pro\s, and kunei=n, ‘to kiss’, denotes the oriental and ‘barbarous’ custom of saluting by ‘kissing the hand to’ another, in token of inferiority and subjection, and thence is applied to any act of servile obeisance or homage, or to worship and adoration in general: in the last or metaphorical sense it is found in most of the best Greek writers. This practice may very likely have been accompanied by the analogous one of prostration, as the two are often found associated together in one expression. It was distinctive of Oriental barbarism; and prevailed amongst the Medes, Herod. I 119, of Harpagus and Astyages, the Persians, Id. proskunh/seis, e)ksta/seis] The plural of abstract nouns denotes the various individual acts or moments or states included under the general conception.

dw=ra ta\ par' e(ka/stois ti/mia] ‘quae apud singulas gentes in pretio sunt’, Victorius: who illustrates by the olive crown as a prize in the Greek games, and quotes Horace, Ep. II 2. 32, clarus ob id factum donis ornatur honestis, of the prize of valour, bearing a special value in the Roman Military service, assigned to ‘Lucullus' soldier’. Of the words by themselves this interpretation is perfectly fair and natural; but in connexion with what follows (as Aristotle seems to have intended, kai\ ga\r to\ dw=ron...) they may be understood somewhat differently, and the par' e(ka/stois referred to ‘the individuals of the two classes’ mentioned immediately after, the filoxrh/matoi and filo/timoi.

sw/matos de\ a)reth\ u(gi/eia] Health, as a bodily excellence, necessarily implies vigour and the power of active exertion for the fulfilment of the duties of life, without these it is no a)reth/ at all, and no subject of congratulation to the possessor. Health is said to be the a)reth/ of the body, in reference to the doctrine of the proper e)/rgon of anything; see note on p. 40 c. 2 § 12. Life is the special function of the body (Eth. Nic. I 6), and health is life in its best form, as far as the body is concerned.

*(hro/dikos] a famous physician, native of Selymbria, in Thrace on the Propontis; to be distinguished from another less known physician, Gorgias' brother, of Leontini, Plat. Gorg. 448 B, 456 B. On Herodicus and
his medical practice, see Plat. Phaedr. 227 E, and Heindorf's and Ast's notes; also Rep. III 406 A seq., where an account of him and his system of self-tormenting is given. Protag. 316 EMacaulay, in his celebrated Essay on Bacon, Edin. Rev., July, 1837, selects these opinions of Plato, which he describes at length from the passage of the Republic, as to the value of Herodicus' system of medical practice, as one of the illustrations of the contempt for all that is useful and practical which pervades the Platonic philosophy; contrasting this, much to the disadvantage of the ancient philosopher, with the opposite spirit and tendency of the Baconian system, which aims, as he assumes, exclusively at practical and attainable good, and promotes the investigation of truth solely with a view to the substantial and solid benefit of the human race. Schrader cites Dial. de Orat. XXIII 4 Ne in corpore quidem valetudinem medici probant, quae animi anxietate contingat. Parum est aegrum non esse; fortem et laetum et alacrem volo. Prope abest ab infirmitate in qua sola sanitas laudatur..
tw=n a)nqrwpi/nwn] See note on c. I § 7, di) a)/llas ai)ti/as a)nqrwpika/s.

Personal beauty has no absolute standard or uniform expression, manifesting itself in the same forms at all periods and under all circumstances. It is relative, not only to the three stages of human life, youth, prime (a)kmh/) and old age, but also to the habits and functions natural and appropriate to each of those stages; manly and athletic exercises, in the way of training, to youth; military service, the imperative duty of an active and able-bodied citizen, to middle age; sedentary and intellectual pursuits, to old age, yet so that strength and vigour remain adequate to the endurance of ordinary or ‘necessary’ labours— extraordinary exertions, as in athletic exercises and service in the field, being no longer required. The habit of body which is fitted to the exercise of these several functions at the corresponding period of life is a constituent element of its personal beauty.

ne/ou me\n ou)=n ka/llos k.t.l.] When it is said that the beauty of a young man consists partly in the possession of a body in a serviceable state for undergoing the labours and pains incident to the race and feats of strength, the meaning seems to be that the robust habit of body and the muscular development required for the one, and the indications of activity combined with strength, which appear in the outward form, necessary for the other, are pleasant to the eye, both in themselves and also as suggesting a fitness or adaptation or harmony of the exterior of the person with the habits and pursuits which are appropriate to youth.
pro\s a)po/lausin] means no more than the mere enjoyment afforded by the sight of personal beauty. Victorius, who suggests another interpretation, concludes finally in favour of this.

oi( pe/ntaqloi ka/llistoi] The combination of a natural aptitude or
capacity (pefu/kasi pro/s) for strength and speed, vigour and activity, as evidenced by success in the various exercises of the pe/ntaqlon, and the outward expression of these faculties in the configuration of the body, when accompanied with beauty in the shape, symmetry, and expression of the features, is the highest form of personal beauty in the young man. ‘Die übung im Pentathlon war wegen der verschiedenartigkeit der fünf wettkämpfe ganz vorzüglich das werk junger rustiger männer mit elastischem leibe. Die Pentathlen zeichneten sich daher durch gleichmässige stärke der glieder, allseitige gewandtheit und körperlich harmonische bildung vor allen übrigen vortheilhaft aus, und werden daher vom Aristoteles als die schönsten Agonisten genannt.’ Krause, Gymn. u. Agon. der Griechen, Vol. I, p. 494, abschn. VI § 31. The exercise of the pe/ntaqlon is therefore mentioned in the passage before us as belonging solely to the period of youthThe pe/ntaqlos however, though by the number and variety of his accomplishments he is superior to all other athletes, yet in regard of certain special excellences, as compared for instance with the runner or wrestler, he is only second rate. Plat. Erast. 135 E. The philosopher in the popular sense, Aristotle's pepaideume/nos, the man of universal attainments, is compared to the all-accomplished athlete. *)=ar' e)nnow= oi(=on le/geis to
 filo/sofon a)/ndra; dokei=s ga/r moi le/gein oi(=on e)n th=| a)gwni/a| ei)si
 oi( pe/ntaqloi pro\s tou\s drome/as h)\ tou\s palaista/s. kai\ ga e)kei=noi tou/twn me

The pe/ntaqlon consisted of five exercises as the name implies. These are enumerated in an epigram of Simonides, Anthol. 67 (73), Bergk, Fragm. Lyr. p. 791,
*)/isqmia kai\ *puqoi= *diofw=n o( *fi/lwnos e)ni/ka a(/lma, podwkei/hn, di/skon, a)/konta, pa/lhn,
and in an epigram of unknown authorship quoted by Eustath. ad Il. *y. p. 1320, Anthol. e)pigra/mata a)de/spota CCCLIV,
a(/lma podw=n, di/skou te bolh/, kai\ a)/kontos e)rwh/, kai\ dro/mos, h)de\ palh/: mi/a d' e)/pleto pa=si teleuth/.

The same five are named in the Schol. on Pind. Isthm. I 35, and in the Schol. on Plat. Erast. c. 4. 135 D, pa/lh, si/gunnos (i. e. a)/kwn), a(/lma, di/skos, kai\ dro/mos. On the pe/ntaqlon and its contents, see Krause, Op. cit. p. 476 seq. abschn. VI § 29.

*pugmh/, boxing, was therefore not included in the pe/ntaqlon; and we are driven to suppose that the concluding words of § 14, o( de\ pa=si pe/ntaqlos, which certainly according to the ordinary laws of the interpretation of language ought to include it with the rest of the foregoing exercises, are one amongst many instances of Aristotle's carelessness in expressing himself, and affirm something which he could not really have meant. pa=si, if it can be said to have any meaning at all, must be understood simply to imply, that the pe/ntaqlon combines in one the greatest number and variety of the single and separate exercises. Such is also the opinion of Krause, Op. cit. p. 258, n. 6. He observes that such a conclusion (as would naturally be drawn from the words of Arist.) is opposed to all the
notices which we find in the ancient writers. Aristoteles konnte hier in bekannten dingen die mehr worte bedürfende deutlichkeit einer gedrungenen präcisen, und in gemessener gradation fortschreitender redeweise, welche ihm eigenthümlich ist, aufopfern, da ja doch jedem Hellenen die fünf bestandtheile des Pentathlon bekannt waren.

a)kma/zontos de/ k.t.l.] The simplest way of filling up the elliptical construction seems to be to supply ka/llos after a)kma/zontos, and ge/rontos in the next clause, and pefuke/nai from the immediately preceding prefu/kasin after polemikou/s in the former clause and i(kano/n in the latter. The required sense may be equally well supplied by repeating (as Victorius) the first words of the sentence, a)kma/zontos de\ (ka/llos) (to\) pro\s me\n po/nous tou\s polemikou/s (xrh/simon e)/xein to\ sw=ma); but the consideration of the immediate proximity of pefu/kasin seems more in favour of the other.
i(kano/n] fit for, strong enough for, capable of.
a)/lupon] causing no pain, no painful impression or repulsion, in consequence of the absence of all the ordinary deformities or disfigurements incident to old age.

i)sxu/s] bodily strength, is defined, in a very superficial and perfunctory manner, with a special view to strength in personal encounter— as appears in the several forms it takes, though it is afterwards more definitely expressed in a)gwnistikh\ a)reth/—as the power of moving some one else (e(/teron may possibly be neuter, something else, anything whatsoever), by pulling, or pushing, or lifting (possibly referring to the encounter of Herakles with Antaeus, who showed his great strength by ‘lifting’ him off the ground into the air; or, if e(/teron be neuter, by lifting any heavy weight), or squeezing, or crushing; which seems to be intended for
a complete analysis of the different ways in which a person or thing can be ‘moved’ by another.

mei/zoni] agrees with tini/ understood after a)reth/: the accusative mei/zona, with tina/ understood in to\ u(pere/xein, would be more usual. Two MSS read mei/zona. ‘Excellence in size’ implies superiority over the average (people in general), in length (height), depth (thickness), and breadth, but only (superior) to such an extent as not to impede the motions (of the body) by the excess (of size), lit. to one being only so much greater as not to make the body's motions (slower than they otherwise would be, or than they ought to be, i.e.) too slow. *mh=kos, ba/qos, and pla/tos are the three dimensions of space; but it is not quite certain how they are applied here to the proportions of the human body; mh=kos or ba/qos might possibly represent the abstract height. I have taken mh=kos in this sense here because it is found in Homer to represent the ‘stature’ of a man, and ma/kistos for ‘tallest’. Odys. l/. 309, Otus and Ephialtes, ou(\s dh\ maki/stous qre/ye zei/dwros a)/roura, and 312, a)ta\r mh=ko/s ge gene/sqhn e)nneo/rguioi. u/. 71, of the daughters of Pandareus, mh=kos d' e)/por) *)/artemis a(gnh/, and in Xenoph. de Rep. Lac. II 5, ei)s mh=kos au)ca/nesqai ta\ sw/mata. *mh=kos therefore is the man's height, pla/tos the breadth of the body, measuring from right to left, and ba/qos the depth or thickness, measuring in the direction backwards and forwards. *ba/qos, though it can be applied to vertical measure, up and down, yet as in the ordinary language it represents only what is below us, and not what is above, could hardly be applied to the more than average stature of a tall man.
e)k mege/qous kai\ i)sxu/os] for boxing and wrestling; ta/xous, for the foot-race.

kai\ ga\r o( taxu\s i)sxuro/s e)stin] seems to be added as a mere passing observation, or note upon ta/xous: and the ga/r, which implies that this clause gives a reason for the preceding, must therefore be regarded as due to mere carelessness of writing, there being no logical connexion between the two sentences. (If there were any such connexion between the two, the meaning could only be, that the relation of strength and speed as genus and species, speed being only a variety of strength, is the reason for the introduction of ta/xos into the list of agonistic virtues: the fact being that this could only be a reason for omitting it.)

r(i/ptein iacere, r(iptei=n iactare, of a repeated action. Hermann ad Aiac.
235, Trach. 776. See also Lobeck, Aj. 239, p. 177Lobeck in his elaborate dissertation on the question seems to leave the matter in doubt; and no doubt, from the uncertainty of the MSS readings, the distinction of the two forms of the verb being shewn in most cases merely by the difference of accent, it is difficult to decide in any particular case which of the two forms is to be preferred: and Lobeck shews by examples that (so far as the reading is to be depended on) the same notion of the verb is expressed indifferently by either form. At the same time in the somewhat obscure summing up at the conclusion of his note, he seems (as I understand him) to be in favour, as a general principle, of the hypothesis, that a difference of form in the termination of a verb radically the same (he cites i)/llw or ei)/llw and its numerous varieties as a remarkable instance) does express a corresponding variety in the signification; as in the instance given, the various terminations correspond to different varieties of the general notion of ‘rolling’.. This distinction, which has been doubted by some scholars, is now I believe generally accepted. At all events it applies very well here, where the simple notion of flinging or hurling, once for all, from you, as a stone, would be quite inappropriate to the motion of the legs intended to be described. r(iptei=n ta\ ske/lh is to ‘toss about’ or ‘swing the legs’, backwards and forwards, again and again.
kinei=n po/rrw] ‘to take long strides’.
w)=sai th=| plhgh=|] in boxing, to push or thrust away from you by the blow, so as aliquem de statu deicere; as when you knock a man down.

a)mfote/rois tou/tois] These two last, boxing and wrestling; not running. Supply therefore, in explanation of a)mfote/rois, qli/bein kai\ kate/xein, kai\ w)=sai th=| plhgh=| duna/menos. Victorius (and also Krause, u. s., p. 534, n. 1) quotes Plut. Symp. 4, o(/ti ga\r me/miktai to\ pagkra/tion e)/k te pugmh=s kai\ pa/lhs, dh=lon, and Quint. Inst. Orat. II 8, 13, as confirming Aristotle's statement. Other ancient authorities are given in Krause's notes.
On the pancratium, and the size, strength, and skill required by those who engaged in it, see Krause, u. s. p. 534—538, abschn. VI § 41.
