gives a summary of the contents of the first division of the analysis of the three kinds of Rhetoric, the deliberative. ‘We have treated of the general objects of the public speaker's aims and efforts, viz. of what is good or expedient in itself, and in relation to something else; and the topics from which arguments may be drawn on these subjects (in cc. 4—7); and we have further pointed out the channels and modes (dia\ ti/nwn kai\ pw=s) by which we may supply ourselves with materials for the treatment of the characters and institutions of the various forms of government; but only so far as was (commensurate with) suitable to the present occasion, because (ga/r) exact detail (is not required here, and) is to be found (if required) in the Politics’.

div2.p: The following passage of Cicero, de Or. II 84. 342, will serve as a commentary on the treatment of ‘good’ and ‘virtue’ in this chapter and c. 6; and also on the distinction of virtues in respect of their utility, § 6:

Perspicuum est igitur alia esse in homine optanda, alia laudanda. Genus, forma, vires, opes, divitiae, ceteraque quae fortuna dat aut extrinsecus aut corpori, non habent in se veram laudem, quae deberi virtuti uni putatur; sed tamen quod ipsa virtus in earum rerum usu ac moderatione maxime cernitur, tractanda in laudationibus etiam haec sunt naturae et fortunae bona: [this is illustrated.] Virtus autem, quae per se ipsa laudabilis et sine qua nihil laudari potest, tamen habet plures partes, quarum alia est alia ad laudationem aptior. Sunt enim aliae virtutes quae videntur in moribus hominum et quadam comitate ac beneficentia positae; aliae quae in ingenii aliqua facultate aut animi magnitudine et robore. Nam clementia, iustitia, benignitas, fides, fortitudo in periculis communibus iucunda est auditu in laudationibus; omnes enim hae virtutes non tam ipsis qui eas habent quam generi hominum fructuosae putantur.

div3.p: The subject of this chapter is the analysis of virtue and vice, the noble and disgraceful, moral right and wrong, as the objects of praise and blame, and therefore furnishing materials for the epideictic or encomiastic branch of Rhetoric, of which praise and blame are the characteristic functions.

We may also derive from this analysis topics of the h)/qh, characters or dispositions which serve to give the speech an ethical colour. This is to be effected by producing by the speech (artistically, not by any evidence of character previously acquired, ‘authority’) the impression upon the audience of our truthfulness and probity; of our practical wisdom which will enable us to give them useful advice, and finally of our goodwill towards themselves; this being ‘the second mode of persuading’ (h)=n ‘was said’, cf. c. 2 §§ 3, 4): because the same materials can be employed in representing ourselves as well as others as ‘trustworthy in respect of virtue’, as men of such a character as can be depended upon.

marks a division of panegyrics, the ordinary subjects of the e)pideiktiko\n ge/nos of Rhetoric. A panegyric may be written and delivered ‘with or without a serious purpose (spoudh/)’; the latter are burlesques. On these, and the subjects of encomiastic speeches in general, see Introd. p. 121—123. In the burlesque kind, anything
however mean and trifling, ‘inanimate things, or any insignificant animal’, may be made the object of the panegyric. But as the materials, the topics which furnish the arguments, are the same in both, we may include the burlesque with the serious in our treatment of them in the way of examples or illustrations.

a)/yuxa kai\ tw=n a)/llwn zw/|wn to\ tuxo/n] Thus Polycrates, the Sophist, wrote in praise of pots, and pebbles, and mice (see note on II 24. 2); and others on humble-bees and salt (Isocr. Hel. § 12). As an extant specimen of these trifling productions we have the mui/as e)xkw/mion of Lucian (cf. note on Isocr. Paneg. § 189). S.]

kalo/n] See note on c. 7, 24. Eth. Eudem. VII 15. 3, tw=n ga\r a)gaqw=n pa/ntwn te/lh e)sti/n, a(\ au)ta\ au(tw=n e(/neka/ e)stin ai(reta/. tou/twn de\ kala\ o(/sa di) au(ta\ o)/nta pa/nta e)paineta/ e)stin. tau=ta ga/r e)stin e)f' w(=n ai(/ te pra/ceis ei)si\n e)painetai\ kai\ au)ta\ e)paineta/, dikaiosu/nh kai\ au)th\ kai\ ai( pra/ceis k.t.l. It has either a moral aspect (marked by the characteristic e)paineto/n; on praise and blame, approbation and disapprobation, as characteristic of virtue and vice, see Introd. on e)/painos, Append. B, p. 212, seq.), what is right and noble, an end in itself, di) au(to/; or is physical and sensual, what is beautiful, in which pleasure always accompanies that which is otherwise good. The ugly may be good in the sense of useful, but gives no pleasure.

Virtue therefore must of necessity be kalo/n, because it comes under the first definition of it, it is good in itself, beneficial to the individual and to society, and also has the stamp and seal of general ‘approbation’.

a)reth/] The definition of virtue here given compared with the celebrated one of Eth. Nic. II 6, init., and the detailed treatment of the list of virtues and the meagre and incomplete account here given of them, contrasted with the elaborate and ingenious analysis of them in the third and fourth books of the same work, is a most striking illustration of the difference between the point of view and method of treatment in the popular Rhetoric and comparatively scientific Ethics. For example, the definition here given coincides in no single point with that of the Ethics. It regards virtue solely on the side of its usefulness, probably because this feature of it is likely to produce the greatest effect upon the popular mind. Instead of a e(/cis it is a mere du/namis, an undeveloped faculty or power—this is most expressly denied in Eth. N. II 4, 1106 a 5,
—the proai/resis, the special moral element is omitted, as is also the doctrine of the mean in its application to virtue, and the standard by which this relative mean is to be determined.

Regarded as a du/namis, virtue is a practical faculty, employed in ‘providing and securing or keeping good things’—for oneself, apparently, by the exercise of any a)reth/, excellence or accomplishment bodily or mental—and secondly, ‘a power of conferring benefits, or doing services, many and great, in fact all in everything (on all occasions)’. pa/ntwn peri\ pa/nta is doubtless, as Victorius intimates, a proverbial expression, more especially as it is found in a letter of Cicero to Cassius (ad Div. XV 17. 1, sed expecta pa/nta peri\ pa/ntwnCicero has altered the form and the application of the proverb. In the text it means ‘all kinds on all occasions’, in Cicero it is ‘all the news about everything’.). This is the moral side of virtue so far as it appears in its usefulness to society.

me/rh a)reth=s] Comp. 5 § 9. The list of virtues here given differs from that in the Nic. Ethics II 7, and III 9—IV 15, in the following particulars. All the moral virtues from dikaiosu/nh to pra|o/ths inclusive appear in the Ethics, dikaiosu/nh being treated separately in Bk. V, and the two intellectual virtues of the speculative and practical parts of the intellect, fro/nhsis practical wisdom, and sofi/a speculative wisdom or philosophy, in Bk. VI. sofi/a is omitted in the detailed explanation of the virtues, most likely because it has very little in common with Rhetoric, and would be useless to the rhetorician. prao/ths, which in the Ethics is ranked, as well as here, amongst the virtues, which are there e(/ceis, here duna/meis, in the second book of the Rhetoric becomes a pa/qos, so that it belongs to all the three divisions of our moral nature distinguished in Eth. Nic. II 4. The anonymous mean between filotimi/a and a)filotimi/a is omitted in our list, as well as the three social virtues of an accomplished gentleman, viz. a)lh/qeia, eu)trapeli/a, and fili/a, and also the two virtues of the pa/qh, viz. ai)dw/s and ne/mesis. No notice is taken here of e)gkra/teia, the examination of which occupies the earlier part of Bk. VII, but this perhaps may be considered as an additional argument in favour of ascribing that book to Eudemus, which on all grounds is most probable.

The most useful virtues are the highest and greatest, by the foregoing definition. Of these, justice and courage, the one most serviceable in peace, the other in war, are for this reason most held in honour amongst mankind: and in the next degree liberality, because it is lavish, and does not enter into competition with others (a)ntagwni/zesqai) for money, which everybody else covets more than anything besides.

Justice is the virtue which assigns to every one his due, and in this shews obedience to the law. This virtue and the two following, which are all specially characterised by ‘obedience to the law’, are thereby invested with a political and objective character, and distinguished from the remainder, which are rather subjective and individual. The end and object of the true statesman is to make the citizens good, and this must be effected by training them in obedience to the laws of that form of government under which they live; the type of the perfect citizen varying under various constitutions. dokei= de\ kai\ o( kat' a)lh/qeian politiko\s peri\ tau/thn (th\n a)reth\n) ma/lista peponh=sqai: bou/letai ga\r tou\s poli/tas a)gaqou\s poiei=n kai\ tw=n no/mwn u(phko/ous. Eth. N. I 13, sub init.

w(s o( no/mos] sc. le/gei, keleu/ei, prosta/ttei; i.e. the law settles the legal rights of the citizens of a state, the observance of which is justice. Injustice is the cause of unfair distribution, to injustice it is owing that men take what does not belong to them, ta\ a)llo/tria, and thus it acts or operates in disobedience to the law. Of the three kinds of justice distinguished in Eth. N. VI, this takes in only the first, dikaiosu/nh dianemhtikh/, c. 6; the other two are (1) diorqwtikh/ or e)panorqwtikh/ ‘corrective’ justice, which ratifies and corrects wrong, and restores plaintiff and defendant to an equality, c. 7; and (2) reciprocal justice, to\ a)ntipeponqo/s the lex talionis, the law of retaliation or reciprocity transferred to commercial justice, which regulates exchanges and contracts of all kinds, c. 8.

a)ndri/a] In the chapter on this virtue of ‘gratitude’ in the Nic. Ethics, III 11, a)ndrei/a (as it is there written) is first defined in general terms as a virtue residing in a mean state in things that inspire confidence, or encouragement, or boldness, ta\ qarrale/a, on the one hand, and fear on the other: its sole object and aim in choosing a course of action and encountering danger being to\ kalo/n, the right and noble as an ultimate end, because it is so, and for no other reason; which implies also the opposite, the spurning of what is base and disgraceful. This is the general notion of fortitude, the endurance of pain, labour, danger, in the pursuit of an unselfish, honourable, high and noble object, when the opposite course would be base, mean, disgracefulActs of fortitude must likewise be deliberate and voluntary, dei= d' ou) di) a)na/gshn a)ndrei=on ei=nai, a)ll) o(/ti kalo/n (1116 b 2).. From this are
then distinguished five popular notions of ‘courage’, a)ndrei/a in a narrower sense, none of which can be properly called ‘fortitude’. The first of these is political courage, the courage of a citizen, as a member of a state, and living under and directed by its laws, described in 1116 a 17—b 2. And this seems to be the view of courage which is taken here, the terms employed in each corresponding very closely, dokou=si ga u(pome/nein tou\s kindu/nous (this restricts the virtue to facing danger and gives it a narrower sense than ‘fortitude’) oi( poli=tai dia\ ta\ e)k tw=n no/mwn e)piti/mia kai\ ta\ o)nei/dh kai\ dia\ ta\s tima/s, a 18. di) ai)dw= (it is due to a sense of honour) kai\ dia\ kalou= o)/recin, timh=s ga/r, kai\ fugh
 o)nei/dous, ai)sxrou= o)/ntos, a 28. Further, one of the characteristics of this form of a)ndrei/a reappears in Eth. Eudem. III 1. 13, as belonging to political courage, mi/a me
 politikh/: au(/th d' e)sti
 h( di) ai)dw= ou)=sa, and another § 16, dia\ no/mon de\ h( politikh\ a)ndrei/a. The prominence of the military character of this virtue is likewise marked in the description both of the Ethics and Rhetoric by u(pome/nein tou\s kindu/nous in the one, and by e)/rgwn e)n kindu/nois § 8, and h(...e)n pole/mw| § 6, in the other; so that it seems that there is sufficient warrant for the identification of the two; the duty to the state and obedience to its laws being again made the ground of the obligation to practise this virtue.

The third virtue, swfrosu/nh, temperantia, is likewise represented under a political aspect. It is a virtue by which men's bodily appetites are regulated according to the dictates of the laws of the state, ‘are so disposed towards bodily pleasures as the law enjoins’. In Eth. Nic. III cc. 13, 14, there is no regular definition of it; but we gather from the contents of the two chapters that it is a virtue of self-control, which consists in a mean state with regard to the indulgence in bodily pleasures, (pains having less to do with the virtue); and in a due measure or estimate of the value of them. It is thus a ‘mean’ between a)kolasi/a, ‘excessive indulgence in them’, and a)naisqhsi/a, total ‘insensibility’. II 7, 1107 b 4.

e)leuqerio/ths] The principal difference between the views taken of the virtues in the Ethics and Rhetoric respectively, is that in the latter they are regarded solely on the side of their utility to society—a political view—in the Ethics they are confirmed habits or states resulting from a due regulation of the elementary pa/qh out of which they are formed and developed. They are ‘relative means’, meso/thtes pro\s h(ma=s, mean states varying in individuals according to the special character of each, lying at a variable distance between two extremes of the pa/qh out of which they grow, the proper mean in any given case being determined by the fro/nhsis or practical wisdom, the objective standard being the collective judgment of those who are specially endowed with this faculty, the fro/nimoi. Consequently here ‘liberality’ in expense is represented as a dis
position or habit inclined to do good, to make oneself useful in dealing with money.

megaloyuxi/a] ‘high-mindedness’ is represented in the same way as the preceding, as a virtue which is ‘productive of benefits’, shews its utility, ‘on a large scale’; to which ‘little-mindedness’, meanness of spirit, is the opposite. This is a very different and much narrower view of the virtue than that which is conveyed by the description of it in Nic. Eth. IV 7—9, which is summed up in the brief phrase at the end of c. 9, h( me\n ou)=n megaloyuxi/a peri\ timh/n e)sti mega/lhn, and defined c. 7, 1123 b 2, dokei= de\ megalo/yuxos ei)=nai o( mega/lwn au(to\n a)ciw=n a)/cios w)/n. The megalo/yuxos of the Ethics is a man of high aims and lofty spirit, full of scorn and contempt for all that is beneath him, men and things, and with a pride which is justified by his deserts: pride without merits to support it is no longer proper pride, a virtue; but degenerates into vanity xauno/ths, an undue sense of one's own merits.

mikroyuxi/a de\ tou)nanti/on] is put in brackets by the recent Edd. as a gloss. It certainly seems to be superfluous, as it is repeated in the following sentence; and also if it be retained, mikropre/peia and mikroyuxi/a are both contrasted as opposites with megalopre/peia, which in the latter case is certainly incorrect. At the same time if the words are omitted the repetition of a)reth/ is quite equally objectionable.

megalopre/peia] ‘magnificence’ in expenditure, is distinguished from ‘liberality’ merely by this, that whereas the one is peri\ pa/sas ta\s e)n xrh/masi pra/ceis (every kind of money transactions), magnificence is peri\ dapanhra\s mo/non, ‘those alone in which a large cost is involved’. Eth. N. IV 4, sub init. It is only to men distinguished either by birth or reputation, or anything else that confers distinction, that this virtue is suitable —in others it is no virtue at all, 1122 b 30. Plato and his dramatis personae sometimes add megalopre/peia to the four cardinal virtues, the classication which he usually adopts. Meno 74 A, 88 A. Rep. II 402 C, VI 490 E, 494 B, VII 536 A, VIII 560 E. It does not, however, exactly correspond with Aristotle's interpretation, but has a wider and more general signification. See Rep. VI 486 A, where it is applied to the dia/noia. It seems from the definition, (o(/roi, 412 E, a)ci/wsis kata\ logismo
 o)rqo
 to
 semno/taton), to be a nearer approach to Aristotle's megaloyuxi/a.

fro/nhsis] appears much in the same character here as in Eth Nic. VI 5—9, where it is analysed at length. It is ‘practical wisdom which shews itself in the discrimination between good and evil, and particularly moral good and evil, in general, dokei= dh\ froni/mou ei)=nai to\ du/nasqai kalw=s bouleu/sasqai peri\ ta\ au(tw=| a)gaqa\ kai\ sumfe/ronta, ou) kata\ me/ros, oi(=on poi=a pro\s u(gi/eian h)\ i)sxu/n, a)lla\ poi=a pro\s to\ eu)= zh=|n, 1140 a 25. dia\ tou=to *perikle/a kai\ tou\s toiou/tous froni/mous oi)o/meqa ei)=nai, o(/ti ta\ au(toi=s a)gaqa
kai\ ta\ toi=s a)nqrw/pois du/nantai qewrei=n: ei)=nai de\ toiou/tous h(gou/meqa tou\s oi)konomikou\s kai\ tou\s politikou/s, Ib. 1140 b 7. a)reth/ ti/s e)stin kai\ ou) te/xnh, b 24. duoi=n d' o)/ntoin meroi=n th=s yuxh=s tw=n lo/gon e)xo/ntwn, qate/rou a)\n ei)/h a)reth/, tou= docastikou=: (or tou= logistikou=, i.e. the dia/noia or reasoning faculty, the discursive reason, as opposed to the nou=s, the speculative, intuitive reason, the organ of the other intellectual virtue sofi/a): h(/ te ga\r do/ca peri\ to\ e)ndexo/menon a)/llws e)/xein, kai\ h( fro/nhsis, b 25. h( de\ fro/nhsis praktikh/, c. 8, 1141 b 31. tw=n kaq' e(/kasta/ e)stin h( fro/nhsis, a(\ gi/netai gnw/rima e)c e)mpeiri/as, c. 9, 1142 a 14.

to\n e)nestw=ta kairo\n] ‘the present (instant) time’. e)nista/nai, ‘to place in’ a position: e)ni/stasqai, e)nsth=nai, e)nesthke/nai, e)nesta/nai, ‘to be placed, set in, stand in’, a position. Hence (2) (I think) of things ‘standing in the way’, and so either (a) close by, ‘present’, ‘instant’, ‘instans’ (tempus, bellum, &c.), ‘impending’, ‘threatening’; (for instans, ‘present’, Quint. V 10. 42, praeteritum, instans, futurum). In grammar, e)nestw\s xro/nos, ‘the present tense’, e)nestw=sa metoxh/, ‘the present participle’, instans tempus (Facc. Lex. s. v.); or (b) ‘to stand in the way’ as an obstacle, impediment, or ‘objection’; as the logical e)nsth=nai and e)/nstasis, of an objection, or contrary instance, to a supposed conclusion; and hence also ‘instance’, something which stands in your way and so possibly attracts your attention, or as a generalisation of the logical ‘instance’ or objection. See Introd. p. 269, and note.

peri\ de\ tw=n a)/llwn] ‘The rest are easily discerned’—‘the rest’ are what follows, the causes namely and consequences of virtue—‘anything that is productive of, because it tends to or promotes (pro/s), virtue, or that is the effect or result of it (ta\ a)p' a)reth=s gino/mena), is estimable and an object of praise (kalo/n). Such things are (the first) the ‘signs’, (the second) the works of virtue (and therefore praiseworthy)’. The shmei=on (Introd. p. 161—163) is the probable—or, in the case of the tekmh/rion, certain—indication of the existence of the thing which it accompanies; from the ‘signs’ of virtue in a man we infer, with more or less probability, its actual existence. Schrader quotes the little tract peri\ a)retw=n kai\ kakiw=n, printed as an appendix to the three Ethical treatises in Bekker's 4to ed. Vol. II p. 1249. It is an abridgment or epitome of Aristotle's account of the virtues in the third and fourth books of the Ethics, with a slight admixture of Platonism and other occasional alterations. e)paineta\ me/n e)sti ta\ kala/, yekta\ de\ ta\ ai)sxra/. kai\ tw=n me\n kalw=n h(gou=ntai ai( a)retai/, tw=n d' ai)sxrw=n ai( kaki/ai. e)paineta\ d) e)sti kai\ ta\ ai)/tia tw=n a)retw=n kai\ ta\ parepo/mena tai=s a)retai=s (these are the ta\ poihtika\ th=s a)reth=s and ‘signs’), kai\ ta\ gino/mena a)p' au)tw=n kai\ ta\ e)/rga au)tw=n, yekta\ de\ ta\ e)nanti/a, 1249 a 26.

peri\ de\ tw=n a)/llwn...i)dei=n] for the more usual ta\ a)/lla i)dei=n. This substitution of a preposition with its case for the direct government of the
verb, has been noticed by Heindorf in the case of ei)s, on Plat. Lys. § 16, and in that of peri/ and a)mfi/, on Phaedo § 65, p. 250 C (in which place peri\ ka/llous takes the place of the nominative); likewise of peri/ and u(pe/r by Bremi on Dem. Olynth. I p. 14. 18 (ap. Schäfer Appar. Crit. ad Demosth. I 208); and a similar use of the Latin, &c. by Heusing, ad Cic. de Off. I 15. 3. Comp. Epist. ad Div. II 17. 1; III 12. 2 (Schäfer). But what has not been observed of this usage is, that it is almost exclusively characteristic of a middle or later period of the Greek language, viz. the fourth century B.C.

The earliest instances I have noted of it are Soph. Oed. Col. 422, e)n de/ moi te/los au)toi=n ge/noito th=sde th=s ma/xhs pe/ri, and Aj. 684, a)mfi\ tou/toisin eu)= sxh/sei. In Plato it is not uncommon, Phaedo 231 D, bou/lesqai peri/ tinos, Rep. IV 427 A, ei)=dos no/mwn pe/ri kai\ politei/as (a good example), Ib. 436 B, kaq' e(/kaston au)tw=n pra/ttomen, Phaedo 249 C (this use of kaq' e(/kaston for the simple accusative is found in various writers; see Stallbaum on Rep. ll. cc.), Ib. VII 533 B, peri\ panto\s lamba/nein, Theaet. 177 B, Gorg. 487 A. But in Demosthenes and Aristotle it becomes quite a usual mode of expression. In the de Fals. Leg. alone it occurs in §§ 6, 7, 64, 167, 239, and probably elsewhere in the same speech.

From Aristotle, with whom it is still more familiar, I will content myself with referring to Rhet. I 15. 1, peri\ tw=n a)te/xnwn...e)pidramei=n, Ib. § 27, peri\ o(/rkwn...dielei=n. II 4. 30; 5. 21, toiou/tous peri\ w(=n (i.e. ou(\s) fobou=ntai, a good example. 18. 4, peri\ mege/qous (i.e. me/geqos) koino/n (e)sti), Ib. 21, init., in both of which it stands for the nominative, as it does also in Pol. VI (IV) 2, 1289 a 11, and III 3, init. Pol. I 1 ult. I 9, 1257 a 5, II 1 init., Ib. c. 4, 1262 b 25, peri\ tou= metafe/rein—pollh\n e)/xei taraxh/n. Eth. N. IV 4 init., peri\ megaloprepei/as dielqei=n, X 1 sub init., 1172 a 26, u(pe\r tw=n toiou/twn —parete/on ei)=nai, where it stands for the accusative. de Insomniis c. 2, 459 a 29, e)pi\ tw=n ferome/nwn—kinei=tai, would be more regularly ta\ fero/mena.

e)pei\ de\ ta\ shmei=a k.t.l.] An exemplification of the preceding rule, and application of it to the special virtues. ‘Seeing that the signs of virtue, and all such things as are works (results, effects), or affections’ (properties, qualities, attributes—on pa/qh and its various senses see Introd. pp. 113—118; on the special sense here, p. 114) ‘of it are kala/’, the same rule will apply to each special manifestation of it, as a)ndri/a. The pa/qh of virtue are illustrated in the examples by a)ndrei/ws, dikai/ws, a)di/kws: these are paqh, ‘affections’, of courage, justice, and injustice, in the sense of ‘what happens to them’, some change they have undergone, consisting in a modification of them in form and signification; as dikai/ws ‘justly’, denotes a certain mode of action, viz. just acting. An exception occurs to the general application of the rule to the special virtues in the case of dikaiosu/nh: in this alone, though it is true of the e)/rga, it is not true of the pa/qh: in other words, in the rest of the virtues the ptw/seis are
su/stoixa, the changes of termination represent true co-ordinates, all being terms referable to the same notion or class, viz. that of virtue, as a)ndri/a, a)ndrei=os, a)ndrei/ws: all are equally kala/ and praiseworthy (see note on c. 7. 27); but in the single case of justice this does not universally apply, for to\ dikai/ws zhmou=sqai, just (deserved) punishment, is not equally praiseworthy with a just act, to\ dikai/ws pra/ttein, but the contrary; since it is more disgraceful than an unjust punishment. (This seems to be a mere fallacy of o(mwnumi/a, ambiguity, equivoque, dikai/ws not standing in the same relation to zhmiou=sqai and pra/ttein: in the one case the ‘justice’ of the act lies in the intention of the actor; in the other it belongs not to the actor, but to the law and the judge who inflicts the punishment. A similar equivocal meaning lies in the word pa/qos: in the rule and the general application of it, it stands for properties or attributes: in the special exception it denotes an ‘affection’ in the sense of suffering or punishment.)

e)f' o(/sois ta\ a)=qla timh/, kala/] The kalo/n is an end in itself; it is independent of all ulterior considerations and aims: therefore any act of which honour alone, and not profit (e)f' o(/sois timh\ ma=llon h)\ xrh/mata) is the prize, is kalo/n: the prize aimed at, or the end of the exertions and efforts, determines the character of those efforts or actions, which are therefore fair and noble like the end at which they aim. timh/ is an end of this kind. Eth. N. I 4, 1096 b 16, kaq' au(ta\ (a)gaqa/) de\ poi=a qei/h| tis a)/n; h)\ (are they not?) o(/sa kai\ monou/mena diw/ketai, oi(=on to\ fronei=n kai\ o(ra=|n kai\ h(donai/ tines kai\ timai/; tau=ta ga\r ei) kai\ di) a)/llo ti diw/komen, o(/mws tw=n kaq' au(ta\ a)gaqw=n qei/h tis a)/n. c. 3, 1095 b 22, timh/ is the end of the politiko\s bi/os, pursued by the xari/entes kai\ praktikoi/, v. 30, dh=lon ou)=n kata/ ge tou/tous h( a)reth\ krei/ttwn. In IV 7—10, timh/ is represented as the end of the megalo/yuxoi and filo/timoi, the sphere in which these two virtues are exercised. c. 7, 1123 b 18, me/giston de\ tou=t' a)\n qei/hmen o(\ toi=s qeoi=s a)pone/momen, kai\ ou(= ma/list) e)fi/entai oi( e)n a)ciw/mati, kai\ to\ e)pi\ toi=s kalli/stois a)=qlon. toiou=ton d) h( timh/.

kai\ o(/sa mh\ au(tou= e(/neka k.t.l.] The general characteristic of all the following topics (to § 19) is disinterestedness; unselfish acts, of which the object is the good of some one else, and not one's own. Any act of this kind, where there is no ulterior end of profit or advantage to oneself, which is done therefore for its own sake, and ‘because it is in itself desirable’, conforms to the definition, § 3, and is kalo/n. So the highest and purest form of friendship or love is distinguished from the two lower forms, those whose end is profit and pleasure. Both of these are selfish; true
friendship is disinterested, oi( boulo/menoi ta)gaqa\ toi=s fi/lois e)kei/nwn e(/neka ma/lista fi/loi, Eth. N. VIII 4 init.; and the true friend is e(/teros au)to/s, IX 9 init. and Ib. 1170 b 6, or a)/llos au)to/s, c. 4, 1165 a 31, ‘a second self’ (not one's own self) alter ego. And on the other hand, e)pitimw=si toi=s e(autou\s ma/list' a)gapw=si, kai\ w(s e)n ai)sxrw=| filau/tous a)pokalou=si, dokei= te o( me\n fau=los e(autou= xa/rin pa/nta pra/ttein, kai\ o(/sw| moxqhro/teros h)=| tosou/tw| ma=llon: o( d) e)pieikh\s dia\ to\ kalo/n, k.t.l. IX 8, init. And in the Politics, III 7, the distinction of the two classes of government, normal and abnormal, o)rqai/ and parekba/seis (deviations from the true standard), is determined by the end of each, according as it is to\ koino/n or to\ i)/dion sumfe/ron: the public interest of others, or the private interest of the governors themselves, one or several; in other words, it is determined by the selfishness or disinterestedness of the governing powers of the state.

o(/sa u(pe/r te—to\ au(tou=] This clause seems certainly out of place here, though Schrader defends it as an example of ta\ a(plw=s a)gaqa/. ‘Qui enim ut patriam iuvet commoda sua negligit, is bonum simpliciter praefert illi quod huic bonum foret’: that is, he prefers general to special or particular good, (his own). But this does not account for the te, which if the words are retained in the received order is as superfluous as it is inexplicable. The sense would be improved and the particle accounted for by transferring the clause so as to follow ta\ toiau=ta (§ 17 ad fin.) The passage will then run thus: ‘and all absolute (or general, see note on a(plw=s, c. 2 § 4) goods: and all natural goods (things which are naturally good, in themselves, and so good for all) and (therefore, or kai/, ‘that is’) things which are not (specially and particularly) good to oneself (au)tw=|), appropriated to particular individuals, because such things (things that are thus special and particular, and not common to others) carry with them the notion of selfishness or self-interest’. Here the clause comes in as the first example—‘anything, namely, which a man does either (te) for his country, to the neglect of his own interest, or (kai/) anything that a dead man may have the benefit of, rather than one who is living (such as posthumous fame, funeral orations, monuments to his memory); because such honours paid (or advantages accruing) to a man while he is alive, involve or imply more self-interest’, and are therefore less kala/.

ta\ a(plw=s a)gaqa/] ‘Talia sunt quae absolute, citra respectum ad hunc hominem, locum, tempusve bona sunt. Unde tw=| a(plw=s, illi quod simpliciter tale dicitur, opponuntur ta\ au)tw=| Rhet. I 7. 35, et III 13. 4, ta\ tou/tois III 19. I, ta\ tini/ Top. III 1 (116 a 21), ta\ h(mi=n Magn. Mor. I 1, ta\ pro\s a)/llhla de Gen. An. VII (sic); ta\ ph=|, pou=, pote/, pro/s ti, de Soph. El. c. 5, 166 b 22.’ Schrader. Add h)\ a(plw=s h)\ e)kei/nois, Eth. N. I 11, 1101 b 3. ou)de\ o( a(plw=s, a)ll' o( pw=s, Ib. II 4, 1106 a 1.

kai\ ta\ th=| fu/sei a)gaqa/] Comp. 7. 33, to\ au)tofue/s. ‘Sunt profecto laudationibus minime incongruentes materiae, genus, parentes, patria, pul
critudo, ingenii acumen, solertia, docilitas, tenax memoria, ingenita animi magnitudo, et quae a natura proveniunt bona alia.’ Schrader.
au)tw=| a)gaqa/] ‘good for him’, that is, for this or that individual. See note on c. 7. 35, to\ au)to\ kai\ a(plw=s, and Schrader (quoted above on ta\ a(plw=s a)gaqa/).

ta\ eu)ergeth/mata] ‘any benefits conferred’, because they are necessarily conferred on others, and therefore, so far, more praiseworthy than acquisitions. These are distinguished from eu)pragi/ai peri\ a)/llous (ante), which are ‘any good and noble deeds done in the service of others, and not for oneself’, for the same reason as the preceding. Eth. Nic. IV 15, 1163 a 1, kalo\n de\ to\ eu)= poiei=n mh\ i(/na a)ntipa/qh|, w)fe/limon de\ to\ eu)ergetei=sqai.

ta\ ga\r ai)sxra/ k.t.l.] ‘for shameful things we are all ashamed of, when we say, do, or are intending to do them’. Sappho's verses, for instance, in answer to Alcaeus,—‘something I would say, but shame prevents me’—she infers from this that it was something to be ashamed of, ai)sxro/n, and replies, ‘Hadst thou yearned after things good or fair, and had not thy tongue stirred up mischief to utter it, shame had not possessed thine eyes, but thou wouldst have spoken of the thing that is right’. The third line in particular of this Alcaic stanza requires correction, and there is not much help to be derived from the Aristotelian MSS. In the first, Blomfield, Mus. Crit. I p. 17, reads i)=ke/ t' e)slw=n: and Hermann (much better), El. Metr. Gr. III 16, de stroph. min. i(=ke/ s) (‘reached thee’, the Homeric i(/kein), from the reading i(/kes of one MS. Bergk, Fragm. Lyr. Gr. p. 607, follows MS A^{c} in reading h)=xe and the Aeolic e)slw=n. The third line, which in the MSS appears as ai)dw/s ke/n se ou)k ei)=xen o)/mmat), without varia lectio, is written by Blomfield, u. s., ai)dw/s ken ou)xi/ t' o)/ppat) ei)=xen: by Hermann, ai)dw/s ke/ teus oi)k ei)=xen o)/ppat): and by Bergk, ai)dw/|s ke s' ou)k a)/n h)=xen o)/ppat) (surely ke and a)/n thus repeated in different forms and almost immediate juxtaposition is indefensible): none of these seems to be satisfactory, but I have nothing better to suggest. [In Bergk's 2nd ed. p. 674 the fragment is printed as follows: ai) d' h)=xes e)/slwn i)/meron h)\ ka/lwn, | kai\ mh/ ti *vei/phn glw=ss' e)ku/ka ka/kon, | ai)/dws ke/ s' ou) ki/xanen o)/mmat), | a)ll' e)/leges peri\ tw= dikai/ws. S.]

The fact that the eye is the principal organ of the manifestation of
some of the feelings or emotions, as love, shame, fear, is here, as often elsewhere, expressed poetically by the phrase that ‘shame has its seat in the eye’. Compare the proverb in II 6. 18, to\ e)n o)fqalmoi=s ei)=nai ai)dw=, where see note.

kai\ peri\ w(=n a)gwniw=si mh\ fobou/menoi] ‘and things about which we are excessively anxious or distress ourselves, without fear’: the acquisition of which causes us a violent mental struggle (a)gw/n), distress, or anxiety, ‘agony’ in our exertions to attain, or in the fear of losing, it. The addition of mh\ fobou/menoi is made here, because fear is the usual concomitant of the emotion, and generally included in the notion. Probl. II 31, h)\ o(/ti a)gwni/a fo/bos ti/s e)sti pro\s a)rxh\n e)/rgou (Vict.). a)gwnia=|n belongs to that class of verbs which imply a diseased state or condition of the mind or body; see note on pneustia=|n, I 2. 18.
The anxious feeling is usually excited about the kind of good things that ‘tend to our reputation’; and this is why they are praiseworthy.
‘The virtues (excellences) and functions of men and things naturally worthier, are nobler and more praiseworthy, as in man than in woman’.

ai( a)polaustikai/ (a)retai/)] ‘those which contribute to the gratification or enjoyment of others rather than of ourselves, of which justice is an instance’. a)po/lausis is not here confined to sensual gratification, its proper meaning. In Eth. N. I. 3, Sardanapalus, the type of sensuality, is taken as the representative of the bi/os a)polaustiko/s: note on 1 5. 7. Here again it is the unselfishness that is laudable.

kai\ to\ tou\s e)xqrou\s timwrei=sqai ma=llon] ‘and the heavier vengeance on, punishment of, one's enemies’ (ma=llon may be either to punish them in a higher degree, the more the better; or as contrasted with katalla/ttesqai, ‘rather than the reverse’), and ‘refusing to be reconciled, come to terms, with them’. The reason being, that ‘retaliatory’ or ‘reciprocal justice’ (note on § 7) requires this, and therefore it is right, and of course laudable; and also because ‘not to be beaten’ (an unyielding resolution)
is a sign of a ‘manly character’. Comp. I 6. 26 (a)gaqa\) ta\ toi=s e)xqroi=s kaka/, and § 29. This was a constant article of the popular morality, and is cited as such here: see, for instance, Xen. Mem. IV 2, 14 seq. Rhet. ad Alex. 1 (2), 13, 14. Again in Aristotle's Rhet. II 5. 5, Eur. Ion 1045—7, Med. 808, Cic. de Off. I 7. 2.

‘Victory and honour are noble and praiseworthy things; for they are desirable though unproductive (see c. 5. 7, note infra § 26), and manifest (are signs of) an excess, superiority, higher degree, of virtue’, i.e. a higher degree than the virtues which they crown would attain without them: a man may be good without them; with them he must be better. Comp. Eth. N. IV 8 init. oi( ga\r eu)genei=s a)ciou=ntai timh=s kai\ oi( dunasteu/ontes h)\ oi( ploutou=ntes: e)n u(peroxh=| ga/r, to\ d' a)gaqw=| u(pere/xon pa=n e)ntimo/teron. Comp. infra § 39.

mnhmoneuta/] ‘things to be, capable of being, or that deserve to be, remembered’; as eu)mnhmo/neuta (infra) is ‘easy to be remembered’. mnhmoneu/mata, which Victorius adopts upon the superior authority of MSS, is monumenta, memorials, elogia, et quae memoriam alicuius ornant. He does not seem to have observed, what Bekker, who prefers the former, doubtless did, though he does not say so, that ma=llon can be construed with the adjective mnhmoneuta/, but hardly, or not so well, with the substantive mnhmoneu/mata.
a(\ mh\ zw=nti e(/petai] ‘things that outlast life, that follow a man beyond the grave’, as posthumous fame.

oi(=s timh\ a)kolouqei=] Honour itself, especially as contrasted with profit (supra § 16), imparts a praiseworthy character as the prize of action, and is itself kalo/n and a thing to be praised (§ 25, supra). It must therefore convey this in some measure to everything, particularly actions, by which it is attended upon or accompanied.

ta\ peritta/] (see note on 6. 28) are kala/ as well as a)gaqa/. They are thus illustrated by Schrader. ‘Quae aliis sui generis praestant. Gellius I XIII P. Crassus Mucianus traditur quinque habuisse rerum bonarum maxima et praecipua, quod esset ditissimus, quod nobilissimus, quod eloquentissimus, quod iuris consultissimus, quod Pontifex Maximus. Velleius (de Pompeio), II 53, Vir in id evectus super quod ascendi non potest.’

ta\ mo/nw| u(pa/rxonta] ta\ i)/dia kai\ a(\ mhdei/s, 6. 28. The difference between the two lies in this, that the topic of 6. 28 denotes positive good, as excellences, accomplishments, personal or intellectual advantages, which are peculiar to a man, and shared by no one else; here they rather refer to
peculiar actions, or qualities that can be manifested in action, which are more easily remembered, and therefore more the objects of praise, and in this sense kalli/w: e)k pra/cewn o( e)/painos, § 32.

‘In bibliotheca, quae prima in urbe ab Asinio Pollione publicata est, unius M. Varronis viventis posita imago est, Plin. VII 30. L. Metello tribuit populus Romanus quod nunquam ulli alii ab condito aevo ut quoties in senatum iret curru veheretur ad curiam. Plin. VII 43.’ Schrader. I have quoted these instances because from Schrader's point of view they very well illustrate the topic. But I believe they are not exactly what Aristotle had in his mind when he wrote the words. These are not exactly subjects of ‘praise’, which the topics of this chapter deal with, exclusively or more immediately. ta\ peritta/ and ta\ mo/nw| u(pa/rxonta are to be taken together, the latter being a step higher in degree than the former. ta\ peritta/ are distinguished and exceptional (as Schrader puts it) excellences, qualities, achievements. ta\ mo/nw| u(pa/rxonta are a step beyond, ‘unique’.

kth/mata a)/karpa] note on 5. 7, e)/sti de\ xrh/sima ma=llon. A pleasuregarden on this principle is a finer thing and more deserving of approbation than a market-garden from which you make a profit. The reason here given for this preference is different to that assigned in Eth. N. IV 9 (quoted in the note referred to). There it is accounted for by the selfsufficiency or independence (au)ta/rkeia) that it implies; here by its being more in accordance with the gentleman's character, in contrast with the vulgarity of trade and money-making.

ta\ par' e(ka/stois i)/dia] These are special pursuits, modes of action, manners, and customs cultivated in particular countries, ‘national’ and ‘peculiar to them’. In England, for instance, special skill in cricket and other athletic exercises gains a man applause; in Greece, running, boxing, wrestling, chariot-racing, are the great games. In Europe a man is applauded for his skill in dancing, which the Chinese utterly contemn, and regard as a useless waste of labour. Quint. Inst. Or. III 7. 24, Minus Lacedaemone studia literarum quam Athenis honoris merebuntur; plus patientia, fortitudo.

o(/sa shmei=a/ e)sti tw=n par' e(ka/stois e)painoume/nwn] ‘all signs, or distinctive marks, of habits (characters, actions), that are approved in particular countries, as the habit of wearing long hair in Lacedaemon. This is a ‘sign’ of a gentleman, a character very much approved in that country. It is a sign of this, because with long hair it is difficult to perform any menial taskou) ga oi=o/n t' e)pithdeu=sai ta\ th=s a)reth=s zw=nta bi/on ba/nauson h| qhtiko/n, Pol. III 5, 1278 a 20., and therefore the wearing it shews that menial occupations are alien from that character. Gaisford quotes, Xenoph. de Rep. Lac. XI 3, e)fh=ke de\ (Lycurgus sc.) kai\ koma=|n toi=s u(pe th
 h(bhtikh
 h(liki/an, nomi/zwn ou(/tw kai\ mei/zous a)
 kai\ e)leuqeriwte/rous kai\ gorgote/rous fai/nesqai. [Aristoph. Aves, 1282, e)lakwnoma/noun a(/pantes a(/nqrwpoi to/te, e)ko/mwn k.t.l. S.]

qhtiko/n] *qh=tes, qhteu/ein, denote hired service in agriculture, but not slavery; the qh/s is no doulos. In this sense both words are used by Homer. The qh=tes formed the fourth and lowest class under the Solonian constitution. At Athens, in Aristotle's time, the qh=tes, to\ qhtiko\n (plh=qos), still denotes the class of paid agricultural labourers, as an order of the state or population; and is expressly distinguished from the ba/nausoi or texni=tai, artisans and petty manufacturers, who are still hired labourers, but work at mechanical employments, and in towns, forming with the others the lowest order of the population of the state. In Pol. III 5, ba/nausos and qh/s are several times thus distinguished. It is there said that in some constitutions (such as monarchies and aristocracies) neither of these classes is admitted into the governing body; in oligarchies the qh/s cannot, the ba/nausos can, be a citizen. In the account given, VI (IV) 4, 1291 b 14 seq., of the various kinds of population which form the bases of so many different varieties of democracy, we have in line 25 the term xernhtiko/n, of precisely the same import, substituted for qhtiko/n: the other had been already mentioned. In Pol. VII (VI) 4, 1319 a 27, three classes of these lower orders are distinguished, to\ plh=qos to/ te tw=n banau/swn (artisans) kai\ to\ tw=n a)gorai/wn a)nqrw/pwn (small tradesmen or retailers, buyers and sellers in the market, VI (IV) 4, 1291 a 4, le/gw de\ a)gorai=on to\ peri\ ta\s pra/seis kai\ ta\s w)na\s kai\ ta\s e)mpori/as kai\ kaphlei/as diatri=bon), kai\ to\ qhtiko/n. Of all these it is said just before, o( ga\r bi/os fau=los, kai\ ou)qe\n e)/rgon met' a)reth=s. qhtiko/n metaph. = douliko/n, ‘servile, menial’, occurs again Eth. Nic. IV 8, 1125 I.

mhdemi/an e)rga/zesqai ba/nauson te/xnhn] This again applies to Lacedaemon: Gaisford quotes Aelian, V. H. VI 6, ba/nauson de\ ei)de/nai te/xnhn a)/ndra *lakedaimo/nion ou)k e)ch=n. Xen. Oecon. IV 2, kai\ ga\r ai(/ ge banausikai\ kalou/menai kai\ e)pi/r)r(htoi/ ei)si kai\ ei)ko/tws me/ntoi pa/nu a)docou=ntai pro\s tw=n po/lewn (add VI 5).

ba/nauson] Of the various kinds of population of a state, enumerated in Pol. VI (IV) 4, the first is the peri\ th
 trofh
 plh=qos, to\ gewrgiko/n: the second, to\ ba/nauson: e)/sti de\ tou=to to\ peri\ ta\s te/xnas w(=n a)/neu po/lin a)du/naton oi)kei=sqai: tou/twn de\ tw=n texnw=n ta\s me
 e)c a)na/gkhs u(pa/rxein dei=, ta\s de\ ei)s trufh
 h)\ kalw=s zh=|n, 1291 a 1. So that here the fine arts, as well as the necessary, indispensable, or mechanical arts, are all included in the class ba/nausoi. See on this subject Thirlwall, Hist. Gr. (Cab. Cycl. 2nd. ed.) c. 18, Vol. III p. 64, note. Pol. V (VIII) 2, 1337 b 8 seq., ba/nauson d' e)/rgon ei)=nai dei= tou=to nomi/zein kai\ te/xnhn tau/thn kai\ ma/qhsin, o(/sai pro\s ta\s xrh/seis kai\ ta\s pra/ceis ta\s th=s a)reth=s a)/xrhston a)perga/zontai to\ sw=ma tw=n e)leuqe/rwn h)\ th
 yuxh
 h)\ th
 dia/noian. dio\ ta/s te toiau/tas te/xnas o(/sai to\ sw=ma paraskeua/zousi xei=ron diakei=sqai banau/sous kaloi=men, kai\ ta\s misqarnika\s e)rgasi/as: a)/sxolon ga poiou=si th
 dia/noian kai\ tapeinh/n. I 11, 1258 b 37, (tw=n e)rgasiw=n) banau/sotatai e)n ai(=s ta\ sw/mata lwbw=ntai ma/lista. Eth. Eudem. I 4, 1215 a 30, le/gw de\
banau/sous (te/xnas) ta\s e(drai/as kai\ misqarnika/s (arts sedentary and mercenary). The e(drai/as in this last passage explains the bodily degradation and injury of the preceding. Comp. Plato, Rep. VII 522 B, IX 590 B, Phileb. 55 C, Theaet. 176 (Heind. note § 85), (Legg. VIII 4, 846 D No native must learn or practise any handicraft. One art is enough for any man; and the natives or citizens must occupy themselves exclusively in statecraft or public duties). Arts are inferior in dignity in proportion to their necessity or utility, Arist. Metaph. A 1. Cic. de Off. I 42. 5.

e)leuqe/rou...to\ mh\ pro\s a)/llon zh=n] ‘to live with reference to, dependent upon, at the beck and call of, another’. Independence, au)ta/rkeia, is a characteristic of the e)leu/qeros, the ‘free and independent’ citizen. Aristotle is writing at Athens, and for Athenians. So it is said of the megalo/yuxos, Eth. N. IV 8, 1124 b 32, kai\ pro\s a)/llon mh\ du/nasqai zh=|n a)ll' h)\ pro\s fi/lon: douliko/n ga/r. Metaph. A 2, 982 b 25, (Vict.) of h( prw/th filosofi/a, dh=lon w(s di) ou)demi/an au)th\n zhtou=men xrei/an e(te/ran, a)ll' w(/sper a)/nqrwpos, fame/n, e)leu/qeros o( au)tou= e(/neka kai\ mh\ a)/llou w)/n, ou(/tw kai\ au(/th mo/nh e)leuqe/ra ou)=sa tw=n e)pisthmw=n: mo/nh ga\r au)th\ au(th=s e(/neke/n e)stin. Victorius also quotes, in illustration of pro\s a)/llon zh=|n, Dem. (pro Ctesiphonte, as he calls it) de F. Leg. p. 411, toi=s de\ pro\s u(ma=s zw=si kai\ th=s par' u(mw=n timh=s glixome/nois. The import of the phrase is, to look to another in all that you say and do, to direct your life and conduct by the will and pleasure of another; in the relation (pro/s) of servant or dependent to master.

It is to be observed that the reason here assigned for avoiding all mechanical occupations as disreputable, viz. that it destroys a man's independence, so that he cannot subsist without looking to others, places the objection to it upon a different ground to that assigned in the Politics (quoted in the last note), where it is that they disqualify a man for doing his duty to the state.

lhpte/on de\ k.t.l.] ‘and we may assume (or represent, substitute one for the other, on occasion) things (qualities, and the terms expressing them) that are very nearly related to the identical, both in commendation and censure, as that the cautious is cold and designing, the simple (simpleton) worthy and amiable, and the insensible mild and calm’. This lays down the general rule, of which the next topic is a special variety, u(pokorismo/s.

Quint. Inst. Orat. III 7. 25. Idem praecipit (Aristotle in this place) illud quoque, quia sit quaedam virtutibus ac vitiis vicinitas, utendum proxima derivatione verborum ut pro temerario fortem, pro prodigo liberalem, pro avaro parcum vocemus: quae eadem etiam contra valent. Quod quidem orator, id est vir bonus, nunquam faciet, nisi forte communi utilitate ducatur. To the same effect, Cic. Orat. Part XXIII 81 (Schrader). [Liv. XXII 12, (Fabium) pro cunctatore segnem, pro cauto timidum, affingens vicina virtutibus vitia, compellabat. S.]

xrhsto/s for h)li/qios is one of those ironical euphemisms which Plato is so fond of employing; as also are gluku/s, h(du/s, and eu)h/qhs, this last belonging also to the common language. gluku/s, Hipp. Maj. 288 B; h(du/s, in several places, Theaet. 209 E, Gorg. 491 E, Rep. I 337 D, VII 527 D, and elsewhere; Lat. suavis, lepidus. xrhsto/s, Phaedr. 264 B, Theaet. 161 A, 166 A, Rep. V 479 A, &c. Ruhnken ad Tim. p. 131. [On eu)h/qeia, cf. note on Isocr. Paneg. § 169, and Rep. 400 E, quoted infra, p. 175. S.]

kai\ e(/kaston k.t.l.] “and in every case from the accompanying, attendant, qualities (the qualities that come next, but always on the higher and better side; on a)kolouqei=n and its various senses, see note on c. 6. 3) derive (e)k) a term or expression always in the best direction (with the most favourable tendency, interpretatio in melius, putting the most favourable construction on the actual facts of the case); call, for instance, the irascible and insane, ‘simple and straightforward’, and self-will (headstrong, stubborn, obstinate temper; au)qa/dhs, one who pleases himself, au)q-a/dhs, ‘self-pleaser’, and will have his own way), ‘magnificence’, or proper pride, and a due sense of dignity (semno/n)”It seems to me nearly certain that megalopreph= is a mistake, either of the author himself or one of his transcribers, for megalo/yuxon. The two have already been distinguished in this very chapter, §§ 11, 12, and megalopre/peia, when it is distinguished from the other as by Aristotle, and not made to include it as by Plato (see the note on § 12), is altogether unsuitable to express the character of the au)qa/dhs, being confined as it is to liberality in bestowing money on a large scale: whereas the virtue of megaloyuxi/a is precisely what au)qa/deia might be represented to be by the figure u(pokorismo/s, by bestowing on it a ‘flattering’ designation. I refer for the proof of this to the Nic. Eth. IV 7.8: it will be found that semno/ths, another false interpretation which is here put upon au)qa/deia, is also characteristic of the megalo/yuxos. Plato points out the true u(pokorismo/s in the case of megalopre/peia, Rep. VI 560 E, u(pokorizo/menoi...a)swti/an de\ megalopre/peian..

On o)rgi/los Victorius compares Hor. Sat. I 3. 51, at est truculentior atque plus aequo liber: simplex fortisque habeatur, with Cic. de Legg. I 7, solent enim, id quod virorum bonorum est, admodum irasci, and therefore an angry temper may be attributed to a virtuous disposition.

maniko/s represents an excitable, violent, furious temper, which sometimes almost assumes the appearance of raving madness. In Plato it is applied to Chaerephon, Socrates' intimate (in the Charmides, init.), and to Apollodorus, Symp. 173 D, where it expresses a very impetuous, excitable temperament, inclined to extravagant and violent manifestations in feeling and utterance; which is illustrated by the conduct ascribed to him at Socrates' death, Phaedo 117 D.
On a(plou=s, as expressive of character, see note I 2. 4.

au)qa/dhs. In Eth. Eud. II 3, 1221 a 8, III 7, 1233 b 34, semno/ths, proper pride, the due measure of personal dignity in one's bearing and behaviour to others, pro\s e(/teron zh=|n, is a mean between the two extremes, a)reskei/a the defect (over-complacency and obsequiousness), and au)qa/deia the excess (undue contemptuousness katafro/nhsis, and disregard of their feelings and wishes). In the Magn. Mor. I 29, it is likewise the excess of semno/ths, as a)reskei/a is the defect. It is exercised peri\ ta\s e)nteu/ceis, in the ordinary
intercourse of society, and manifests itself in the character oi(=os mhqeni\ e)ntuxei=n mhde\ dialegh=nai, in a wilful and stubborn reserve which repels all social converse. The character is represented in the name itself; which is au)to-a/dhs, ‘self-pleasing’. So that when we give the name of megalo/yuxos and semno/s to one who is really au)sa/dhs, we are substituting a virtue for a vice, a mean state for an excess. au)qa/deia is one of Theophrastus' ‘Characters’ defined by him as a)ph/neia o(mili/as, ‘social brutality’.

The special form of this misapplication of names in praise and censure is called u(pokorismo/s, when it takes the favourable side, and interpretatur in melius. On this figure, the name of which is derived from the endearing terms used by nurses to children (pro\s ko/rhn h)\ ko/ron le/gein a)posmikrou=nta, Tim. Lex., lisping in imitation of them), compare Aesch. c. Timarch. p. 17 § 126, tau/thn e)c u(pokori/smatos titqh=s e)pwnumi/an e)/xw, Theophr. peri\ a)hdi/as: u(pokori/zesqai poppu/zwn (Ast ad loc.), or by lovers, Plat. Rep. V 474 E, h)\ e)rastou= u(pokorizome/nou, Arist. Plut. 1012, nhttari/on a)
 kai\ fa/ttion u(pekori/zeto (whence it stands for a ‘diminutive’, Rhet. III 2. 15); hence it is transferred to flattering or endearing expressions in general, and especially such as, in describing the moral character of anything, substitute some nearly associated virtue for a vice; to palliate, extenuate, gloss over. Examples occur in Plat. Rep. VIII 560 E (already referred to), III 400 E, a)noian u(pokorizo/menoi kalou=men w(s eu)h/qeian. Alexis, Tarantini Fr:3, Meineke, Fragm. Comm. III 484, a)=r' ou)k oi)=sq) o(/ti to\ kalou/menon zh=|n tou=to diatribh=s xa/rin o)/nom) e)sti
 u(poko/risma th=s a)nqrwpi/nhs moi/ras: Ovid, Ar. Am. II 657, nominibus mollire licet mala, followed by a long string of examples. Lucr. IV 1154 seq. Horat. Sat. I 3. 44—54. Thucydides, III 82, in a well-known passage, mentions this perversion of moral terms amongst the signs of demoralization prevalent in Greece at the period of the Corcyrean sedition, kai\ th
 ei)wqui=an a)ciw/sin tw=n o)noma/twn e)s ta\ e)/rga a)nth/llacan th=| dikaiw/sei k.t.l. See Ruhnken, ad Tim. p. 266, 6; Ernesti, Lex. Techn. Gr. s. v.; Shilleto, ad Dem. de F. L. § 293; Stallbaum, Plat. Rep. VI l. c.—Quintilian calls it derivatio verborum in the passage above quoted; and V 13. 25, describes it, si acri et vehementi fuerit usus oratione, eandem rem nostris verbis mitioribus proferre; which he then illustrates from Cicero's speeches. The opposite practice is described II 12. 4, est praeterea quaedam virtutum vitiorumque vicinia, qua maledicus pro libero, temerarius pro forti, effusus pro copioso accipitur. [Farrar's Chapters on Language, p. 281 sqq. S.]

kai\ tou\s e)n tai=s u(perbolai=s k.t.l.] The only difference between this and the preceding form of u(pokorismo/s is, that this is a special variety of the other, which substitutes the mean for the excess, but still according to the favourable interpretation of it. qrasu/ths is the u(perbolh/ of a)ndrei/a, Eth. N. II 7, 1107 b 3, 8, 1108 b 20, 1109 a 3, and a)swti/a, prodigality, the spendthrift's habit, c. 7, 1107 b 10, c. 8, 1108 b 24.

paralogistiko\n e)k th=s ai)ti/as] ‘liable to lead to a false inference’, Rhet. II 24. 4, ‘suberit fallacia manans ex causa’, Portus. ‘The mis-reasoning
(paralogistiko/n), or false reasoning, proceeding from the cause’, is the identification of two different causes which must necessarily produce dissimilar effects or actions; these latter are confounded by the fallacy, and ascribed to the same cause. The cause of an action is the proai/resis, the voluntary and deliberate purpose of it; otherwise represented as the ‘motive’ (the efficient cause). Now this cause or motive is different in the case of an act of wanton rashness, where there is no necessity (obligation) to incur the danger (ou(= mh\ a)na/gkh kinduneutiko/s), and of an act of virtue, true courage, which has a noble end, to\ kalo/n, in view: they are prompted by different motives, one belonging to the class ‘bad’, the other that of the ‘good’. This identification of the causes of the two actions leads to the ‘false inference’, that as the same cause produces the same effect, and the cause of both actions is the same, the effects are likewise the same, and both of them are acts of virtue. And then the further inference is drawn, that whatever a man will do from a less powerful motive, he will do a fortiori from one which is higher and more prevailing: the higher the motive or cause, the more powerful the impulse or effect. Similarly it is inferred that if a man is lavish to everybody, this must include his friends; by the rule, omne maius continet in se minus.

u(perbolh\ a)reth=s] Cic. Tusc. Q. V 26. 105, exsuperantia virtutis. u(perbolh/ and u(peroxh/ are frequently employed to express an excess above a given standard, average, or mean; the general conception of ‘excess’, of mere ‘superiority’; without the additional notion of a ‘vicious’ excess, a depravation or deviation from a true standard, which usually accompanies the word, and more especially in Aristotle's theory of virtue, where it stands for a class of moral vices. ‘Non significat hic nimium sed praestantia.’ Victorius. With the notion here expressed, comp. Eth. N. II 2, sub fin. 1105 a 9, peri\ de\ to\ xalepw/teron a)ei\ kai\ te/xnh gi/netai kai\ a)reth/: kai\ ga to\ eu)= be/ltion e)n tou/tw|. The average standard of excellence is surpassed, ‘good becomes better’, in proportion to the degree of difficulty surmounted in accomplishing any task. Pol. IV (VII) 1, 1323 b 3, kekosmhme/nois ei)s u(perbolh/n, lines 8 and 14, kata\ th
 u(peroxh/n, c. 4, 1326 a 21, Ib. b 12, th=s u(perbolh=s o(/ros, b 24. Pol. VI (IV) 12, 1296 b 19, poso
 de\ (by ‘quantity’ I mean) th
 tou= plh/qous u(peroxh/n. This sense of the word is also common in Demosthenes, as de Cor. 291. 24, e)gw\ de\ tosau/thn u(perbolh
 poiou=mai, and the same phrase de F. L. p. 447. 25. c. Mid. 519. 24, e)/sti de\ u(perbolh\ tw=n meta\ tau=ta. u(perbolh\ sukofanti/as, kaki/as, dwrew=n, a)naidei/as, w)mo/thtos, u(/brews, &c., in all which u(perbolh/ denotes not the vice, but merely the ‘measure’ of it.

skopei=n de\ kai\ par' oi(=s o( e)/painos] Compare III 14. 11. The same illustration of the topic, from Plato's Menexenus, is there repeated, with the addition of e)n tw=| e)pitafi/w|, ‘in the funeral oration’, meaning the Platonic dialogue. Socrates, Plato's principal character, or hero, or
spokesman, is here taken more Aristotelio as a substitute for Plato himself, whose opinions and sentiments he is supposed exactly to representBp. Fitzgerald (ap. Grant, ad Eth. N. VI 13. 3) remarks, on Eth. N. III 8. 6, that Aristotle in referring to Socrates prefixes the article when he speaks of him as Plato's interlocutor and representative, and omits it when he has the real historical Socrates in his mind. This is no doubt the general (Grant says, invariable) rule; but I have noted one exception in Pol. V (VIII) 7, 1342 b 23, where we find *swkra/tei without the article in a reference to Plato's Republic, III 398E. The rule is extended to other Platonic characters borrowed from history, as to
 *)aristofa/nhn (the Aristophanes of the Symposium), Pol. II 4, 1262 b 11, and o( *ti/maios (Plato's Timæus, not the real personage), de Anima A 3, 406 b 26.. The passage of the Menex. 235 D runs thus, ei) me
 ga de/oi *)aqhnai/ous e)n *peloponnhsi/ois eu)= le/gein h)\ *peloponnhsi/ous e)n *)aqhnai/ois, a)gaqou= a)
 r(h/toros de/oi tou= pei/sontos kai\ eu)dokimh/sontos: o(/tan de/ tis e)n tou/tois a)gwni/zhtai ou(/sper kai\ e)painei= ou)de
 me/ga dokei= eu)= le/gein.

On this passage, Quintilian, Inst. Or. III 7. 23, Interesse tamen Aristoteles putat ubi quidque laudetur aut vituperetur. Nam plurimum refert qui sint audientium mores, quae publice recepta persuasio: ut illa maxime quae probant esse in eo qui laudabitur credant, aut in eo contra quem dicemus ea quae oderunt. Ita non dubium erit iudicium quod orationem praecesserit.

to\ par' e(ka/stois ti/mion k.t.l.] These are appeals to national and class prejudices and preferences. We should attribute to the object of our encomium the possession of any gift, quality, accomplishment which happens to be esteemed by the particular audience that we are addressing; as in a company of Scythians it would be advisable to address ourselves to their national habits and modes of thinking, and to praise our hero for his skill in hunting or strength or bravery; at Sparta for patience and fortitude (Quint. u. s.); at Athens for literary accomplishments.

‘And in a word, (or, as a general rule), to refer (in praising any one before an audience of this kind) what they highly value to the kalo/n, since they appear to border closely upon one another’. ‘To refer ti/mia to to\ kalo/n’, is to invest them with a moral character, to\ kalo/n being the moral end, the right, the end of action. This is as much as to say that these things, which are so precious in their eyes, are not only valuable, but right in themselves, and therefore they do well to hold them in high esteem.
o(/sa kata\ to\ prosh=kon k.t.l.] ‘all that seems naturally to belong to a man in virtue of his birth or antecedents’, qualities, actions, achievements; ‘such things as were to be expected from him’.

prou+phrgme/nwn] ‘res antea virtute alicuius studioque possessas, laudes quas sibi quispiam labore suo comparaverit.’ Victorius. ‘his own previous acquisitions or possessions’; such as a stock of previous good, noble, great deeds, with which his new achievement, now the object of the encomium, is in accordance; as it ought to be. It is praiseworthy because it is the addition of a new honour, which, since honour itself is kalo/n, must also have a tendency to happiness (eu)daimoniko/n) and be right itself, and all that is right is praiseworthy.

But not only conformity with a man's antecedents may be adduced in praise of an action, but also the opposite, ‘if he surpass them, namely, and improve upon’ his own early condition and actions, or those of his ancestors, not acting in accordance with the past and what he was born to, but contrary to it, i.e. beyond it.

katallaktikw/teros] This does not necessarily contradict the topic of § 24; the irreconcilable temper there is only to be fostered against enemies, here it probably refers exclusively to friends: or if not, in Rhetoric either side may be taken as a subject of commendation, each suitable to a different kind or disposition of audience.
to\ tou= *)ifikra/tous—to\ tou= o)lumpioni/kou] Both of them already quoted, I 7. 32, q. v.

to\ tou= *simwni/dou] The epigram is given at length by Thucydides VI 59. Bergk, Fragm. Lyr. Gr. Simon. Fr. 115, p. 781 [p. 906, 2nd ed.]. *)andro\s a)risteu/santos e)n *(ella/di tw=n e)f' e(autou= | *(ippi/ou *)arxedi/khn h(/de ke/keuqe ko/nis. | *(\h patro/s te kai\ a)ndro\s a)delfw=n t' ou)=sa tura/nnwn | *pai/dwn t' ou)k h)/rqh nou=n e)s a)tasqali/hn.

e)k tw=n pra/cewn o( e)/painos] ‘praise is derived from actions’, i.e. it is only (moral) actions that can furnish topics of e)/painos, in its proper application. Praise and blame, moral approbation and disapprobation (Butler), are the tests of virtue and vice. o( me\n ga\r e)/painos th=s a)reth=s, Eth. N. I 12, 1101 b 32.
See on this subject, and upon what follows, the distinction of e)/painos, e)gkw/mion, and eu)daimonismo/s and makarismo/s, Introd. App. B to c. 9 §§ 33, 34, p. 212 seq.

i)/dion tou= spoudai/ou to\ kata\ proai/resin] On proai/resis, see note, c. 6. 26. The proai/resis, the deliberate moral purpose, is the distinctive characteristic of moral action. ‘Acting in accordance’ with this is consequently said to be ‘peculiar to’, the proprium, characteristic of ‘the man of worth’, or good man. In ‘praising’ any one, therefore, praise being, strictly speaking, confined to moral action, ‘we must endeavour to shew that his actions are directed by a deliberate moral purpose’.
fai/nesqai] ‘that he should be shewn to have’... ‘that it should be made clear that he has’... Note on I 7. 31, p. 141.

dio\ kai\ ta\ sumptw/mata k.t.l.] To establish a character for virtue in the object of your praise it is desirable to shew that his virtuous acts have been often repeated; and therefore, for the same purpose, to make an apparent addition to this number, we should assume as acts done with a moral purpose, w(s e)n proaire/sei, any ‘accidental coincidences’ and ‘pieces of luck’ (which may have happened to him); ‘for if a number of them can be brought forward ‘resembling’ the virtue or excellence that you wish to praise in him, they will be taken for ‘a sign’ of it and of the moral purpose or intention’ (which constitutes virtue). The mere repetition of the actions, to\ polla/kis fai/nesqai pepraxo/ta, is serviceable in producing this impression, because it seems to shew an inclination or fondness for them, and thence a certain direction of the proai/resis or choice, and a certain e(/cis or moral state, which are indications of a virtuous habit. sumptw/ma is a ‘concurrence’ or ‘accidental coincidence’ of one thing or act with another, between which there is no necessary connexion, and, like ta\ a)po\ tu/xhs, purely accidental. ‘su/mptwma est, cum quopiam aliquid agente, et quod nihil ad rem quae intervenit faciat, extrinsecus quippiam excitatum contingit; e.g. deambulante illo solem deficere: a)po\ tu/xhs vero, cum quopiam aliquid agente alicuius rei gratia, aliquid ex eo actu praeter propositum evenerit; ut scrobem facientem, ut arborem serat, thesaurum defossum invenire.’ Victorius. On tu/xh as an agent or supposed cause, see Introd. p. 218—224, Append. C to Bk. I. Both of Victorius's instances came from Aristotle [de div. per somn. infra, and Met. *d 30, 1025 a 16. S.]

On su/mptwma (rare in ordinary Greek) Phrynichus, xrh\ ou)=n suntuxi/an le/gein, h)\ lu/santas ou(/tw, sune/pesen au)tw=| to/de gene/sqai. *dhmosqe/nhs me/ntoi e)n tw=| kata\ *dionusodw/rou (p. 1295, 21) a(/pac ei)/rhke tou)/noma. The only other example of it, referred to by Lobeck, note ad loc. p. 248, in any writer earlier than Aristotle, is Thuc. IV 36, where it stands, like sumfora/, for an ‘unfortunate accident’. In Dem. it is equivalent to to\ sumba/n, which occurs in the same sentence. It occurs also in the Platonic Axiochus, 364 C, in the sense of ‘a disease’ (morbus, Ast), apparently as a special kind of ‘calamity’. In Aristotle I have noted the following instances: Pol. VIII (V) 4, 1304 a 1 (where it means ‘an accident’, as in Dem. and Phryn.) [ib. 6, 1306 b 6; II 12, 1274 a 12]; Top. *d 5, 126 b 36, 39, de div. per somn. c. 1, 462 b 27, 31, su/mptwma de\ to\ badi/zontos e)klei/pein to\n
h(/lion (an accidental coincidence), 463 a 2, tw=n sumptwma/twn ou)de\n ou)/t' a)ei\ gi/netai ou)/q) w(s e)pi\ to\ po/lu (it is a mere occasional, unaccountable accident), de respir. 4, 572 b 26; de Gen. Anim. IV 4 § 10, 770 b 6 [and 777 b 8]; Hist. An. VII 6. 4, 585 b 25, su/mptwsin (accident), IX 37. 6, 620 b 35, 40. 41, 626 a 29. Categ. 8, 9 b 15; p. 199 a 1; p. 1093 b 17. The medical sense of the word ‘symptom’ seems to be derived immediately from the Aristotelian ‘accidental coincidence’. It is an attendant sign of the disease, though a mere external indication, and not of the essence of it; like a sumbebhko/s or ‘accident’.

§§ 33, 34. See the Introd. p. 212 seq. Eth. Eud. II 1. 12, e)/ti d' oi( e)/painoi th=s a)reth=s dia\ ta\ e)/rga, kai\ ta\ e)gkw/mia tw=n e)/rgwn...e)/ti dia\ ti/ h( eu)daimoni/a ou)k e)painei=tai; o(/ti dia\ tau/thn ta)=lla, h)\ tw=| ei)s tau/thn a)nafe/resqai (Eth. N. I 12) h)\ tw=| mo/ria ei)=nai au)th=s. dio\ e(/teron eu)daimonismo\s kai\ e)/painos kai\ e)gkw/mion: to\ me\n ga\r e)gkw/mion lo/gos tou= kaq' e(/kaston e)/rgou, o( d) e)/painos toiou=ton ei)=nai kaqo/lou, o( d) eu)daimonismo\s te/los.

ta\ de\ ku/klw| ei)s pi/stin] ‘The encomium or panegyric is directed to deeds done’ (e)gkwmia/zomen pra/cantas, after they are done, the results of actions; e)/painos being of the actions themselves) ‘and the surrounding circumstances (such as noble birthThe topic of genealogy is put first of all and treated at length by the author of the Rhet. ad Alex., c. 35 (36). 4, seq. in his chapter on the encomiastic and vituperative kind of Rhetoric. This stands in marked contrast to the secondary and subordinate place here assigned to it by Aristotle, who seems rather to have agreed with Ovid l. c. as to its comparative value. and cultivation) serve for confirmation’. These ‘surrounding circumstances’ are a sort of setting of the gem, a frame for the picture, of which the real subject is the ‘deeds’ of the hero of the panegyric; what he has done himself;—nam genus et proavos et quae non fecimus ipsi, vix ea nostra voco. The ‘confirmation’ consists in this,— ‘for’ it is natural and probable that the offspring of the good should be good, and that one reared in such and such a way should turn out of such and such a character (fortes creantur fortibus et bonis: w(s a)lhqe\s h)=n a)/ra e)sqlw=n a)p' a)ndrw=n e)sqla\ gi/gnesqai te/kna, kakw=n d) o(/moia th=| fu/sei th=| tou= patro/s, Eur. Alcm. Fragm. VII Dind.). But still the real object of our praise is the e(/cis, the confirmed habit of virtue, the character and not the mere act; ‘because we should praise a man even if he had not done the (praiseworthy) act, if we supposed that his character was such as to incline him to do it’.

ta\ ku/klw| occurs in the same sense, of ‘surrounding’ (or accompanying) ‘circumstances’, Eth. Nic. III 12, 1117 b 2, ou) mh
 a)lla\ doceien a)
 ei)=nai to\ kata\ th
 a/ndrei/an te/los h(du/, u(po\ tw=n ku/klw| d' a)fani/zesqai, where ta\ ku/klw| are to\ luphro
 kai\ po/noi, ‘the pains and dangers by which courage is sur
rounded, while it looks through them to the pleasant end’; again, Rhet. III 14. 10, oi( dou=loi ou) ta\ e)rwtw/mena le/gousin a)lla\ ta\ ku/klw|.

makarismo\s kai\ eu)daimonismo\s au(toi=s me\n tau)ta/] It is quite true that the two terms are sometimes identified, (as in Eth. N. I 12, 1101 b 24, tou/s te ga\r qeou\s makari/zomen kai\ eu)daimoni/zomen kai\ tw=n a)ndrw=n tou\s qeiota/tous makari/zomen); but they are also distinguished, and then ma/kar and makari/a represent ‘blessedness, bliss’, a higher degree of happiness than eu)dai/mwn and eu)daimoni/a, which is the human form of happiness, while makari/a is the divine. ma/kares is specially applied to qeoi/ by Homer and Hesiod; as well as to the denizens of the maka/rwn nh=soi, the abode of the blessed after death.—au(toi=s is for a)llh/lois.
tou/tois d' ou) tau)ta/] ‘but not the same with the other two’, viz. e)/painos and e)gkw/mion: these are included in eu)daimonismo/s as virtue is in happiness.

e)/xei de\ koino\n ei)=dos k.t.l.] ‘There is a community of kind’ (the two may be referred to one species, one of the three kinds (ei)/dh) of Rhetoric, c. 3. 1, either the sumbouleutiko/n or the e)pideiktiko/n, as the occasion requires) ‘between praise and counsel or advice; for anything that you would suggest in advising may, by a mere change in the language, be converted into panegyric’. Quintilian has borrowed this, Inst. Or. III 7. 28, totum autem habet (laudativum genus) aliquid simile suasoriis; quia plerumque eadem illic suaderi hic laudari solent.

‘And so, when we know what we ought to do in any given case, or to be in respect of character, we must then use the acquired knowledge (of the right course of action, and the right character) as suggestions, by changing and converting the language’ (twisting so as to adapt it to our purpose; lit. turning them by the language). The example, and probably the topic itself, is taken from Isocrates, who in Panath. § 32 employs it as a suggestion or piece of advice, and in Evag. § 45 converts it into a topic of laudation—‘Now when thus expressed, it amounts to (has the value of, may serve for,) a suggestion, but when thus, it becomes laudation, “Proud, not of the accidents of fortune, but of the distinctions due to himself alone”’.—The example in the laudatory form from the Evagoras runs thus in the original, ou)k e)pi\ toi=s di\ tu/xhn, a)ll' e)pi\ toi=s di)
au(to\n gignome/nois. Aristotle was probably quoting from memory, as seems to have been his common practice.
With the passages of Isocrates comp. Ovid. Met. XIII 140, Nam genus et proavos et quae non fecimus ipsi, vix ea nostra voco.

du/natai] Rhet. II 5. 1. du/nasqai is often used in the sense of ‘having the value of, amounting to, equivalent to’, and is construed with the accusative. Herod. III 89, to\ de\ *babulw/nion ta/lanton du/natai *eu)boi+/das e(bdomh/konta mne/as. Xen. Anab. I 5. 6, o( si/glos du/natai e(pta\ o)bo/lous, Thuc. VI 40, lo/goi e)/rga duna/menoi, Eur. Med. 128, ta\ d' u(perba/llont) ou)de/na kairo
 du/natai qnatoi=s (where Elmsley and Pflugk understand kairo/n as used adverbially); also of the power, force, import, ‘meaning’, of a word, Ar. Met. *g 6, 1011 a 7, du/nantai d' ai( a)pori/ai ai( toiau=tai pa=sai to\ au)to/. Thuc. I 141, th
 au)th
 du/natai (is equivalent to) dou/lwsin. Id. VI 36, tou=to du/nantai (mean) ai( a)ggeli/ai, VII 58, du/natai de\ to\ *neodamw=des e)leu/qeron h)/dh ei)=nai. Ast's Lex. Plat. s. vv. du/namai, du/namis. The power or force which is contained in the primary sense of du/nasqai is expressed in the secondary sense in which it appears in the above passages as a particular kind of force, the value of anything, and hence the amount, (of which equality or equivalence is a species), or the import, or meaning (which again is a kind of equivalence) of it. And the accusative is nothing but a cognate accusative. That power or force is the original notion from which the secondary meanings are derived, is proved, if proof were needed, by the parallel use of i)sxu/ein to express precisely the same notion; Eth. Nic. II 3, 1105 b 2, to\ me
 ei)de/nai mikro
 h)\ ou)de
 i)sxu/ei, ta\ d' a)/lla ou) mikro
 a)lla\ to\ pa=n du/natai. As we say du/nasqai/ ti for tina\ du/namin, this construction is merely extended to the new kind of power which constitutes the secondary sense of the verb.

h( de\ le/cis k.t.l.] ‘The expression must be contradictory’ (the opposition of a)nti/fasis, kata/fasis and a)po/fasis, positive and negative, Categ. c. 10, p. 11 b 19, the fourth kind of ‘opposites’ ta\ a)ntikei/mena), i.e. it must be positive in one, and negative in the other, ‘when the prohibitive and the non-prohibitive are interchanged’. This is the case in the two examples; the one forbids pride, the other recommends or praises it—in a sense, provided it be directed to proper objects: by ‘not forbidding’ it contradicts the other.

tw=n au)chtikw=n] quae valent ad amplificandum. These are the
various modes of au)/chsis, which with the opposite, mei/wsis, constitutes the fourth of the koinoi\ to/poi. See Introd. p. 129, and (on II 26) p. 276.

Some of the special topics which follow as instances of au)chtika/ have been already mentioned in § 25, and appear again as giving a special importance or prominence to crimes in c. 14. 4, with the omission of the last. They, and others of the like kind, are included in the Rhet. ad Alex. 35 (36), 12, 13, under the general head of ‘Comparison’ with others for the purpose of laudation, to which they are all reducible. Comp. Cic. de Orat. II 85. 347—8, and Quint. Inst. Or. III 7. 16. With kai\ o(\ ma/lista pepoi/hken, ei) pepoi/hken must be supplied for the sense after kai/.

ta\ e)k tw=n xro/nwn kai\ tw=n kairw=n] ‘circumstances of time and opportunity’ give a praiseworthy character to particular actions at special times and seasons. This topic, equally applicable to comparative goods, has already occurred, c. 7. 32: and with para\ to\ prosh=kon, comp. c. 9. 31. If, for instance, a man performs an act of liberality, at a time of great pecuniary pressure, or in a case of emergency, or at a crisis of especial difficulty, he is then doing something para\ to\ prosh=kon, beyond what could naturally be expected from him, or any one else, and is entitled to especial credit for it. Similarly Victorius.

kai\ ei) polla/kis to\ au)to\ katw/rqwken] This topic is not to be confounded with to\ polla/kis fai/nesqai pepraxo/ta of § 32. That is a ‘repetition of the act’, this denotes the ‘repeated success’ in any attempt, the constant success is an indication—not infallible, or certain as a proof—of special skill: as if a man were to throw sixes several times running, even if it were by mere accident, the inference would be that he had a special knack or skill in throwing dice. ‘The constancy of the success gives it importance, and it will seem not accidental but due to the agent himself’.

kai\ ei) ta\ protre/ponta k.t.l.] ‘And any one’ (on whose account, in consequence of his actions and distinctions) ‘to commemorate whom incentives, stimulants, to virtue (‘encouragements’ to do the like), or marks of respect for it, have been invented or were ever ‘instituted’, must be a praiseworthy character’. This is the general case of the invention or establishment of any public mark of honour in commemoration of the great deeds or distinctions of any signal public benefactor, and as an incentive or encouragement to others to follow his example.

The next clause, ei)s o(\n prw=ton, is a particular example of the former of the two preceding cases, the ‘invention’, the first appropriation, of something in a person's honour. Victorius thinks that kateskeua/sqh is especially applied to the permanent establishment of an enduring monument, as a temple.
This topic again is afterwards applied to crimes, in c. 14. 4.

eu(/rhtai...kateskeua/sqh] We may note here the juxtaposition of the perf. and aor., apparently with no distinction of time intended. I have elsewhere noticed (Pref. to Transl. of Gorgias, pp. xv. xvi.) the difference of idiom between the Greek and English languages which obliges us sometimes to translate the Greek aorist by the English perfect. Other examples of the same inadvertence, confusion of tenses, or whatever else it is to be called, occur, I 3. 8, where praxqh=nai in the same sense and in the same opposition is repeated in the form pepra=xqai, Top. IX sub fin. p. 184 a 8, beboh/qhke me\n...te/xnhn d' ou)pare/dwken. Many instances are found in Sophocles, which in a writer so subtle in the distinctions of language might lead one to think that he at any rate distinguishes them with a meaning. I leave the reader to judge. Philoct. 664, 666, (Herm. 676), lo/gw| me\n e)ch/kous' o)/pwpa d) ou) ma/la, 927—8, oi(=a/ m) ei)rga/sw, oi(=) h)pa/thkas. 1172, ti/ m) w)/lesas; ti/ m) ei)/rgasai; Antig. 406 (Dind.), present and aorist, kai\ pw=s o(ra=tai ka)pi/lhptos h(|re/qh; 1228—9, Aj. 31, Trach. 364, 5, Arist. Ran. 1010—11 (Dind.), pepoi/hkas...a)pe/deicas, Plat. Phaedr. 231 A, a(/ te kai\ die/qento, kai\ a(\ pepoih/kasin eu)=. Dem. de F. L. § 228, ou)t' h)nw/xlhsa ou)/te...bebi/asmai.

ei)s o(\n prw=ton...] The novelty of the distinction, invented expressly for the occasion, marks a still higher sense entertained of the value of the service or the virtue of the act which it is intended to commemorate.

e)gkw/mion e)poih/qh] poiei=n is here loosely used, by the so-called figure zeugma (on c. 4. 6, note 1), in connexion with e)gkw/mion and the statue of Harmodius and Aristogeiton in two different senses—as to Hippolochus, until we know who he was, and in what way commemorated, the application must remain uncertain—of writing the panegyric, and ‘setting up the statue in the market-place’.

Of Hippolochus nothing is known. It seems that Aristotle intended the e)gkw/mion to refer to him. We should therefore insert a semicolon, or at least a comma after *(ippo/loxon, in order to connect the panegyric and the statue with those that they severally concern: ei)s is to be repeated after kai/. ‘And one (is especially praiseworthy) in whose honour a panegyric was first composed, as it was for Hippolochus; (and as the setting up of their statue in the market was ‘done’ first, e)poih/qh, i.e.), and as the privilege of having their statue erected in the market was granted for the first time to Harmodius and Aristogeiton’. Thucydides in his episodical account of the assassination and the circumstances that led to it, VI 54—59, makes no mention of the statue; nor Aristotle Pol. VIII (V) 10, where the attack on Hipparchus is spoken of. Pausanias, 1 8. 5, says, ou) po/r)r(w de\ e(sta=sin *(armo/dios kai\ *)aristogei/twn oi( ktei/nantes *(/ipparxon: ai)ti/a de\ h(/tis e)ge/neto k.t.l. He is describing the a)gora/, though he does not expressly name it. (See Smith's Dict. of Geogr. Art. Athena, p. 293 b.)

e)pi\ tw=n e)nanti/wn] ‘in the opposite cases’, of men to whom any reproach or stigma, mark of disapprobation (the test of vice) was first attached. ‘cum nempe quempiam aut solum aut primum aut cum paucis flagitium admisisse ostendemus, turpitudinem ipsius valde augebimus.’ Victorius. On the topics of vituperation, Quintilian, Inst. Or. III 7. 19—22.

ka)\n mh\ kaq' au(to\n eu)porh=|s k.t.l.] ‘and if you have not enough to say about your hero himself, and in his own person, then institute a comparison between him and others... only the comparison must be with men of distinction, (reputation); because the amplifying power of the comparison and the impression of nobility which it creates, arise from the superiority which is attributed to him over those who are themselves worthy and good’. The same topic is recommended in the Rhet. ad Alex. c. 3 (4). 6.

o(/per *)isokra/ths—dikologei=n] ‘which was Isocrates’ custom, owing to his want of practice in forensic pleading’. Read a)sunh/qeian [with A^{c}] for two reasons. First, what is meant is that Isocrates cultivated the habit of comparing his hero with others in consequence of his want of actual practice in the law-courts.
